HEADLINE: The Governor's 'Monsoon' Budget 

 BODY:
Gov. George Pataki unveiled an $88 billion financial plan for next year that would close a huge gap with a breathtaking array of fiscal gimmicks. It relies on more than $3 billion siphoned away from reserve funds, some of them nearly unknown to people outside the tiny circle of state budget experts. Mr. Pataki is running for re-election this year, and if he is hoping that voters will not understand what he's doing to make the numbers add up, he is probably right. Even in New York, a state famous for the incomprehensibility of its fiscal planning, this budget would have to win a special award for opaqueness. 
 Normally, there would be a sound financial reason for attacking almost everything Mr. Pataki is trying to do. But this is not a normal year. The basic principle upon which he says the budget rests is that this is the time to raid various "rainy day" funds. In the combination of the recession and Sept. 11, he declared, "We didn't get a rainy day but we got a monsoon." He was making a legitimate point. Some of his ideas seem defensible. New York is suffering, in part, because its chief city was the victim of a terrorist attack that was none of its own doing. If the governor has to rely on gimmicks to get through this crisis, no one in the state, or in the bond markets, is likely to blame him. 
 But it is important to make sure Mr. Pataki doesn't go overboard. The state's budget gap is not entirely a result of Sept. 11, or even the recession. Like Washington, New York passed a long string of tax cuts to take effect in the future. Now they are coming due, and next year the new loss of revenue will amount to more than $300 million.
Mr. Pataki is also relying on a lot of "one-shot" revenues to pay for ongoing expenses. The financial markets, which have long been dubious about New York's commitment to responsible budgeting, are not going to be impressed with the fact that the state wants to raid its mortgage fund to pay its current bills. The budget also calls for tapping into nearly $1 billion in federal funds set aside for welfare recipients. At a time when welfare rolls seem likely to grow, and some longtime recipients who lose federal benefits are going to become the state's responsibility, this seems risky.
Mr. Pataki proposed cutting the rate of growth for several school aid programs, drawing criticism from Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Democrat. But the governor came up with a highly unusual proposal that appears to be aimed at helping New York City provide salary hikes for its teachers. The state has long owed the city more than $400 million in a complicated fight about reimbursements. The governor now wants to borrow that $400 million and send it to the city over the next two years. Although no one said so yesterday, the implications are that Mayor Michael Bloomberg and the Board of Education could use the money to settle the long-simmering teacher contract negotiations. That would put the city in the position of committing to permanent salary hikes and paying for them with money that will never return. It was an irresponsible idea when Mr. Pataki did it last week, in a similar arrangement, to increase the pay of health care workers. No matter how much the teachers -- or the health care workers -- deserve more pay, it is still irresponsible today.
Really serious budget crises seem to hit New York State every generation or so. In the 1970's, Gov. Hugh Carey famously highlighted his spending cuts by declaring that "the days of wine and roses are over." There is some spending restraint in this budget, with thousands of jobs being eliminated in state government. But that is a pittance compared with what many thought would be proposed. This is a budget that postpones the end of the days of wine and roses by finding more reserve funds, it seems, than there are caves in Afghanistan.

HEADLINE: GROUND ZERO: SMALL BUSINESS; 
Survey Calls Loss of Jobs Big Problem For Retailers

BYLINE:  By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
The disappearance of 100,000 jobs from Lower Manhattan as a result of the attack on the World Trade Center is the key reason that most stores and restaurants in the area are struggling to survive, according to a survey conducted earlier this month by a downtown business group.
 For businesses that reopened but found their corporate and individual customers had vanished, the findings suggest that efforts to attract and retain commercial tenants in the neighborhood should be a top priority, said Carl Weisbrod, the president of the Alliance for Downtown New York, the group that conducted the survey. 
 "The most important thing is expanding the client base," he said. "We can't get all 100,000 jobs back immediately, but we have an opportunity to get tens of thousands back." 
The survey results, though unsurprising, represent the first attempt to document the hardship experienced by merchants in a wide swath of Lower Manhattan that includes TriBeCa as well as the area below Chambers Street. The door-to-door survey covered 861 stores and restaurants -- about 75 percent of the area's retail establishments, the alliance said.
As might be expected, the worst hardships were experienced by retailers west of Broadway and north of Liberty Street, the area closest to the World Trade Center. Of those, 88 percent reported a "severe decrease" in business during the last quarter. In the area as a whole, 62 percent of the retailers characterized their losses as severe.
About half the retailers said fourth-quarter sales volume was down 20 percent to 50 percent over the same period in 2000, while 27 percent said their sales volume had decreased 51 percent to 80 percent.
The retailers cited a variety of reasons for the decline, including blocked streets, negative perceptions about the condition of downtown, changes in customers' transportation patterns, the presence of street vendors in front of their stores and the loss of residential customers who had moved out of the area.
But 76 percent cited the loss of corporate clients as a significant factor in their sales losses.
"The bread and butter are the corporate clients," said Moshe Hacohen, an owner of Flowers of the World, a florist that has been on Hanover Square for 15 years and also had a shop in the World Trade Center. Mr. Hacohen estimated that business at his Hanover Square store is down 30 percent.
Mr. Hacohen said he is no longer hopeful that he can open another store downtown to replace the one at the World Trade Center. So far, the only help he has received was a $16,000 state grant. He did not apply for a small business loan, in part because of the requirement that personal property be used as collateral. 
And like many downtown business owners, Mr. Hacohen said, he has yet to collect any insurance for his losses. According to the survey, only five percent of the retailers have received full payment for insurance claims, and 14 percent have received partial payments.
The alliance's report paints a gloomy picture, saying that most retailers are pessimistic about the current quarter. But Mr. Weisbrod said business might improve now that the Statue of Liberty is once again open to tourists and because local transportation has been steadily improving. Century 21, the popular discount store, is expected to reopen at the end of February.
The survey's accuracy was challenged by the management of the South Street Seaport. The survey said that 69 percent of the merchants reported a severe decrease in business in the fourth quarter, and 28 percent a modest decline. Paul Harnett, a vice president and general manager of the shopping center, said that according to sales reports filed with his office, 33 percent of the 100 stores at the seaport showed a slight increase in sales over last year.
A spokeswoman for the Alliance said the group stood by its research.
Of the retailers canvassed by the alliance, those south of Liberty Street and East of Broadway -- the area closest to the New York Stock Exchange -- fared best. Marvin Rafeld, the owner of 14 Wall Street Jewelers, said that business began returning to near-normal levels in November. But he remains concerned about the future.
"As aggressive as the government is being -- and there has been a lot of attention and a lot of government assistance," he said, "unfortunately that is not enough. People must be encouraged to return to the area."
There does not appear to be a shortage of office space. The area below Canal Street has about 8.3 million square feet of available office space, according to the real estate company Cushman & Wakefield.

HEADLINE: A BUDGET FOR NEW YORK: OVERVIEW; 
Pataki's Budget Would Close $5 Billion Gap

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 22 

 BODY:
With a recession driving down tax collections, Gov. George E. Pataki proposed an $88.6 billion budget today that avoids deep cuts to most agencies largely by spending the state's reserve funds and coaxing more money from Washington.
 The Republican governor, who is preparing to run for a third term this year, said the confluence of terrorist attacks on Sept. 11 and the recession had devastated tax revenues, opening a $5.1 billion shortfall in the budget for the next fiscal year, which begins April 1. 
 Yet Mr. Pataki vowed he would not put off any tax cuts scheduled to take effect this year and reasserted his creed that cutting taxes creates jobs. State aid for schools would remain frozen at this year's level and spending across most other agencies, many still struggling after last year's bare-bones budget, would remain flat under his plan. Only spending on health programs and economic development would rise slightly. 
The governor, who repeatedly congratulated himself for salting away money during the last seven years, said he would close the budget gap through a series of measures including spending those built-up reserves to bail out the government.
"We are using reserves that were set aside for a rainy day," the governor said. "We didn't get a rainy day, but we got a monsoon."
All told, spending would rise by $4 billion, or about 4.7 percent, but the part of the budget supported with state taxes and fees would grow only about 1.6 percent. The state is counting on about $3 billion in additional federal aid, some of which Congress may not approve.
The governor's plan offers little relief to New York City beyond the $10 billion in federal disaster aid Congress has already approved. The state would give the city an additional $273 million for welfare and Medicaid costs. The subway system, however, would receive $342 million in new funds to avoid a rise in fares. In addition, the city's school board would be given the authority to borrow about $200 million under a complex scheme in which the state would pay back the bonds.
In a speech outlining the plan, Mr. Pataki laid out the underpinnings of his re-election campaign. He vowed not to lay off state workers or raise taxes. He said he would devote $200 million to setting up a new office for state security and he announced a modest $50 million in seed money to spur economic development in upstate New York and on Long Island. He promised jobs, jobs and more jobs. He also took pains to portray New York as a state suffering economic hardship because of the terrorist attacks. He appealed to people's patriotism and asked for sacrifice.
Mr. Pataki said he would close the $5.1 billion gap by freezing hiring at state agencies, putting off growth in most of them, spending about $1.1 billion in various reserve funds, refinancing some debt and obtaining more in federal grants with some creative requests. The plan also hinges on skimming unspent balances off several special-purpose funds, among them the state mortgage agency and the Environmental Protection Fund, to get about $562 million for the state's operating expenses.
"It's a budget that calls for extraordinary measures to deal with extraordinary circumstances," Mr. Pataki said. "Either we control the crisis, or the crisis will control us."
But some of the more tricky maneuvers in the plan immediately drew fire from the Democrats who control the Assembly. For instance, Mr. Pataki is asking students who receive state scholarships to forgo a third of the money until after graduation, when they would be repaid with interest, but only if they graduate. Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver said the idea was "the equivalent of requiring students to buy state bonds."
The governor's plan provides almost no extra money for schools, locking state aid at this year's $14 billion. But it would allow New York City's Board of Education and four other urban districts to borrow money equivalent to the amount the state owes them from past years, known as "prior year claims." Under the proposal, the state would pay the interest and principal on the bonds.
For the city's Board of Education, it would mean a infusion of $204 million in each of the next two years, money the Bloomberg administration desperately needs as it tries to reach a labor agreement with the city's powerful teachers union. 
Democrats complained Mr. Pataki did not keep all his promises to the schools. As he has in the past, he proposed simplifying the cumbersome school aid formulas, collapsing several streams of revenue into one block grant. He also proposed cutting money that would have reduced class sizes in the lower grades and that would have established all-day kindergarten statewide, programs he had previously pledged to support.
"This budget fails again to fulfill our commitment to the state's 4-year-olds," Mr. Silver said. "This is the second year in a row he has failed to live up to that promise."
Despite holding the line on spending in most agencies, the governor's plan would winnow the state's work force by about 4,850 jobs, to 194,500 people, by March 2003. Most of those jobs would be lost through attrition. In addition, about 1,500 state employees would be offered early retirement with a buyout. Nearly 600 jobs would be cut in the prison system, while the mental hospitals and clinics would lose about 400.
Mr. Pataki is also planning a piece of budgetary sleight-of-hand with the Environmental Protection Fund, which pays for parkland acquisition, recycling and other programs. He and the Legislature never appropriated the $125 million from the fund this year as he had originally planned, much to the dismay of many environmentalists.
Now the governor has asked the Legislature to appropriate $250 million for the next two months and all of the next budget year, but he then plans to take $100 million out to spend for other purposes. He also plans to use the fund to pay for some environmental programs now paid for with general tax revenues. He maintains that the fund collects enough money through a special tax of land sales to pay for the new costs, but some environmentalists are skeptical.
Mr. Pataki's spending plan also uses about $884 million in surplus welfare grants the state has built up over the last few years as more and more people have been moved off the welfare rolls.
The federal grants have built up in a Washington bank account and are supposed to be used for programs that help people get jobs, like day care for the working poor.
But the governor plans to spend $438 million from the fund to offset a tax cut for poor people with children, $345 million for scholarships, and $61 million for preschool programs. It remained unclear if the federal welfare authorities would object to those expenditures.
The use of the welfare-fund surplus is only one of several ways the governor is trying to maximize the money flowing from Washington to Albany. He is also proposing changes to Medicaid formulas and a tax on nursing home receipts that he contends the federal government will reimburse under Medicaid.
From a political standpoint, the budget seemed a relief to many lawmakers. Mr. Pataki had tried to compare the state's financial condition to the Great Depression. He said the state could lose as much as $9 billion in revenues in the next fiscal year.
As a result, the $5 billion budget gap -- which will be caused mostly by a drop of nearly $4 billion in personal income-tax collections -- looked good to many lawmakers. Few on either side of the aisle could take issue with closing the gap by squeezing more money from Washington or spending the total of $2.5 billion in reserves and one-time revenues.
"I'm still looking for the gloom and doom lots of people were forecasting," Senator Joseph L. Bruno said. "And I don't see it."
Mr. Bruno said he was not at all troubled by spending down the state's reserves or using up one-time windfalls, like the $880 million welfare surplus. Asked about the one-shot revenues, Mr. Bruno said: "Whatever they are, they are appropriate."
Some lawmakers worried that the governor's plan used up most of the surplus money to be had, leaving the legislative leaders little new revenues to pay for programs they preferred. "It's too early to tell where he left room for the Legislature to have its greatest impact on this budget," one high-ranking Assembly Democrat said.

HEADLINE: Kmart Files Bankruptcy, Largest Ever For a Retailer 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM and LESLIE KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
The Kmart Corporation filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday, the largest such filing ever made by a retailer.
 Speculation on Kmart's financial condition had been intensifying for weeks as the company faced a cash shortage that was accelerated by a slump in holiday sales and a failed price-cutting campaign. But Kmart's underlying problems had been mounting for some time as it lost ground to Wal-Mart, the nation's No. 1 retailer, and Target, the discount retailer known for its relatively fashionable merchandise. 
 Kmart, the nation's third-largest discount retailer, said yesterday that all 2,114 of its currently operating stores would remain open for now. But analysts say that several hundred stores will be closed after a corporate review is completed at the end of April, which could mean layoffs for thousands of the company's 240,000 workers. Kmart will also extricate itself from leases on some 350 stores that it has already closed or leased to other companies. 
Since its start in 1962, Kmart has become a fixture on the American landscape, known for its blue light specials, in-store announcements ("Attention, Kmart shoppers!") and the big red K's that adorn its storefronts.
Kmart's fall is bad news for an economy already stung by Enron, which made the largest bankruptcy filing in history less than two months ago, and ripples will be felt by creditors and suppliers. Yesterday, companies ranging from Eastman Kodak to Delta Galil Industries, a small Israeli underwear maker, said they had millions of dollars in payments outstanding.
Kmart's stock, which closed as high as $13.16 last August, fell another 60 percent yesterday, closing at 70 cents. This will be a blow to some workers, who as a group have about 14 percent of their 401(k) assets in Kmart stock. 
Charles C. Conaway, Kmart's chief executive, said in a statement that "after considering a wide range of alternatives, it became clear that this course of action was the only way to truly resolve the company's most challenging problems."
In filings with the United States Bankruptcy Court in the Northern District of Illinois, in Chicago, Kmart listed $16.29 billion in assets and $10.35 billion in debt. At the end of the financial quarter ended Oct. 31, Kmart had $366 million in cash.
The company has secured $2 billion to finance its continuing operations from a group of banks led by J. P. Morgan Chase, and it said it would emerge from bankruptcy protection sometime next year. Analysts, however, said the company had yet to develop a successful strategy to position itself against the other retail giants.
Wal-Mart has laid claim to the penny pinchers. Target has identified with style-conscious suburbanites by offering modish brands like kitchen utensils and teakettles designed by the architect Michael Graves. "It's not a natural gimme that there is room for Kmart," said Emme P. Kozloff, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein. 
Eighteen months ago, when Mr. Conaway took Kmart's helm, he promised that a turnaround would be apparent in two years. Instead, tactics like trying to beat Wal-Mart on pricing and reducing advertising in circulars have not worked.
Kmart has long been known for its boom and bust cycles. The chain was started in 1962 as a discount division of the S. S. Kresge Company, a five-and-dime store that was F. W. Woolworth's chief competitor during the first part of the century. The vast stores were put outside cities in bustling new suburbs.
At first Kmart and the suburbs were a perfect match. The chain grew rapidly, and housewives reveled in its well-priced abundance. Within a decade, Kmart had 673 stores and rivaled Sears, Roebuck as the nation's largest retailer. But it was during this period of rapid expansion that Kmart grew complacent. In 1973, the company experimented with using computers that could track inventory and make orders. But store managers, who filled out orders by hand, rejected the computers, predicting, accurately, that the new technology would reduce their autonomy, according to "In Sam We Trust," a history of the rise of Wal-Mart (1998, Times Books). 
Kmart decided to pass on computers, but its competitors did not. Sam Walton put the systems in anywhere he could afford to, and the added efficiencies paid off over time. Today, as the world's largest retailer -- and one of its most efficient -- Wal-Mart does roughly fives times the business of Kmart, $200 billion in annual sales.
Over the years, Kmart failed to keep its stores looking fresh, and its fashions became dowdy. So ingrained in the public culture was Kmart as a purveyor of polyester that in the 1989 film "Rain Main," Dustin Hoffman's autistic character yells Kmart insults.
Kmart tried hard to fix its problems. In 1997, the company signed up Martha Stewart, then an emerging merchandising star. Last year, her company, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, did $1.6 billion in sales through Kmart. Yesterday, Martha Stewart said she would continue with Kmart while it was in bankruptcy despite being owed roughly $13 million. 
Kmart has every intention of reviving itself, but the track record of smaller discounters that have run into trouble shows how difficult such changes can be. Montgomery Ward tried to come back after declaring bankruptcy in 1997 and even had the backing of General Electric, its parent, but it declared bankruptcy again at the end of 2000 and went out of business. Bradlees emerged from bankruptcy in 1999 only to file again the next year and go out of business.
Kmart's urban stores, including 10 in New York, are least likely to close because they generally have higher sales volumes and less competition from Wal-Mart and Target, consultants said. But elsewhere, the outlook is often bleak.
"In suburban and rural areas, Wal-Mart is pounding Kmart into the ground," said Burt Flickinger III, a retail consultant. "In those areas, Kmart stores will largely go dark."

HEADLINE: A Clubhouse Divided Over Taking In Guests; 
Century Members Debate Rentals

BYLINE:  By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
Is the venerable Century Association destined to become a bedroom community?
 A proposal to construct 15 guest bedrooms -- by tacking on an additional floor to the association's five-story Beaux-Arts building at 7 West 43rd Street -- has provoked heated debate among members of one of Manhattan's most prestigious clubs. 
 The Century's managers say that the room-rental plan would provide a much-needed new source of income and ensure the club's continued existence. But opponents of the proposal worry about the $6.5 million debt that the club would incur, as well as two years of construction disruption. Others fear that the presence of a hotelish operation in the protected universe of the Century would violate the tranquil camaraderie of the club's comfortable meritocracy. 
The Century counts some 2,400 members, many from New York's cultural, professional and political worlds. The 2001 membership directory lists Brooke Astor, Tina Brown, William F. Buckley Jr., Ric Burns, Chuck Close, Ellen V. Futter, Frank O. Gehry, Betsy Gotbaum, Philip Johnson, Henry A. Kissinger, Robert M. Morgenthau, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, David Rockefeller, Felix G. Rohatyn and Andy Rooney. 
For decades, Century members, who call themselves Centurions, have availed themselves of room-rental arrangements with clubs in other cities, but have not been able to reciprocate at the Century. Nevertheless, some of the club's members are operatic in their opposition, even though the practice is commonplace at many other clubs in Manhattan and around the world.
The most passionate naysayers have declined to state their case publicly, given club rules requiring that members take responsibility "for the exclusion from the clubhouse of reporters and news photographers on assignment." Members must also "prevent public mention of discussions or activities of any character," according to the rules, "and avoid assisting journalists who might do so." (This is not so easily accomplished, since so many journalists are club members, including editors and writers from The New York Times.) 
If the controversy over the so-called "bedrooms plan" would seem to be a tempest in a bone-china teapot -- as one 30-year member called it -- some at the Century are especially exercised over the very loss of the club's decorum. "I don't want a disagreement over the building of the bedrooms to make the club look frivolous," said John O'Keefe, a public-relations consultant and New York City Opera board member who has been a club member for three decades. "This club has a seriousness of purpose, and this issue will be resolved in a civilized way."
The core of the new dispute involves the club's survival. The bedroom proposal is important to the club's future solvency, according to a letter sent to members by Louis S. Auchincloss, the club's president, and J. Robert Moskin, the chairman of the club's house committee. 
The letter, obtained by The Times, warns that "meeting future cost increases will place severe demands on the level of dues, the size of the membership, and the number of private events in the clubhouse," adding, "None of these prospects is attractive."
The letter warns that the bedrooms must be built because club managers do not want to increase the membership substantially, raise dues from their current yearly level of $1,900 for local residents or witness "still more strangers partying here," a reference to the rental of the club spaces for weddings and other events. 
During a Jan. 8 membership meeting to discuss the bedroom plan, some questions were so skeptical that Mr. Auchincloss postponed a membership vote on the bedroom proposal that had been planned for the club's monthly meeting in February, according to one attendee. Since then, some members have been lobbying to vote down the notion. 
"We are waiting for another report to be done," Mr. Auchincloss said, "since there was concern about the financing. They need to know how to finance it in this difficult era." He was willing to speak on the record to a reporter, he said, "because I feel we are a landmark and the press is entitled to certain information." But he declined to discuss the specifics of the controversy.
On Jan. 14, Mr. Moskin began sending prepaid postcards to Century members in an informal, nonbinding and anonymous poll to determine how many favor the construction project and how many might actually use the rental rooms for themselves or their families. Ultimately, the club's board of managers alone "could implement such a decision," Mr. Auchincloss said, "but we would like to have everybody vote anyway."
The new report certainly has been well preceded. Last year an analysis by two Century club members, the structural engineer Robert Silman, and Byron Bell, the architect who oversaw the renovation of the club's stately 1891 Stanford White building a decade ago, concluded that "it is entirely feasible to add bedrooms," according to the letter by Mr. Auchincloss and Mr. Moskin, dated Nov. 26, 2001. Another analysis estimated that the construction cost would be $6.5 million, including furnishings. 
The club's board of management approved the house committee's recommendation that a total of 15 bedrooms with private bathrooms be built, adding a locker room for the women who work at the Century, as well as an administrative space. To do this, the club, which is near Fifth Avenue, would expand its fifth floor and add a sixth.
The expansion would depend on approval from the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission. "We are told that there would be no objection," Mr. Auchincloss said, "as long as the additional floor can't be viewed from the street."
The letter proposes that most of the $6.5 million construction cost be borrowed on a 15-year loan. 
The annual payments on a loan at 7.5 percent would amount to about $723,000, and the club would need to charge at least $190 per room per night at the city's current average 70 percent occupancy rate, according to Sean Hennessey, director of the hotel consulting business at the accounting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers. 
"Generally the rooms available at such clubs are highly desirable and perform very well for them," said Mr. Hennessey, who is not a Century member and is not involved in the proposal. "The $190 price would compare very favorably to other hotels, given the exclusivity factor. And it could contribute to the profitability of other aspects of the club." 
The letter sent to members also tries to reassure them that annual dues will not be raised to add the bedrooms, and that no special assessment will be levied on the Centurions, who supported a $6 million budget in the fiscal year that ended last September. 
Nevertheless, many members are worrying that the plan will saddle the club with a sizable debt in uncertain economic times, in an era when graying members of many city clubs are aging out and the clubs themselves are fighting for relevance. "The vagaries of the hotel business are like the vagaries of construction projects," one longtime member said. "There is no guarantee that a high occupancy rate will repay the debt, nor that the construction project will come in on budget."
Some members also object to the construction disruption. The letter acknowledges that the work would be accomplished during two successive summers. The club would be closed for two months during the first year, and for six weeks during the second. But, the letter insists, "few club activities or events would be disrupted."
Yet some club members do not welcome the prospect of a profitable new attic. "Mr. Auchincloss is a man of exceptional taste, and I'm sure he's trying to do the best for the club," said Peter Duchin, the orchestra leader and member for two decades. "But my first objection is aesthetic. If Stanford White wanted to have bedrooms, he'd have put them there." 
Other demurrers object to the addition of a hotel reception and concierge operation in the club's classic lobby. Some members have also expressed fears that, after the project is completed, an influx of new room-renting strangers may alter the intimate character of the club. "I don't want to see someone's kids running through the bar," Mr. Duchin said with a laugh. 
The Century was formed in 1847 "for the purpose of promoting the advancement of art and literature." Mark Twain called it "the most unspeakably respectable club in the United States." Today members can still honor tradition by taking meals at the long table -- an oasis for unaccompanied club members -- and quaffing Silversmiths, rum drinks on shaved ice in silver cups.
The club has often embraced change exceedingly slowly, and, on occasion, messily. In 1988 women were admitted to the club amid debate that was positively bitter; some members resigned. And in 1990, angry words were exchanged over the association's sale of a prized 1847 painting, William Sidney Mount's "Power of Music," to pay for renovations. (The work was bought in 1991 by the Cleveland Museum of Art.) 
The current bedrooms plan has left many Centurions on the fence. "I'm agnostic on the subject," the historian Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. said. "I haven't taken a position yet." 
Others express a fair amount of indifference. "They can put the beds in," the author Peter Quinn said, laughing, "just as long as I don't have to make them." 
Or, as the author Robert A. Caro put it, "I have devoted zero thought to this." 
In some respects, the conflict may be generational. "The older members want to keep things the way they are," Mr. Quinn said. "What a surprise." 
But when they speak about the Century, it is plain that many of the more senior members see the club as a sacred place, and subscribe to the if-it-ain't-broke-don't-fix-it theory. Yet Mr. Auchincloss remains optimistic. "It seems to me probable," he said, "that it will be worked out."

Conrad/The New York Times); (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)(pg. B1); A painting by Charles Yardley Turner depicting a Saturday night in 1894 at the Century Club, then as now one of the city's most prestigious. (pg. B7)

HEADLINE: McGreevey Plans to Eliminate Some State Jobs 

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 22 

 BODY:
In his most dramatic step yet to address New Jersey's looming budget problems, Gov. James E. McGreevey said today that he planned to send layoff notices to more than 600 state workers beginning Wednesday.
 Speaking to an audience of 350 at Montclair State University, Mr. McGreevey used the first town hall meeting of his week-old administration to unveil bleak news: despite a 5 percent cut in spending, the state budget crisis is so severe that he must reduce the size of its work force immediately to close the $2.8 billion deficit for the fiscal year ending June 30. 
 Although 600 nonunion middle management employees will receive the layoff notices, it is unclear how many jobs will actually be eliminated from the state payroll.
Some of the workers are holdovers from the previous administration who will be replaced, Mr. McGreevey said, while others can agree to be "bumped" to a different job classification.
"In the end, we expect a limited reduction in the size of the state work force," the governor said to reporters after the meeting. "This is part and parcel of the 5 percent reduction in state expenditures, which I intend to save $100 million."
The governor said it was unclear how much the state would save by cutting the jobs, or whether further rounds of layoffs were expected, but he said he would discuss some details of the plan Wednesday, when he is to speak before a group of local government leaders at a meeting of the League of Municipalities at the New Jersey State House.
"We are cutting state government across the board," the governor said. "Tomorrow, layoff notices will go out to upwards of 600 state employees, which is tough. I'll need the mayors and the school boards to understand fiscal responsibility and live within their means."
Since the day he was elected, Mr. McGreevey has warned that the state's budget gap will require severe reductions in the size of state government, and he has pledged to keep a campaign promise not to raise taxes.
Last Wednesday, his first full day in office, he ordered all commissioners to cut 5 percent from their budgets.
This morning he also ordered administrators of New Jersey's public colleges and universities to trim 5 percent from their operating budgets, saving the state $65 million but raising the possibility of tuition increases by next school year.
Mr. McGreevey said he was reluctant to trim the aid, and he pledged to meet with educators and school administrators to map a long-term strategy for higher education in New Jersey.
"I understand that it is the state that best educates her children that will be most competitive in the new economy," he said.
Administrators at several New Jersey colleges and universities said they hoped to take measures that would cut spending without curtailing educational programs. Francis L. Lawrence, the president of Rutgers University, said that there would be no tuition increase this year but that the school would stop hiring immediately.
Mr. McGreevey's plan to reduce the size of the state work force is the most specific cost-cutting plan he has released to date. But his persistent warnings about the deficit have come to dominate the state's political discussions. Many elected officials preparing to attend Wednesday's League of Municipalities meetings were bracing themselves for deep cuts in state aid.

HEADLINE: How Vulnerable Are Nuclear Plants? 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Nuclear Reactors as Terrorist Targets" (editorial, Jan. 21):
 There is much more than enough radioactive material at the Indian Point nuclear power plant to require the permanent evacuation of a 50-mile radius around it, should the material be released into the atmosphere. 
 When one considers the dire consequences that visited the economy with the destruction of 16 acres of office space in Lower Manhattan, the result of losing every single bit of infrastructure, and every job, in the New York metropolitan area is too horrible to contemplate for long. 
But since that is the worst-case scenario with Indian Point, we must ask ourselves: Is the destruction of an entire metropolitan area, and probably the entire American economy, a risk worth taking?

MARYJANE SHIMSKY
Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.
Jan. 21, 2002

HEADLINE: Jitters in Japan for Savers and Banks 

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 22 

 BODY:
As Japan's debt-sodden banks stagger to the end of the fiscal year in March, the impending end of the government's blanket guarantee on bank deposits is causing skittish savers to pull their money out of the country's smallest lenders, sinking some and potentially generating a wider economic crisis, with larger banks also at risk.
 On Monday, Moody's Investors Service lowered the deposit ratings for five regional banks and downgraded the outlook for Japan's biggest banks to negative from stable. Moody's said it "considers the Japanese banking system to be in a grossly inadequate financial shape to meet the new challenges from a changing systemic support mechanism." 
 Paul H. O'Neill, the United States Treasury secretary, urged Finance Minister Masajuro Shiokawa today to press Japan's banks to write off their most troublesome loans. Mr. O'Neill was in Tokyo for the Afghan donors conference. 
Lawmakers from the ruling party have increasingly been calling for the government to keep the blanket guarantee for at least another year -- yet another test for Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi, who wants to clean up the ailing financial system with market-based solutions instead.
The plan to end the full guarantee on bank deposits, which Mr. Koizumi calls a subsidy for weak banks, was in the works under an earlier administration but was postponed as lawmakers decided that the financial system was too weak.
Despite the growing pressure, Mr. Koizumi seems determined to stand firm. He sees important long-term gains from doing so and fears a backlash from investors.
Starting in April, fixed-term deposits at any single bank will be insured only up to 10 million yen ($75,466) for each saver, a system similar to that of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation in the United States. Ordinary savings accounts will be treated the same way beginning in April 2003.
In normal times, the ending of the blanket guarantee would probably cause barely a ripple. After all, people who want all their savings guaranteed by the government need only open accounts in multiple banks and keep no more than 10 million yen in each.
But these are not normal times in Japan. Profits at most banks have been eroded by a recession, a weak stock market and growing competition, leaving many with mountains of bad loans and high expenses.
Even so, the Japanese remain prodigious savers, parking 55 percent of their money, or $7.7 trillion, in banks. Burned by years of falling stock prices, they have traded high returns for piece of mind.
Interest rates on ordinary accounts are only around 0.03 percent, and twice that for certificates of deposit, but all deposits have been fully guaranteed since 1996, when the system was put in place to bolster public confidence after seven housing loan corporations collapsed.
In anticipation of the limited guarantees, however, many savers have been taking their money out of institutions they view as weak -- most of them credit unions and cooperatives, the country's smallest lenders -- and shifting it up the food chain: from the tiny co-ops to the small regional banks, and from the small regional banks to the big city banks.
Money is also going into the post office savings system, gold, nonyen accounts and mattresses. According to Richard Jerram, an economist at ING Baring Securities in Tokyo, as much as 100 trillion yen ($755 billion) is being moved around because of the deposit-guarantee change.
At the smallest banks, deposits fell 1.5 percent in the last three months of 2001. And time deposits, which banks rely on to provide cash for predictable periods, fell more than 30 percent at the nation's credit cooperatives in the first nine months of last year.
The exodus of money out of smaller institutions proved to be the final blow for a record 46 credit unions and cooperatives that collapsed last year. Ishikawa Bank, a larger regional lender, folded in December, the first failure of a full-fledged bank in two years.
Though the more than 600 cooperatives hold just 10 percent of the nation's savings, they are the lender of last resort for the millions of small companies that employ about 90 percent of Japan's work force. The demise of the co-ops has stoked fears that corporate bankruptcies will skyrocket, leaving banks of all stripes with even larger losses.
"From now until the end of March, there will be a financial crisis," Yoichi Masuzoe, a member of Parliament, said earlier this month.
Another problem for Mr. Koizumi is that the co-ops are at the center of many rural districts, where few banking alternatives exist and his Liberal Democrats win most of their support.
Fearing a backlash from voters, powerful voices in the party have begun accusing the prime minister of recklessness in his insistence on capping the deposit guarantee.
The government is "cutting down the weak trees and leaving only the strong ones," said Shizuka Kamei, an influential party member, adding, "That's like chopping down weak trees with Agent Orange -- if you do that, you'll kill the entire forest." Like some of his colleagues, he wants the government to extend the guarantee until the economy recovers.
Mr. Koizumi has softened his stance in recent weeks, saying he will intercede if a wider crisis envelops the banking system. But having staked his reputation on adopting needed but painful reforms, he is walking a fine line. Reversing course and keeping the full deposit guarantee -- a step that Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi took two years ago -- or funneling public money to prop up lenders would erode investors' confidence not only in Mr. Koizumi but also in the banking system.
"Postponing the reform again would be a virtual admission that the financial system is severely distressed," said Mr. Jerram, of ING Baring Securities.
For now, Mr. Koizumi and his team are hoping that the April deadline will pass without the trickle of bank failures turning into a torrent.
"So far they've been successful by winnowing out the weakest players without triggering a crisis," said Brian Waterhouse, a banking analyst at HSBC Securities in Tokyo. "But it's an extremely dangerous game they are playing."

HEADLINE: Run, Osama, Run 

BYLINE:  By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
On the way back from Kabul, I passed through Pakistan, the Persian Gulf, London and Belgium, where I had a variety of talks with Arab and Muslim journalists and business people and Muslim community leaders in Europe. All of them were educated, intelligent and thoughtful -- and virtually none of them believed that Osama bin Laden was guilty.
 Let's see, there was the serious Arab journalist in Bahrain who said that Arabs could never have pulled off something as complex as Sept. 11; there was the Euro-Muslim woman in Brussels who looked at me as if I was a fool when I said that the bin Laden tape in which he boasted of the World Trade Center attack was surely authentic and had not been doctored by the Pentagon; there was the American-educated Arab student who insisted that somehow the C.I.A. or Mossad must have known about Sept. 11 in advance, so why didn't they stop it? There was the Saudi businessman who declared that there was a plot in the U.S. media to smear Saudi Arabia, for absolutely no reason. And there was the Pakistani who confided that his kids' entire elementary school class believed the canard that 4,000 Jews who worked in the World Trade Center were warned not to go to the office on Sept. 11. 
 Frankly, these views have been present across the Arab-Muslim world ever since Sept. 11, but I somehow hoped that after the fall of the Taliban, or bin Laden's confessional tapes, they would have melted away. But they have not. Indeed, they have congealed into an iron curtain of misunderstanding separating America and the Arab-Muslim world, and are now as deeply held as they were on Sept. 11 -- even if people are slightly more reticent about airing them. 
And they add up to a simple point: that while America has won the war in Afghanistan, it has not won the hearts and minds of the Arab-Muslim world. The cultural-political-psychological chasm between us is wider than ever. And if you don't believe that, ask any U.S. ambassador from Morocco to Islamabad -- any one of them. They will share with you cocktail party chatter about the "American conspiracy" against the Muslim world that will curl your ears.
Yes, there are exceptions in every country. When I sat with Bahraini friends in Manama last week, I found many of them deeply introspective and ready to look reality in the eye. But these are not the rule. Why? What produced this iron curtain of mistrust and misunderstanding?
There are many rivets in it. One is our own failure over the past two decades to really explain ourselves in Arabic and to puncture canards about U.S. policy with hard facts. The Bush team has yet to provide a dossier, in Arabic, detailing all the evidence against bin Laden. It is not too late for that, although facts alone will not be enough.
There is enormous cultural resistance to believing anything good about America. Some of this is deliberately fanned by the state-run press in certain Arab countries to deflect criticism from the regime. Some is revenge for America's support for Israel, particularly at this time when the Israeli-Palestinian conflict has turned into such a human meat grinder, aired every night on Arab TV. Not acknowledging America's version of reality, or undercutting its sense of victory in Afghanistan, is a way for Arabs and Muslims to get revenge for America's support for Israel, which they feel so powerless to affect.
At the same time, there does seem to be a certain strain of self-loathing at work in parts of the Arab-Muslim world today. What else can one think when someone tells you that Arabs or Muslims could never have been clever enough to pull off Sept. 11 -- only the Mossad or C.I.A.? It is a sad fact that Arab self-esteem is very low these days, because of the lagging state of Arab political systems and economies, and that feeds the free-floating anger that bin Laden has been surfing on.
Finally, we have to admit that bin Laden touches something deep in the Arab-Muslim soul, even among those who condemn his murders. They still root for him as the one man who was not intimidated by America's overweening power, as the one man who dared to tell certain Arab rulers that they had no clothes, and as the one man who did something about it. 
Quietly today, many in the Arab-Muslim world are rooting for bin Laden to get away. They are whispering in their hearts, "Run, Osama, run!" That's what's really going on out there. I just wish we knew how to change it.

HEADLINE: ENRON'S COLLAPSE: THE LAWYER; 
Seeking Top Berth In Pursuit Of Enron

BYLINE:  By LESLIE WAYNE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan 22 

 BODY:
The lawyer William Lerach was all over the television news today as he lugged a large carton of shredded Enron documents to the courthouse in Houston. Amid a sea of microphones, Mr. Lerach gave the impression he was leading the charge for angry shareholders in their legal battle against Enron.
 In reality, it is a job he wants but does not yet have. Instead, Mr. Lerach, perhaps the most famous and flamboyant lawyer for shareholders, is engaged in a pitched three-way battle to be named chief legal counsel for all Enron shareholders, a job that could end up netting legal fees in the hundreds of millions of dollars for the firm selected. 
 Just who will be named chief counsel for the class-action suit will be determined by a federal judge next month. 
In the meantime, Mr. Lerach is campaigning, appearing on morning talk shows and making dramatic statements to reporters on the courthouse steps as he filled the airwaves today.
He wants the job so badly that he has even jettisoned some clients, most famously, Amalgamated Bank of New York, in the hopes of staking his fortune with even bigger ones -- one of the criteria for deciding the lead counsel. 
"Bill Lerach puts himself in the forefront in terms of publicity and fees and everything else," said James M. Finberg, a lawyer with a San Francisco firm that is also vying to be named chief counsel. "But the decision of who becomes lead counsel will not be made by who has the most press attention, but will be made by a judge." His firm's clients include the City of New York pension fund and a State of Florida pension fund.
In the world of shareholder litigation, Mr. Lerach, who did not return calls for comment, is well known. He has won over a billion dollars for shareholders in two big financial scandals involving junk bonds and savings and loans, and brought frivolous cases like litigation over the lip-synching duo, Milli Vanilli.
Mr. Lerach has made a personal fortune and gained the lasting hatred of corporate America by bringing more than 600 suits against companies whose stock price has dropped. His firm, Milberg Weiss Bershad Hynes & Lerach, accounts for about half of all shareholder suits against corporations and has won $6 billion for its clients. 
For this Mr. Lerach earned the name the "king of strike suits," and corporations talk about having been "Lerached."
His firm once agreed to pay $50 million to settle a case in which someone he sued accused him of abusing the legal system and a federal jury agreed.
"He is a controversial figure of historic dimensions," said John Coffee, a securities law professor at Columbia University. "Those who do not like him say he behaves as an extortionist, is threatening and shakes people down. Others say he is more zealous than the lazier plaintiffs' attorneys. He is the most controversial figure in a field of litigation known for its egos and flamboyant types."
Some say Mr. Lerach's boldest move to date may be in giving the impression in the Enron case that he already has the job he wants: "Lerach is running around like it's his case," said one law school professor, who insisted on not being identified. "Why is this man smiling? He thinks he has the case, and it is not clear that he does."
In reality there are three legal teams vying to be selected as the lead counsel for the shareholders -- mainly large pension funds who bought Enron shares, but also individual investors. Mr. Lerach's big client is the University of California Regents, which has lost about $144 million. Another is Mr. Finberg's firm, Lieff Cabraser Heimann Bernstein, whose two clients, the New York and Florida pension funds, have a combined total of $440 million in losses and which feels it has something extra. "We have a very sympathetic group," Mr. Finberg said. "We represent a lot of the families of people who died in the World Trade Center."
A third group is composed of public pension funds from Georgia, Ohio, Washington and Alabama and is represented by a law firm in Delaware and one in Atlanta. This group is claiming losses of $330 million. Lawyers for the two firms, Grant & Eisenhofer and Chitwood & Harley, did not return calls. 
Under federal securities reform legislation enacted in 1995, the criterion for selecting a lead lawyer was changed. Rather than the firm that filed a class-action case first (one of Mr. Lerach's specialties), the lawyer who represents the plaintiffs with the greatest losses, among other factors, is now favored.
The lead lawyer's firm decides on the legal strategy, directs all other lawyers and gets the biggest slice of the fees, as well as determines how much lawyers for the other plaintiffs will be paid. These fees can run into the hundreds of millions -- the $3.2 billion class-action settlement against the Cendant Corporation is expected to net legal fees of over $270 million.
"The lead law firm does most of the work and gets most of the fees," said Brian Borders, a spokesman for the Association of Publicly Traded Companies, which represents small and midsize companies. "The fees in the Enron case could be in the hundreds of millions. It is going to be the grandaddy of all securities class-action cases and that will dictate the size of the fees."
At the moment, Mr. Lerach is doing some fancy footwork to get the lead position. In court today, he argued that the selection of the lead counsel should be changed from the law firm whose clients, as a group, suffered the biggest losses to the firm with the single client who has lost the most. By the first calculation, Mr. Lerach's firm would be in third place. 
By the second calculation, he contends, he would be in first place, as he says the California Regents' $144 million was the single largest loss. While the Florida pension fund lost more, $300 million, Mr. Lerach argued that Florida should be disqualified as a lead plaintiff because it brought more class-action lawsuits over the last three years than allowed by federal law. But lawyers for the State of Florida say this law does not apply to institutional investors.
To back up his legal theory that the lawyer for the single-biggest plaintiff should get the nod, he asked his other client, Amalgamated Bank, to step down, and the bank, with only $10 million in losses, agreed.
"This is something that we agreed to do so that Bill Lerach could become the lead attorney on the case," said Melissa Moye, chief economist for Amalgamated Bank, who reasoned that if stepping back was the only way to get Mr. Lerach selected to represent the whole class of shareholders, it would.
"We did this by mutual consent. We want the California Regents to be named as the lead plaintiff," Ms. Moye said.
In fact, some see Mr. Lerach's action's today, especially his courting of the press, as a smart marketing move intended to draw even bigger clients to him.
"He's been courting the pension funds by saying, you ought to pick Milberg Weiss as the lead counsel," said Mr. Borders of the publicly traded companies group. "It's all about marketing."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Off on Warning About Technology

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks fell yesterday, sending the Nasdaq composite index to its lowest level in two months, after a Merrill Lynch analyst said that computer-related shares were more expensive then they had been in almost 20 years.
 Microsoft and Intel led the decline. Kmart plunged after filing for protection from creditors. 
 Shares of Microsoft fell $1.64, to $64.46, and Intel dropped $1.78, to $31.70. 
Kmart plunged $1.04, or 60 percent, to 70 cents.
The Nasdaq composite index dropped 47.81 points, or 2.5 percent, to close at 1,882.53. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 8.27 points, or 0.7 percent, to 1,119.31. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 58.05 points, or 0.6 percent, to close at 9,713.80. 
Richard Bernstein, chief United States strategist at Merrill Lynch, wrote in a note to clients yesterday that technology shares were overvalued. He advised them to book gains they might have had in technology stocks from the rally, which began late last year, that has lifted the Nasdaq as much as 45 percent from its September lows.
Valuations in these stocks "are now clearly stretched to bubble-like levels," he said. Investors should favor drug stocks, he said.
His research found that technology shares were the most expensive in the last 18 years, compared with the S.& P. 500. On the same basis, using projected earnings, drug stocks have only been cheaper on two other occasions over the period.
Investors mostly ignored a report yesterday from the Conference Board that showed its index of leading economic indicators rose 1.2 percent in December, the third consecutive monthly rise. The increase, a sign the recession may end by the middle of this year, was the largest since February 1996. --------------------

Treasury Prices Fall
(By Reuters)
Treasury bond prices slipped yesterday. Remarks by a Federal Reserve official and a big jump in the index of leading indicators threw cold water on prospects for another Fed rate reduction next week after 11 cuts since the start of last year.
Prospective supply from a coming two-year note auction also weighed on that sector, analysts said. The Treasury will auction a record $25 billion in two-year notes today.
Treasuries sank after Robert McTeer, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, said the economy had improved from where it was two months ago. A Conference Board report that the index of leading economic indicators jumped 1.2 percent in December also contributed to the decline. 
The benchmark 10-year note fell 5/32, to a price of 100 23/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 4.90 percent from 4.88 percent on Friday. Markets were closed Monday.
The 30-year bond, sensitive to worries about the long-term inflation outlook, returned to its lowest levels of the day when the government reported a smaller surplus for December than in the month a year ago -- $26.57 billion, down from $32.67 billion in December 2000. 
The 30-year bond fell 12/32, to a price of 99 29/32. Its yield rose to 5.38 percent from 5.36 percent on Friday.

HEADLINE: GROUND ZERO: CITY GOVERNMENT; 
Mayor Tells New Firefighters He Won't Skimp on Training

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that although the city's budget would not be able to cover all the needs of the Fire Department, New York would still go ahead with plans for a new $50 million training center for probationary firefighters, as well as a new command center for the city's Office of Emergency Management. The old command center, known informally as the bunker, was destroyed in the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center. 
 Mr. Bloomberg mentioned both plans yesterday when he swore in the latest group of firefighters beginning training, the second such class to emerge since Sept. 11, when the department lost 343 members. 
 "You have accepted a fundamentally dangerous job," he told the incoming firefighters. "But that does not mean we can't do an awful lot to ensure that you get home every night to your families." 
"My commitment to you," he continued, "is that we will provide the resources, even in tough economic times, to make sure that that tradition of the bravest continues. That doesn't mean we're going to be able to do everything we'd like to do. That doesn't mean we're going to have as many firefighters as we'd like to have. But we'd like to make sure that we give you the tools to do your job."
Construction has already begun on three buildings, and on the renovation of a building on Randalls Island, home to the 27-acre Fire Department training academy known by department members as the Rock. The first building is expected to be completed in March. 
The new additions will include a "burn building" in which firefighter trainees will get used to high temperatures, and an area where they will acclimate to fire and smoke. Two days of antiterrorism training will be added to their curriculum, said the new fire commissioner, Nicholas Scoppetta. The project is expected to be completed by the end of next year. Mr. Scoppetta, addressing his first class of recruits, said: "You are sworn in today in the shadow of giants. We can never really replace that experience, but we can substitute the kind of training you will get here that will prepare you for the very, very difficult job that you will have ahead of you." 
Four of the 307-member class, who go through about three months of training, lost a brother or father in the World Trade Center attack. And department officials said yesterday that 15 percent of the class were minority recruits, the highest percentage in 10 years.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's $13 million command bunker in 7 World Trade Center collapsed seven hours after being set on fire by falling debris. Since Sept. 11, a temporary command center has been run from Pier 92, and a backup site was also set up at a location that city officials have never revealed. Now the plan is for a new, permanent command center, probably in a borough other than Manhattan, officials say, and another backup center. Several sites are being evaluated. 
Yesterday, a spokesman for the Office of Emergency Management, the agency that would be housed in the bunker, declined to provide even hints about the new site, whose whereabouts Mr. Bloomberg said would be announced soon. 
Under the Giuliani administration, however, officials came up with certain criteria for a site: it must be far from water, so it does not flood and cannot be attacked from a boat. It must be easy to get to by several forms of transportation, and it would be a plus if the site had a spot to land a helicopter. Giuliani officials did extensive searching in Brooklyn. 
"We are looking for a new site," Mr. Bloomberg said yesterday. "That is one of the high-priority items in this administration. Rest assured that it will be not in a high-rise building," or, he added, in an area where there are many other buildings nearby. 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg swore in the second class of probationary firefighters since Sept. 11 and assured them of the city's support. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Satellite Start-Up forApple Co-Founder

BYLINE:  By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: LOS GATOS, Calif. Jan. 22 

 BODY:
Emerging from an early retirement he began more than a decade ago, Stephen Wozniak, one of Silicon Valley's legendary computer designers, has caught start-up fever and is forming a company to develop consumer products based on wireless and global positioning satellite technologies.
 The company, which is being backed by Mobius Venture Capital and Draper Fisher Jurvetson, two of the Valley's largest venture capital firms, and Palo Alto Investors, was financed in December with a $6 million initial investment. It plans to have its first products finished sometime next year. 
 G.P.S. receivers have until now been relatively costly devices used by sportsmen and in car navigation systems. But the falling cost has made it possible to think about integrating location data with almost anything wireless and connected to the Internet. By driving down the cost of G.P.S. technology, the company says, it expects to help "everyday people track everyday things."
The new company has been named Wheels of Zeus, a takeoff on Woz, the nickname of its founder, who in 1976 left his job as a Hewlett-Packard technician to found Apple Computer with his high school friend, Steven P. Jobs. It is the first start-up venture for Mr. Wozniak since he closed his previous company, Cloud 9, a maker of high-end consumer remote control devices, in 1988.
While Mr. Jobs went on to found Next Inc., bought Pixar, and then returned to Apple as its chief executive in 1997, Mr. Wozniak, now 51, has largely remained on the sidelines. That has made him unusual in a hothouse business and technology culture that is characterized by serial entrepreneurs, few of them walking away after either success or failure. Instead, he has occupied himself with private investments and has taught computer education for elementary through high school students in the Los Gatos, Calif., school district, where he lives.
The new company will not initially announce what products it is planning and Mr. Wozniak said this week it was likely that it would not at first market its own products. It will instead seek licensing and marketing arrangements with other consumer electronics and related companies.
He said one goal was to take technologies that are now costly and reduce them in price so they could be sold in consumer markets. He said he was not concerned that Silicon Valley was in one of its steepest declines in a decade. Wheels of Zeus has based itself in a small office building here, and Mr. Wozniak said the rent was less than half of what it would have been at the peak of the Internet bubble that ended about a year ago.
"I'm trying to conserve money," he said.
Mr. Wozniak said he had enjoyed simply being a consumer of new technologies for more than a decade. But last year, a friend visited and began talking about an idea that used G.P.S. in a strange way and he found himself excited by the prospects of doing something with this.
"Sometimes I say that and I'm not really serious," he remarked, "but this time I was really serious."
Mr. Wozniak said he had considered financing the new venture privately and with the support of individual investors. But late last year, he bumped into Greg Galanos, a partner at Mobius, the investment firm based in Mountain View, Calif., formerly named Softbank Venture Capital.
Mr. Galanos said his firm had been excited about both the company's technology idea and the possibility of backing Mr. Wozniak.
"After all how many times will Steve jump on something new again?" he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Stephen Wozniak, Apple's co-founder, at his start-up company, Wheels of Zeus, in Los Gatos, Calif., yesterday. G.P.S. technology lured him back. (Peter DaSilva for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Daschle Hopes to Lead Senate Toward an Economic Recovery Package 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 

 BODY:
Senator Tom Daschle, the Democratic majority leader, said today that he intended to begin the new legislative year with an effort to pass the elements of an economic recovery package that both parties support.
 Having been criticized by Republicans as obstructionist since a recession-fighting package died in the Senate last month, Mr. Daschle sought to recast the partisan debate over how to help the economy in terms favorable to his party. 
 With Congress scheduled to reconvene on Wednesday, Mr. Daschle said the Senate should move quickly to adopt an extension of unemployment benefits, a one-time payment of $300 to low-income workers, a temporary tax credit for businesses that invest in new equipment and money to help the states cope with rising costs in Medicaid. 
Republicans all but rejected his offer, saying they would continue to push for a broader package that includes permanent tax cuts for individuals and businesses. But they left open the possibility that they could support a narrower package if their bill failed to pass. 
It is not clear that either party's approach can deliver the 60 votes needed to pass the legislation in the Senate.
The skirmish came as the two parties prepared to begin work on a new budget, an annual battle that promises to be even more contentious than usual. The administration and the two parties in Congress are confronting not only a return to budget deficits but the needs created by the war on terrorism and the recession, as well as the normal election-year pressures for more spending.
In a sign of the political cross-currents, administration officials said the budget proposal that President Bush was preparing to send to Capitol Hill would call for a spending increase of as much as 9 percent next year, much larger than many conservatives are comfortable with. 
It will also forecast a deficit that could approach $100 billion, a level that Democrats said they would use to level charges of fiscal mismanagement at the administration.
People familiar with Mr. Bush's plan said it would propose an increase in military spending of around $35 billion, on top of the current level of $329 billion, and a doubling of the budget for domestic security programs, to $30 billion.
Some other domestic and social programs unrelated to the war would also get spending increases under Mr. Bush's plan, but others would be frozen or cut. 
Over all, programs not related to national security would grow at a rate in the low single digits, probably around 3 percent, meaning that many of them would not keep up with inflation, budget analysts said.
The Congressional Budget Office will provide the House and Senate budget committees with its fiscal outlook as lawmakers return to work on Wednesday, defining the field on which the budget battle will take place. The figures are expected to show the government in a deficit for the next few years even before any new spending or tax cuts.
In seeking to start the year with a focus on the economy, Mr. Daschle was following his party's strategy of emphasizing its differences with Mr. Bush on issues other than the campaign against terrorism.
His office said Mr. Daschle's slimmed-down economic plan would cost $69 billion in the current fiscal year, then drop off sharply to $7 billion next year, reflecting its goal of giving a sharp but temporary lift to the economy.
Mr. Daschle's plan would leave for later the question of whether the recovery plan should include what Republicans consider the most effective tonic for the economy, a permanent round of new or accelerated tax cuts for individuals and businesses. 
It would also put aside the divisive question of how to provide better access to health insurance for the unemployed, which more than any other issue led to a stalemate on economic legislation before Congress recessed for the holidays last month.
In a letter sent today to Mr. Bush, Mr. Daschle said he was proposing "that we break the impasse on economic recovery legislation by adopting a nonpartisan, common-sense approach." 
"Let's immediately pass what we agree on," Mr. Daschle wrote, "and keep working to find common ground in the areas where we disagree."
The House twice passed packages of tax cuts and help for the unemployed last fall, but efforts to forge a compromise broke down in the closely divided Senate. 
Although economists say the recession appears to be drawing to a close, and may even be over, both parties are pressing ahead with their plans, sensitive to the likelihood that the recovery could be weak and that unemployment typically continues to rise for months even after a downturn ends.
In a letter to Mr. Bush tonight, Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican minority leader, said Mr. Daschle's offer could break the logjam. But in a clear sign of how far apart the two parties remain, Mr. Lott went on to say that he would immediately seek a vote on the bill passed last month by Republicans in the House, a measure that Mr. Daschle has said is unacceptable.
Administration officials said Mr. Bush's budget proposal would set aside about $75 billion next year and $50 billion the year after to pay for an economic recovery plan along the lines of the bill that passed in the House. That bill includes an acceleration of the income tax rate reductions included in last year's tax bill and a variety of permanent corporate tax cuts.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Tom Daschle will put the economy back on the table today. (Carol T. Powers for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A BUDGET FOR NEW YORK: CITY REACTION; 
The Promise of State Aid Inspires Both Relief and Uncertainty

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 22 

 BODY:
If New York City officials were looking to the state for significant aid to help them close a multibillion-dollar shortfall in the city budget in the coming year, the budget that Gov. George E. Pataki proposed here today makes it clear that they will have to keep looking to the federal government.
 But if the state budget proposal was not all that some city officials had hoped, it was certainly not all that others had feared. Despite the $5.7 billion deficit that the state faces in the coming year, Mr. Pataki said that his budget would not only "hold the line" and avoid cutbacks in most programs, but would also actually increase aid to the city. 
 The way the governor explains it, his budget plan will raise state aid to the city by $509 million next year. Some city officials and budget monitors expressed doubts about that figure, which is based on a number of assumptions that may not come to pass, but they expressed relief nonetheless that the state budget would not seriously cut their aid.
Mr. Pataki, a Republican, said that the city would be receiving not only the state aid, but also more than $10 billion in federal money to help it rebuild from the attack on the World Trade Center. "We're going to make sure that New York City not just is rebuilt, but that New York City comes back economically and from a civic standpoint, stronger than ever," he said.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said he would travel to Albany on Monday to testify about the city's needs before State Senate and Assembly committees. "We understand that the state has limited resources," he said, but he added that the city's needs are great and expressed hope that a way can be found "to get our fair share of the monies that the state distributes."
Some Democrats and city officials questioned whether the state was doing enough to help the city -- whose budget deficit for the coming year has been estimated at $2.9 billion to $4.7 billion -- recover from the attack and set its books in order.
And they criticized Mr. Pataki for announcing an economic development program, called the Economic Opportunity Fund, that would eventually provide more than $2 billion to pay for infrastructure improvements to create jobs in upstate New York and the Hudson Valley and on Long Island -- but not in New York City.
The City Council speaker, Gifford Miller, criticized the plan. State Senator Eric T. Schneiderman, a Manhattan Democrat, said, "For the governor to send up an economic development program after New York City has suffered its most devastating blow, and to explicitly exclude New York City, is unbelievable."
Mr. Pataki said the program was intended to address the economic needs of the three regions that it would help, and he noted that the city would be getting significant federal aid that he hoped could be used for economic development. He said that "we will be getting federal funds to be able to rebuild not just Lower Manhattan, but a significant percentage of those funds we hope, at the end of the day, we'll be able to use to help those other areas in the city that have been impacted by the economic crisis."
The governor said that the budget included enough aid to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to avoid fare increases.
The state plan gives the city the authority to impose a 30-cent tax on cellphones, which would net about $12 million a year. The city could also bring in $4.5 million in new revenues from a cigarette-tax increase, while a change in how the state collects sales taxes electronically from merchants is expected to bring the city another $13.8 million in the coming year.
But some officials and budget monitors warned that some of the promises might not come to fruition. The governor's $509 million figure includes $110 million that will be realized only if the federal government increases the amount of Medicaid money that it pays to the states -- something that officials in Washington have said is highly unlikely.
The largest portion of the $509 million that Mr. Pataki says the city would get under his plan is not exactly new money. For years the city has complained that it has not been reimbursed fully by the state for the money it has spent on education. Mr. Pataki said that he would authorize a bond sale to pay the city $204 million in reimbursements for some of those past claims.
The schools chancellor, Harold O. Levy, praised what he described as a "creative initiative to pay longstanding prior-year school aid claims," and said the money "should accelerate an infusion of state aid payments to meet critical local needs."
Some education officials, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said they expected that the money would be set aside to help pay for teacher raises. That could raise eyebrows among some budget watchdogs, who oppose the government issuing debt to pay salaries.
But while the infusion of money will be welcome, it is really in effect giving the city money that it has already spent. The budget would reduce other forms of school aid to the city by $11 million.
The budget would also increase state aid to the city for welfare programs by $132 million, state officials said. That includes more aid for child welfare programs, and money to double the subsidy for homeless families that have spent nine months in shelters to help them move to permanent housing.
"We were pleasantly surprised," said Gail B. Nayowith, executive director of the Citizens' Committee for Children of New York City. "We were warned the budget would be dire with a capital D."
