HEADLINE: Espionage? By the U.S.? China Prefers To Stay Quiet 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Jan. 22 

 BODY:
A Chinese government spokesman offered a muted reaction today to disclosures that a presidential jet outfitted in the United States had been crammed with listening devices, and his comments suggest that China would not let the incident upset plans for the first state visit by President Bush next month. 
 The plane was delivered to China in September but has not been used because the Chinese military discovered that its interior was laced with sophisticated satellite-operated bugs, an airline official and a Western diplomat here said today. 
 "I don't think this case will have any impact on other issues," Sun Yuxi, a Foreign Ministry spokesman, said at a regularly scheduled news conference this afternoon. 
It was the first time the government had directly addressed the allegations, which emerged in the Western press over the weekend. The effort to play down an episode that many had predicted would lead to a diplomatic crisis illustrates the depth of China's current commitment to cultivating better relations with the United States. 
The officials who confirmed the reports said there had apparently already been dismissals in China's civil aviation office, which arranged to buy the Boeing 767, and in the Air Force, which was assigned to guard the jet while it was being refurbished last year in San Antonio by two American companies. 
Two senior Chinese civil aviation officials of the civil aviation office have disappeared, a Western diplomat said, and a senior Air Force officer who was supervising security has been detained. 
But there has not been a single word of public outrage. Indeed, experts note that the government has seemingly gone out of its way to suppress information about a case that threatens to embarrass both Chinese and American leaders. 
Cultivating good relations with the United States has become a paramount goal for China's leadership since Sept. 11. To a large extent, Washington has reciprocated. 
"The two countries will insure that this incident has no big effect, because they understand the importance of preserving their relationship," said Wang Yong, a foreign-policy expert at Beijing University. "It would have had a bigger impact before Sept. 11, but I think even then it would not have been huge. China is now concentrating on stability and developing its economy, and for that it needs good relations with the U.S."
China's leaders have little to gain and much to lose right now by publicly protesting -- or even publicly acknowledging -- any tampering with the plane. 
Last year, when an American EP-3 spy plane collided with a Chinese Air Force jet that was tailing it over international waters off the coast of southern China, the government loudly condemned American espionage. That set off a tense period marked by strong anti-American public sentiment here. 
With Mr. Bush due here in less than a month, the government has little interest in poisoning the atmosphere for dialogue. 
Mr. Bush started his term loudly proclaiming his strong distrust of China. Since Sept. 11, though, he has softened that position considerably, in part because of China's strong support for the United States' action in Afghanistan. He has been urged in that direction by pro-engagement advisers like Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and by Mr. Bush's ambassador to China, and old friend, Clark T. Randt.
It is no secret that other administration officials, particularly in the Defense Department, continue to see China as inherently an enemy. 
The Chinese government is acutely aware that a successful summit meeting next month could help bring President Bush firmly into the pro-engagement camp.
"They know that 9/11 has changed the environment and they can use that to change the substance of their relationship with the U.S.," said a Western academic who has recently discussed the issue in China. "They know that the only way to move the administration to the center is through a full-court press to prove and impress the Bush administration that it can cooperate with China."
Domestic political considerations also help explain why the bugging scandal might be kept under wraps. For China's military officers, the allegations involve dereliction of duty or (according to some versions of the story) a willingness to take bribes. 
For President Jiang Zemin, the placement of listening devices would mean betrayal by a country he has sought to portray as friend. The fuss also draws attention to the lavish plane he had ordered, already a source of grumbling among some people.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 25, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article on Wednesday about reports of listening devices in an aircraft outfitted in the United States for China's used an erroneous given name in some editions for the United States ambassador, who was cited as an advocate of improving relations. He is Clark T. Randt, not Alexander.

HEADLINE: Steel Users Campaigning Against Curbs on Imports 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 

 BODY:
A coalition of manufacturing companies that rely on steel imports has begun lobbying the White House and Congress to reject proposed restrictions on foreign-made steel, arguing that protecting ailing steel makers will cost consumers far more than it helps producers.
 The group, which includes the heavy equipment maker Caterpillar and the lobbyist for the leading makers of home appliances, has stepped up its campaign ahead of a pending administration decision on whether to enact what could be the most sweeping controls on steel imports since the 1980's. 
 Under a trade action he started last year, President Bush must decide by March 6 whether to impose tariffs and quotas on a wide range of steel products. Last month, a government trade panel recommended tariffs as high as 40 percent on some steel imports. Mr. Bush can accept, amend or reject those recommendations. 
As part of an effort to counter the Washington influence of major steel companies and their unions, corporate members of the Emergency Committee for American Trade, an umbrella group that works to dismantle barriers to open trade in steel and other goods, have met with administration officials in recent days to fight the industry's push for high tariffs.
"Steel tariffs would be an abrogation of President Bush's 'not over my dead body' promise not to raise taxes," said William C. Lane, Washington director for Caterpillar. "They are really a tax on all steel users."
The antitariff lobbyists released a study today from two economists at the Institute for International Economics that said the highest tariffs and tightest quotas under consideration would cost domestic steel users and foreign steel companies $34 billion over four years. American companies that buy steel would end up paying about $500,000 for every job saved by shielding steel companies from foreign competition, according to the study.
Steel makers and unions have asserted that the trade protections are vital to protect the industry against a flood of cheap imports, which they say are made possible because foreign governments subsidize steel companies. Most of the major integrated American steel companies are in serious financial trouble and need government help to stay in business, the companies have said.
Steel users agree that producers need help. They say they support the steel industry's request for government aid to help them pay pension and health benefits for retired steel workers. Steel companies say such so-called legacy costs have eroded their profitability. They have asked the Bush administration and Congress for as much as $13 billion in aid.
But unlike the steel companies, the user group says steel companies should receive aid instead of -- not in addition to -- limits on imports.
Trade experts who oppose restricting imports also say that the Bush administration may not have much room under international trade rules to protect steel companies.
The World Trade Organization permits member nations to impose temporary restrictions on imports in some circumstances, like sudden surges of foreign-made goods that cripple domestic manufacturers.
But trade experts say that the latest statistics show that imports of leading steel products, including hot- and cold-rolled flat steel, have declined over the last three years, while some other steel imports have increased only modestly over the period.
That could give Britain, Germany, Russia, Brazil, Mexico, South Korea, China and other steel exporters the right to retaliate immediately against United States steel tariffs or quotas unless the Bush administration negotiates corresponding reductions in tariffs on other goods, like textiles and sugar.
Even if new tariffs were upheld by the World Trade Organization, they have repeatedly proved to be ineffective in helping steel producers in this country, trade experts said.
Ben Goodrich, a co-author of the study of steel tariffs, said various forms of trade protections enacted since 1968 had done little to put the steel industry on a firm footing but had cost steel users $120 billion.
"If trade protection could foster industrial prosperity, the U.S. steel industry would be doing very well," he said.

HEADLINE: Congressional Memo; 
Senator Attacks Oil Policy As Top Democrats Jockey

BYLINE:  By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 

 BODY:
Senator John F. Kerry of Massachusetts criticized President Bush's energy plan today as "old thinking" that would not end the nation's dependence on foreign oil, becoming the latest prominent Democrat to stake out his differences with the president.
 Mr. Kerry's nearly hourlong speech, endorsing tougher fuel efficiency standards and tax credits to promote reliance on alternative and renewable fuels, was the newest sign that the race for the Democratic presidential nomination is well under way two years before the first primaries. 
 Although presidential hopefuls often like to try out their voices far from Washington at small fund-raising dinners and gatherings with the party faithful, an unusual number of aspiring Democrats are seeking a national platform here in the capital. 
First was Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, in a major speech this month that accused Republicans of pushing through a tax cut that worsened the recession. Last week, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut sought to make his mark with a speech at Georgetown University on foreign policy that included a call for the overthrow of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader, plans to enter the fray on Thursday by setting out a long-term economic plan for his party. Interestingly, Mr. Gephardt, widely seen as particularly close to organized labor, has chosen to give his speech at the centrist Democratic Leadership Council, which he helped found but has not always agreed with.
Today, Mr. Kerry, another likely 2004 aspirant, staked out environmental territory, saying Mr. Bush's energy policies were beholden to the status quo and arguing that it was "false advertising" to say those policies would lead to energy independence.
"Old thinking passed through the doors of 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue far more easily and often than new thinking," Mr. Kerry said. "Exxon Mobil, Enron or Chevron enjoyed an access bonanza at the expense of consumers and state-of-the-art environmental-technology manufacturers. As a result, those most heavily invested in the current energy system have set a course for the future which, not surprisingly, champions the status quo at the expense of new ideas and innovation."
It might seem early for such fierce competition in the war of ideas and, perhaps, even futile at a time Mr. Bush's approval ratings are extraordinarily high. But party strategists say Democrats remember how Bill Clinton jumped into the race early in 1991, when many more prominent Democrats hesitated to take on President George Bush.
Mr. Clinton's former strategist, James Carville, predicted that Mr. Bush "will become vulnerable, and no one wants someone to run around saying in 2004 that I was the first one to warn America about pollution, Enron, the deficit -- pick a subject."
"The futures market is at work here," Mr. Carville said, "and no one wants to be the guy who laid back too long."
In addition, with the primary season most likely to be accelerated, it is already time to be prospecting for staff members and money and seeking the serious scrutiny of pundits. 
"These candidates understand that the first primary is the idea primary, and they want to engage it," said Al From, head of the Democratic Leadership Council.
Different aspirants face different challenges, Democrats say. As Senate majority leader, Mr. Daschle does not want for exposure. He drew plenty of attention for his speech that said Mr. Bush and Republicans caused "the most dramatic fiscal deterioration in our nation's history" when they pushed through a 10-year $1.35 trillion tax cut.
But as Senate leader with a one-vote majority, Mr. Daschle cannot go beyond his ability to bring consensus. Some Democrats protested that he did not go far enough when he failed to propose rolling back part of the tax cut. More conservative Democrats complained that his criticism of Mr. Bush left them open to attack because they had voted for the cut.
Although he began his career as a new style high-tech Democrat, Mr. Gephardt is now more often perceived as an old-line labor liberal. So on Thursday he will try a balancing act. His aides say he will be trying to unite the wings of his party, taking the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., John J. Sweeney, to the speech at the leadership conference, a group that has had serious differences with labor on issues like trade policy.
Mr. Lieberman, who had to submerge some of his individuality as Al Gore's running mate in 2000, has been reclaiming his credentials as a moderate. When he spoke on foreign policy last week, he not only called for an initiative to "combat the despotism, poverty and isolation in the Muslim world that terrorists exploit," but he also showed himself to be a hawk in his party with his call to remove Mr. Hussein from power.
Mr. Kerry, with his promises to filibuster against drilling for oil in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, has been building a niche as an environmentalist, a less crowded arena if Mr. Gore chooses not to run again.
Today, Mr. Kerry cast the quest for renewable and alternate energy sources as a post-Sept. 11 necessity. "Domestic, renewable sources are urgently needed now, because they are entirely under our control," he said. "No foreign government can embargo them. No terrorist can seize control of them. No cartel can play games with them. No American soldier will have to risk his or her life to protect them."
Or course not every Democratic aspirant is speech making here. Senator John Edwards of North Carolina has no such address planned. But he will be on a foray to New Hampshire early next month.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator John F. Kerry, who spoke yesterday on the environment. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Kennedy and Bush Negotiate on Patients' Rights, Alarming Their Allies 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 

 BODY:
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, and the White House are engaged in intensive discussions seeking a deal on patients' rights legislation, and their usual allies are expressing alarm at the terms of a possible compromise.
 The talks focus on the ability of patients to enforce their rights by suing health plans, insurance companies and employers who have promised various health benefits. 
 The Senate passed its version of the legislation, the patients' bill of rights, last June by a vote of 59 to 36, with 9 Republicans supporting the legislation. The House passed its version, 226 to 203, in August. Both measures would allow patients to sue health maintenance organizations and insurers for injuries caused by the denial of care, but the House bill provides a more limited right to sue. 
Consumer advocates strongly prefer the Senate bill. President Bush favors the House bill and threatened to veto the Senate measure last year.
Mr. Kennedy and White House officials said they hoped to reach an agreement on patients' rights, just as they forged a bipartisan agreement on education legislation through weeks of quiet negotiations last year. The friendship between Mr. Bush and Mr. Kennedy, scions of two of America's best known political families, could yield political dividends for both men.
The chief sponsors of the Senate bill are Mr. Kennedy and Senators John Edwards, Democrat of North Carolina, and John McCain, Republican of Arizona.
In an interview, Mr. Edwards, a plaintiffs' lawyer intimately familiar with the issue of insurer liability, said: "I'm pretty optimistic that we may be able to reach some agreement. There is still a lot of work to be done."
Representative Charlie Norwood, Republican of Georgia, wrote the liability provisions of the House bill in negotiations with the White House last year. Mr. Norwood, a longtime advocate of patients' rights, stunned Democrats when he agreed to restrictions on the right to sue demanded by Mr. Bush.
James P. Manley, a spokesman for Senator Kennedy, characterized the talks as conversations and added, "The conversations with the White House are designed to see if there is any common ground."
But the talks have progressed to the point that aides to Mr. Kennedy and White House officials are discussing legislative language to define the standard of care to which H.M.O.'s would be held in making medical decisions.
People involved in the discussions said they were using the House bill as their point of reference. In addition, they said, aides to Senator Kennedy have indicated that they could accept an arrangement under which the right to sue would be governed mainly by federal law, not by state laws regulating insurance or the quality of medical care. This would apparently give insurers the uniformity they seek.
In return for that concession, Senate aides said, lawsuits involving questions of medical judgment and medical necessity could be filed and tried in state court with juries determining the amount of damages in some cases. The H.M.O.'s performance would be measured against standards set forth in federal law.
Consumer advocates and plaintiffs' lawyers generally prefer state courts to federal courts because the state courts are more convenient and their rules of evidence and procedure are often more favorable to plaintiffs.
Groups that have supported Mr. Kennedy in the past expressed concern about the direction of his talks with the White House. They said they worried that in the guise of a patients' rights bill, the insurance industry would secure more protections for itself to stave off the impact of recent developments in courts and state legislatures that are trying to regulate managed health care.
In recent years, many federal and state judges have made it easier for injured patients to sue insurers for damages. But the law is continually in flux, and patients can never be sure whether they will prevail.
President Bush's usual allies, including business groups and insurers, are even more alarmed than the consumer groups.
Suzanne DeFrancis, a spokeswoman for the Health Benefits Coalition, which represents employers and insurers, said: "We are incredulous that talks on this bill are still going on. How in the world can Washington pass a bill that raises health costs at a time when costs are already going through the roof? We're in a recession. More and more people are losing insurance. Why are Congress and the White House discussing legislation that would make things worse?"
Members of the Health Benefits Coalition include the National Federation of Independent Business, the United States Chamber of Commerce, the Business Roundtable, the National Association of Manufacturers, the Health Insurance Association of America and the American Association of Health Plans.
Supporters of patients' rights say that federal legislation is needed even more now as health costs rise rapidly because, they contend, insurers will be more tempted to save money by denying people treatment.
The House and Senate bills would both establish federal rights for tens of millions of people with insurance, guaranteeing access to emergency care, medical specialists and medically necessary prescription drugs.
Federal and state officials have had difficulty figuring out how to regulate H.M.O.'s because they make both administrative decisions, as insurers, and medical decisions, like doctors and hospitals.
Under the compromise now being discussed, H.M.O.'s could be sued like doctors and hospitals if, in making medical decisions, they failed to exercise "ordinary care" -- the degree of care, skill and diligence that would be exercised by a reasonable and prudent health care professional.
The White House wants to limit the damages that patients could recover in lawsuits against H.M.O.'s. But administration officials and Senate aides have apparently not discussed the precise level of such caps.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Edward M. Kennedy is seeking a deal on patients' rights. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: ENRON'S COLLAPSE: THE OVERVIEW; 
InShift, Bush Assails Enron Over Handling of Collapse

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER with DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: BELLE, W.Va., Jan. 22 

 BODY:
Abruptly changing his tone about a company that contributed heavily to his political campaigns, President Bush said today that he was "outraged" that the Enron Corporation misled its employees and investors, including his mother-in-law, who he said lost more than $8,000 when its stock collapsed. 
 For the first time, Mr. Bush called for government action to force greater corporate disclosure of financial information. 
 In comments to reporters here before he toured a machinery shop, Mr. Bush also strongly defended how members of his cabinet handled calls for aid from Enron's top executives, summarizing those members' message to the company's leaders as "no help here." 
Mr. Bush's new tone came as the scope of the Enron investigation widened. The company told a federal court in Houston today that on Monday night it had discovered more shredded documents on the 19th floor of its headquarters in Houston, suggesting that employees were destroying potential evidence despite what the company's leaders say were orders to the contrary. 
The shredded remains were turned over to the Justice Department today, and the Federal Bureau of Investigation sealed off part of the headquarters building.
Meanwhile, the House Energy and Commerce committee said it would issue subpoenas to a recently dismissed partner of Arthur Andersen, the main accounting firm for Enron and the auditor of its questionable financial arrangements. The fired Andersen partner, David B. Duncan, may cite his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination before the committee on Thursday, investigators said. Three others at Andersen, including the firm's chief executive, were also summoned.
In his comments today, the president never mentioned Enron's chief executive, Kenneth L. Lay, a once-close friend whom he had nicknamed Kenny Boy and who was the largest single contributor to Mr. Bush's campaigns since Mr. Bush entered politics. Nonetheless, by implication the president cut the cord with Mr. Lay today, saying, "What I'm outraged about is that shareholders and employees didn't know all the facts about Enron."
"My own mother-in-law bought stock last summer, and it's not worth anything now," he said of Jenna Welch, Laura Bush's mother.
Mr. Bush added later: "She didn't know all the facts. And a lot of shareholders didn't know all the facts. And that's wrong."
Republican strategists said Mr. Bush's changed tone reflected a political calculation by the White House as Congressional hearings on the company's collapse begin this week. They said the administration was determined not to allow Democrats to portray Enron as a problem only for Republicans. 
"The dynamic over Enron cannot be that Democrats are against Enron and for reform, and we're defending Enron and against reform," said one strategist who is close to the White House but who would not allow his name to be used. "What Enron did is outrageous, and if you don't move to correct it, it becomes an indictment of the free market. The Republican Party is the free market party. And we have to demonstrate our desire to make the market fair and to crack down on abuse."
Bill Dal Col, a Republican strategist, said Mr. Bush's comments were an appropriate response to the widening disclosures about Enron.
"When you've got a crisis that's growing like this -- every time you turn the page there's a new chapter of hocus-pocus accounting -- the stronger the outrage has to be," Mr. Dal Col said.
After Mr. Bush spoke, the White House corrected the president on the timing of his mother-in-law's investment. Mrs. Welch bought 200 shares of Enron on Sept. 21, 1999, for $40.90 a share, the White House said, for a total investment of $8,180. She sold her holdings on Dec. 4, two days after the company declared bankruptcy, for 42 cents a share, meaning her investment had plummeted to $84.
The White House did not say if any other members of Mr. Bush's family had held Enron stock. Some of his close aides did, but they were forced to divest their holdings shortly after they joined the administration, under federal ethics rules.
When Mr. Bush last spoke publicly about Enron on Jan. 11, he distanced himself from Mr. Lay, saying he recalled that the Texas executive had also supported Mr. Bush's rival, Ann Richards, for governor of Texas -- and expressed concern for Enron's workers. Mr. Bush also called for an investigation into "the whys of Enron," focusing on changing rules to protect the life savings of workers. But in those comments, he never criticized the company or its executives, many of whom were his political and social friends in Texas. His tone suggested that he viewed Enron's collapse as an example of the ups and downs of capitalism, rather than an effort to defraud.
Today, after a stream of revelations about the company's efforts to hide its debts and overstate its profits, Mr. Bush seemed angry -- both at the company and at suggestions that his administration had been unduly influenced by a major contributor.
"If somebody has got an accusation about some wrongdoing, just let me know," he told reporters.
"It's like when I talked with Don Evans and O'Neill," he said, referring to his commerce secretary and Paul H. O'Neill, the secretary of the Treasury, "they told me they had spoke to Enron. I said, 'Tell the people what you did.' "
He brushed aside any suggestion that Enron officials, in several meetings with Vice President Dick Cheney and his energy task force, had influenced the administration's energy policy. "We laid out the energy report," Mr. Bush said. "It's fully disclosed." 
Mr. Bush called for action to prevent a recurrence of the Enron debacle, saying, "Our government must do something about it."
But he never elaborated on how oversight of companies like Enron, or their accounting firms, should change.
And just minutes later, addressing workers at the Walker Machinery Company here about the economy and his campaign against terrorism, Mr. Bush returned to one of his favorite themes: that the government overregulates the economy and should let up on American companies so they are freer to act as they see fit. He said the government should "not overregulate those who are trying to create work." 
As Mr. Bush spoke today, new details were emerging about shredded documents at the company's headquarters. Enron said in federal court that a second batch of shredded documents was found on Monday night in a trash receptacle at the company's headquarters. 
Enron officials said they knew nothing about the destruction of the documents and they insisted that the company had repeatedly ordered employees not to destroy documents after a series of lawsuits and federal investigations began looking into the collapse of the company last October and November. Destroying documents that are relevant to those investigations or to lawsuits against the company and its executives would be a crime.
But lawyers representing shareholders and employees said they doubted that explanation. "This cannot be tolerated," said William Lerach, an attorney in a class-action suit against Enron and Andersen, pointing to a box of shredded Enron documents that he brought to the court hearing. "The integrity of the civil litigation system has been insulted."
He and others asked Judge Melinda Harmon of Federal District Court in Houston to seize the company's documents and put them under the guard of United States marshals. They argued that Enron and Andersen could not be trusted to turn over valuable evidence related to the case.
The court hearing came a day after a former Enron employee, Maureen Castaneda, said that she had found a box of shredded documents on the 19th floor of the Enron headquarters, the same floor where the company found additional evidence of shredding on Monday night. Ms. Castaneda, who was a director of foreign exchange at Enron until she was fired last week, said she took a box home to use the confetti as packing material. She said the box contained shards of paper referring to some of the secret Enron partnerships that are at the center of the accounting scandal that forced the company into bankruptcy protection.
Efforts to reach Ms. Castaneda today were unsuccessful. The company said that it was now cooperating with federal investigators and that company lawyers had interviewed several workers on the 19th floor about document shredding.
"Until yesterday, the company believed the process was working and was completely observed," Kenneth Marks, a lawyer for Enron, said today. "We don't know what happened here. There could be completely innocent explanations for this."
Rusty Hardin, a lawyer for Andersen, criticized the opposing lawyers for drumming up publicity with television interviews Monday night, a day ahead of the scheduled hearing. Mr. Hardin said lawyers for Andersen were working hard to preserve and recover documents.
"We are not suicidal," he said, gesturing toward Judge Harmon. "If we were shredders and not preserving documents you could run us out of business."
In an interview today, an Enron employee who works on the 19th floor confirmed that shredded material had filled a plastic bin beside the shredding machine for several weeks. He said that he had never seen anyone actually doing the shredding but that he had assumed it was taking place.
"It was obvious there was paper in the shredder," he said. "Probably recently."
He said the 19th floor is divided between a research division and payroll and accounting departments. The employee, who spoke on the condition that his name not be used, said he had not considered the evidence of shredding in a common room to be significant because accounting and payroll employees routinely destroy documents.
And he said that while company executives had sent three e-mail messages in October outlining restrictions on shredding, he had not interpreted those messages to be blanket prohibitions but instead were limited to documents related to the investigations. He said a fourth e-mail message sent on Jan. 14 was emphatic that all shredding cease.
Document shredding seems likely to be a main topic of the coming Congressional hearings. Tonight, the House Energy and Commerce Committee, preparing for its hearing on Thursday on shredding of documents by Andersen, Enron's auditors, was expected to subpoena four current or former Andersen officials: Joseph F. Berardino, the chief executive; Michael C. Odom, a partner in the firm's Houston office who was relieved of management responsibilities last week; Nancy Temple, a lawyer in the firm's Chicago headquarters; and Mr. Duncan, the lead partner on the Enron account.
Ms. Temple and Mr. Odom are expected to testify willingly, but Mr. Berardino and Mr. Duncan are resisting, investigators say, and Mr. Duncan may invoke his Fifth Amendment right, they said.
"Duncan remains an extremely recalcitrant witness who believes he ought to be able to take the Fifth by fax," said Representative James C. Greenwood, the Pennsylvania Republican who is chairman of the subcommittee that will hold the hearing. If Mr. Duncan does not at least show up to exercise his Fifth Amendment rights, Mr. Greenwood said, the subcommittee would consider citing him for contempt of Congress.

HEADLINE: THE POP LIFE; 
Incongruously, Moldova Samples the Club Scene

BYLINE:  By NEIL STRAUSS 

DATELINE: CHISINAU, Moldova 

 BODY:
Times are far from good here in the capital of Moldova, a tiny republic squeezed by Romania to the south and west and landlocked by Ukraine everywhere else. In an economy that has shrunk by 60 percent since the breakup of the Soviet Union a decade ago, the average Moldovan salary is between $25 and $45 a month, life expectancy has dropped by five years, and living conditions are abysmal.
 When Moldova is in the news it is usually for lurid tales like that of hospital workers selling human organs as meat to street vendors, or of the estimate that more than half of Europe's sex workers have been kidnapped from this country of 4.4 million. Considering that by comparison life in the Soviet Union now seems like the good old days, it is little surprise that last year Moldova became the first former Soviet state to vote the Communists back into power. 
 But step into the nightclub Soho, which opened last month just off the main street, Bulevardul Stefan cel Mare, and another world awaits. A state-of-the-art sound and light system propels four plush floors of revelers. Dancers costumed as Santa Claus, Teletubbies, ballerinas and teddy bears run rampant through the main floor, jumping off ledges, throwing each other in the air and grabbing clubgoers. An M.C. shouts exhortations from the stage, and a D.J. from Ukraine plays the latest American, European and Russian dance music (most of it downloaded illicitly from the Internet and burned onto CD's).
Above the bar, a shirtless customer dangles upside down from a metal rod as a bartender tries to pour a drink down his throat. Nearby, a woman gyrates in a crow's nest below an extensive catwalk that encircles the club. A hidden stairwell on the glass-filled top level leads to a secret fifth floor, where a luxurious private room (and bedroom) is reserved for the club's owners and their guests.
Though Soho is the most modern-looking club in Chisinau (pronounced KISH-e-now), it may not be for long. Promoters estimate that six new discos will open in the city by spring. "Between now and May, there will be a lot of changes in the nightlife in Chisinau," said Eugene Kara, one of the managers of another club that opened last month, Studio 01. "It's like a revolution."
At Studio 01, five minutes from Soho, is a first for Chisinau: the daunting red velvet ropes that are nearly ubiquitous at trendy lounges in New York. In a back room in the basement club, managers watch the front entrance through security cameras, making or breaking a local's night out by radioing the bouncer with orders to admit or deny. Mr. Kara said there were three types of people he did not let in: "no mafia, no people with fat stomachs and no punks." He then added a fourth category: "people who just want to sit around and look at girls." 
Studio 01 is a smaller affair than Soho, a darkened room with couches, tables and television screens surrounding a sunken dance floor. On a recent weekend, D.J. Yarik from Moscow was playing downtempo dance beats while a saxophonist stood nearby, improvising to the music. 
Some people, Mr. Kara acknowledges, are upset and frustrated with the club's door policy. "There aren't enough of the right kind of people in this city," he said, pledging to school the city in contemporary trends and fashion.
In a society undergoing great upheaval as the government tries to Russify the country (which has bobbled back and forth between Russia and Romania for centuries), club managers are trying to pull the youth in another direction. "We want to change the mentality of our people," said Alexander Peklo, a manager at Soho. "We want them to be closer to Europe and the U.S.A. -- in club style and music. And right now they're very far away, so it has to happen slowly, step by step."
Of course, as in any European city, American franchises have already come and conquered. On Bulevardul Stefan cel Mare, there is a McDonald's and a Benetton, but prices are so steep that, local businessmen say, many families dine at McDonald's only on special occasions and only about 30 families can afford to shop at Benetton.
"It's very hard living here," said Peter Oganesean, a bartender at Citi, a club where patrons may be techno-dancing one minute and joining hands for a traditional circle dance the next. "We have a lot of problems, but this new generation is more optimistic. They're learning different languages and economics. They just want to make their lives better. So they work very hard every day, and at night they want to relax and go to clubs. We lived 50 years with Communism and saw how Americans and Europeans lived so much better." He paused. "Now the president and Parliament are Communist again, but that's O.K."
There are other hypotheses about the nightclub boom. "People say, 'You're such a poor country, how do you have so much entertainment and clubs now?' " said Mr. Peklo of Soho. The answer, he said, is in the class divide that followed the fall of Communism: the poor grew more destitute, and a few people grew extremely rich. So though opening a nightclub in such an economy is hardly a get-rich-quick scheme, the lawyers and businessmen who started Soho (at a cost they put at about $500,000) and the much smaller rock club Black Elephant: The Underground Club, where a bust of Frank Zappa adorns the entryway, say they're just trying to bring modern culture and entertainment to their lives and city. Even Moldova's best band, Zdob si Zdub -- which combines punk-rock, Moldovan folk and Balkan brass-band music -- has performed more in Moscow than in its home country. 
"There are a lot of talented Moldovan musicians," Mr. Oganesean said. "But if you play Moscow, you make money. If you play Chisinau, you don't make any money."
Not one club owner said that his club was as full as it could be or making much money. Ciornaia Karacatita (which translates as Black Octopus), a nightspot that caters to an over-30 crowd, has been having a particularly tough time. 
"Originally, the club was for very rich people who could pay the $20 entrance fee," said Dimitri Shoimu, a manager and maitre d'hotel. "These days, business is bad; you know the situation in our country. Now it's $5. And business is worse." The club even had to close its casino last month, because new taxes made it too expensive to run.
Mr. Shoimu paused, then gestured toward the six people on the dance floor, swaying alongside giant Day-Glo decorations of undersea life (including, of course, a giant black octopus).
Optimism, however, seems to run as rampant as new clubs in this country. Smiling and looking at Mr. Peklo from Soho, Mr. Shoimu added, "But our manager said he'd invest some money to kill the competition."

HEADLINE: City's Welfare Rolls 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Joyce Purnick writes (Metro Matters column, Jan. 21), "The city's Independent Budget Office reported last week that welfare rolls grew by several thousand in October and November for first time in six years, and predicted that they would continue to rise for the next several months." 
 This might suggest that the Independent Budget Office based its estimate of what will happen to the city's welfare roll in the coming months on statistics from October and November. 
But as we say in our recent report, "I.B.O. bases its projection of a rising welfare roll on the assumption that the city will lose about 130,000 jobs before its economy picks up again in the summer of 2002."
Making projections can be controversial. But making these projections is what the Independent Budget Office must do to fulfill its role of keeping New Yorkers informed about important fiscal issues.

DOUG TURETSKY
Communications Director
N.Y.C. Independent Budget Office
New York, Jan. 21, 2002

HEADLINE: In Trade Issue, the Pressure Is on Flowers 

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY DePALMA 

 BODY:
Congress's failure to renew an unusual antinarcotics program that used flowers to fight drugs means that tariffs are now being collected on roses, carnations and certain other products imported from four South American nations for the first time in a decade.
 So far, the additional cost of the tariffs -- about 5 cents a rose -- has not generally found its way into the retail prices of fresh flowers, and the supply of imports has remained steady. But with Valentine's Day three weeks away, florists say that some of the extra cost may be passed on to consumers. 
 If the tariffs are not lifted soon, said Steve Neubauer, president of the Independent Florists' Association, "we may see some adjustment in prices." 
Congressional leaders say that in the new session that began yesterday, they will again try to remove the tariffs by extending a trade pact with the four Andean nations, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador and Peru. The pact was set up to use economic development to counter narcotics trafficking.
To give some impetus to what is considered to be a fairly remote issue in a time of pressing national matters, the extension may be packaged with three other Bush administration priorities, including the trade promotion, or fast-track, authority bill. All four may go to the floor for a final vote at the same time, perhaps in early March. 
In the last session of Congress, a similar piggybacking strategy backfired when a six-month extension of the Andean trade bill was tucked into an economic stimulus package being considered in the Senate. The stimulus package was held up, and the trade pact expired on Dec. 4. 
After a period of confusion over what to do about the tariffs, customs officials in the United States began collecting the duties at ports of entry late last year. Importers now pay a 6.8 percent tariff on Colombian roses, which arrive in Miami and other major ports. All other flowers from the Andean nations come in under a 6.4 percent levy, except for miniature carnations, for which a 3.2 percent duty is charged. 
"The vast majority of the people I speak to are just going to absorb the extra costs," Mr. Neubauer said. "Given the state of the economy, there's a great deal of sensitivity about price." 
California still produces a substantial crop of seasonal roses, but more than 80 percent of the fresh roses sold in the United States come from Colombia. The growth in Colombian exports has taken place largely in the decade since 1991, when the the Andean Trade Preference Act was passed.
The legislation was intended to encourage people in rural parts of Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador and Peru to produce legitimate market goods, like fresh flowers, instead of the coca leaves and poppies used to make cocaine and opium. 
The trade deal also reduces tariffs on certain textiles and on asparagus. Peru's asparagus crop is being harvested now, and the country's ambassador in Washington, Allan Wagner, has said that the expiration of trade preferences may drive some poor Peruvian farmers back to growing coca.
While it is clear that the trade pact has not made the narcotics problem disappear, enough progress has been made for a number of influential members of Congress to back the idea of extending the pact and expanding it to include more goods, like canned tuna from Ecuador and a greater variety of textiles. 
An extension of the pact until 2005 -- when the Free Trade Area of the Americas is supposed to be ready -- was approved by the House last year. A similar measure in the Senate was released from committee but never made it to a floor vote.
If the pact is renewed in this session, it will be retroactive to Dec. 4, and the duties now being collected on Colombian roses and other goods would be refunded. 
Peter J. Moran, executive vice president of the Society of American Florists, said he had received assurances from Senator Tom Daschle, the majority leader, that the issue would not be overlooked this session. "They told us that this will be one of their priorities when they return," Mr. Moran said. "We'll have to wait and see."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
Optimism needs a warning label when it comes to forecasting productivity.

BYLINE:  By Jeff Madrick; Jeff Madrick is the editor of Challenge Magazine and of a new journal of social health, Indicators. Both publications are based in Armonk, N.Y. He is an adjunct professor of humanities at Cooper Union. E-mail: challenge@mesharpe.com.

 BODY:
ONE tantalizing question in economics these days is whether productivity will rise as rapidly after this recession as it did in the late 1990's. If productivity -- the output of the economy per hour of work -- grows robustly, so will the economy. But if it does not, wages will not rise rapidly, profits will be weaker, and federal revenue will be much lower than expected. America may again find itself in a state of political confusion and disarray, just as it did in the slow-growing era from 1973 to 1995.
 At first glance, a few new studies on productivity's future suggest that there is ample reason to be optimistic. For example, two Federal Reserve economists, Stephen D. Oliner and Dan E. Sichel, say the range of productivity growth is likely to be 2 to 2.75 percent a year in coming years. From 1995 and 2001, productivity grew by roughly 2.3 percent a year. 
 Dale W. Jorgenson and Mun S. Ho of Harvard and Kevin J. Stiroh of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York say it could grow 2.25 percent a year, but they offer a wider range of 1.3 percent to 3 percent. A former chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, Martin N. Baily, says the range is likely to be 2 to 2.5 percent.
But when we look beneath the headlines, we find that this optimism is based on some fairly grand assumptions. If these are only slightly disappointing, productivity growth could be significantly lower than had been forecast.
First, the midrange conclusions of these studies assume that semiconductor and computer prices will continue to fall at the same stunning pace they did in the late 1990's, or at worst, not much more slowly. Can the industry keep up this level of innovation? Not everyone thinks it can.
Second, the studies assume that while investment in high technology may have been overenthusiastic in the 1990's, it will resume at a robust pace once the recession passes. A reason this is important is because a large part of the nation's total productivity gain in the 1990's was concentrated in the makers, not the users, of computer hardware, software and telecommunications equipment. If their sales growth tapers off, so will the entire economy's productivity. But some observers argue that business and home users already have more computer power than they need.
Third, most of these studies do not allow for the impact of cyclical demand. But, writes Mr. Baily, now at the Institute for International Economics, such rising demand may well have been an important cause of capital investment in high technology as sales and profits rose. And that demand benefited from loosening monetary policy, an unusually high dollar, which kept foreign capital coming in and inflation down, and soaring stock prices.
In addition, rising productivity in wholesale and retail trade, apparently a big source of productivity gains outside computers, was probably highly dependent on rapidly rising demand for goods. And rising productivity in the securities business, another big source of the nation's productivity gains, was particularly dependent on the soaring stock market. Will that recur?
So Mr. Baily is among the less optimistic of the productivity watchers unless demand keeps rising rapidly. But even his own modest forecast depends on counting productivity differently from most others. He says the Bureau of Labor Statistics' productivity data, based on estimates of production in the economy, are not necessarily accurate. Estimates of income, the other side of the financial statement, suggest more rapid productivity gains in the 1980's and 1990's. Mr. Baily averages the two. Again, by no means does everyone agree.
If these assumptions do not fall into place, it is entirely possible that productivity will grow over time by less than 2 percent. Mr. Oliner and Mr. Sichel's lower estimate of 2 percent, for example, would be significantly too high if computer prices fell only as fast as in the early 1990's while the portion of capital investment in high technology slowed even moderately. If Mr. Baily's estimate were put on a consistent basis with the other estimates, his lower limit would be significantly less than 2 percent a year. And such growth is far less than what the Congressional Budget Office is forecasting to determine future federal surpluses.
One lasting contribution of these studies, however, is that they help further puncture the romanticism about the new economy. The Oliner-Sichel study, for example, sees little benefit to purchasers of computers from "network effects," externalities, or increasing economies of scale. In other words, just because one company buys a computer does not mean that the productivity of other companies, even if they already have computers, will also rise.
On the other hand, a study by the McKinsey Global Institute concludes that there were such additional gains in productivity. But McKinsey says many of those came from managerial and organization innovations, like Wal-Mart's popular "big store" in retailing.
As Mr. Baily notes, such a conclusion is grounds for optimism. It suggests that future productivity is not completely dependent on how much companies invest in high technology, but on how innovative our companies can be across the board.
Thus, the nation has its work cut out for it. Government must maintain stable policies that sustain growth. Our companies must remain innovative and competitive. Antitrust policies probably need to be more closely enforced. In addition, in my view, investment funds cannot be wasted in rampant overspeculation, fed by opaque information from corporations and deliberate obfuscation by Wall Street. And, I would add, public investment in education, health care, infrastructure and research must be reinvigorated. Public investment is an area mainstream economists all too readily neglect at the nation's peril.
One immediate source of optimism should be taken with a grain of salt, however. Productivity has risen about 1.5 percent in the current recession, which has never happened before in the post-World War II period. But there have also never before been such harsh employment practices. Expendable temporary workers and the ease with which companies lay workers off are important sources of this productivity performance. They are not necessarily sources of long-term economic strength.

GRAPHIC: Photo: High technology's impact on productivity may be greatest in high technology. Greg Duhon, an engineer at the Internet service provider NetZero, checks the network. (Kim Kulish for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Optimistic Earnings Reports Lift Chip Makers

BYLINE:  By CHRIS GAITHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 23 

 BODY:
Earnings reports from chip makers over the last two days have bolstered hopes for a recovery and pushed an index of semiconductor stocks 4.3 percent higher. 
 While dreary compared with the fourth quarter of 2000, the reports from several smaller manufacturers of chips and chip-making equipment nonetheless generally met or beat Wall Street's expectations. The Philadelphia Stock Exchange's semiconductor index gained 21.41 today, to 520.54, on announcements from Novellus and others. 
 LSI Logic, which makes customized microchips for communications networks, typified the mix of good and bad news. After markets closed today, the company said fourth-quarter sales fell by nearly half from a year earlier, to $406 million, and it reported a loss of $74 million, or 20 cents a share. But the loss was 4 cents a share narrower than analysts had expected, and the company predicted increased sales of as much as 3 percent this quarter and a return to profit in the second half of the year.
STMicroelectronics, the European chip maker, reported Tuesday that earnings and sales matched analysts' estimates. Despite a prediction that its slump would continue into this quarter, its shares rose 4.2 percent, to $30.76, today.
Fairchild Semiconductor reported a 31 percent year-over-year decline in sales Tuesday, but posted an unexpected profit and said bookings improved in its communications, computing, displays and industrial businesses. The book-to-bill ratio was above 1, a sign of a growing market, for the second consecutive quarter.
"We continue to believe that we saw the low point for our trade sales in the third quarter and that we are moving through the early stages of a market recovery," said Kirk Pond, the president and chief executive. 
Manufacturers of chip-making equipment led the rally after a trade group said late Tuesday that the industry's sales in December rose from the previous month for the first time in a year. The group, Semiconductor Equipment and Materials International, said the industry reported December sales of $834.9 million and new orders of $652.4 million, for a book-to-bill ratio of 0.78. The ratio improved from 0.73 in November.
Novellus, an equipment maker, reported fourth-quarter profits on Tuesday that declined 81 percent and said it would report a wider-than-expected loss for the current quarter. But in an example of investor optimism, its shares rose $3.42, or 9 percent, today to close at $39.65.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: KABUL; 
At Long Last, Paychecks for Afghan Civil Servants

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: KABUL, Afghanistan, Jan. 22 

 BODY:
It is payday at long last in Afghanistan, and after months of penury the lucky few are taking home their first wages since last July dreaming of simple things.
 "First of all, I'll repay all the people I borrowed from," said Muhammad Rahim, an accountant in the Finance Ministry. 
 Mr. Rahim moonlighted as a laborer to earn money for his family during the six months that Afghanistan's government did not pay salaries. 
He also sold off his car, furniture and television set.
Asked what he would buy with what was left after paying his debts, Mr. Rahim said, "Food, food, food."
What if there is still a bit left for luxuries?
"I would like to buy books for my children," Mr. Rahim said. "I don't want them to grow up illiterate."
Paying government workers is a small step in Afghanistan's long climb to normality. But it was deeply encouraging to people here, who worked for five years under the Taliban only to learn that its leaders had looted the central bank before they skipped town.
"We have found hope with the new government," said Shah Jihan, a clerk at the Finance Ministry.
On Tuesday, the government paid monthly salaries to 1,381 workers in Kabul, with the typical salary being about $45 a month.
By the end of this week it plans to pay $8 million in wages to 219,000 civil servants throughout the country. It does not yet have the money to pay soldiers. Nor can it pay the overdue salaries.
The Taliban stopped paying workers even before the United States bombing campaign began last October because of economic woes caused by drought and internecine fighting.
"This is only a start," said Abdul Qadeer Fitrat, the acting governor of the central bank. "But we're optimistic that more money will start flowing into the country."
The country desperately needs it. Before the Taliban fled the capital in November, they stole millions of dollars from the vault at the central bank. When Northern Alliance troops pried open the door, they found less than $150,000 worth of afghanis, the local currency.
The Taliban left behind five-foot-high piles of cash. Officials say that was only because it was in small denominations and too heavy to carry.
"Our country lost its dignity because of them," said Abdul Zahir, the guardian of the vault.
The cash used to pay this month's salaries was printed in Moscow during the time that Burhanuddin Rabbani was president of Afghanistan. It was in a Moscow warehouse when the Taliban seized Kabul in 1996 and was finally delivered here last week in three cargo planes.
Mr. Fitrat said future payments would be made with money from a startup fund donated by the United States, Britain and other countries. That account, supervised by the United Nations, contains about $10 million, short of the $20 million the United Nations had hoped to raise.
This week in Tokyo, international donors also pledged more than $4.5 billion to Afghanistan, which has been ravaged by 23 years of war. But that money is aimed at long-term reconstruction rather than the government's immediate expenses.
To pay all the back salaries to the civil servants and the military, Mr. Fitrat estimated that the government would need $200 million to $250 million. The United Nations recently appealed for an additional $80 million to fortify the startup fund.
Mr. Fitrat said the government hoped to generate income from taxes, license fees and interest rates. The Taliban abolished the charging of interest on the ground that it violated Islamic principles.
In a country where computers are as rare as nightclubs, the transfer of money today was charmingly old-fashioned. Tellers handed huge sacks of bills to cashiers from the ministries. They slung the sacks over their shoulders and made for the exit.
Shir Ali, the bag carrier for the Finance Ministry, hauled his red and white sack containing 290 million afghanis -- $10,700 at current exchange rates -- across a busy traffic circle, dodging trucks and horse-drawn carts.
When Mr. Ali arrived, he was hustled into a room as a crowd of employees milled restively outside.
"They're paying all the ministries before ours," one man said as he paced angrily up and down the hall. The Finance Ministry, not surprisingly, was among the first to be paid.
Nur Muhammad, a comptroller, asserted that as a 30-year employee of the ministry he deserved prompt payment. "My house burned down," he said. "My health is poor. I need the money."
For the most part, though, people here responded with equanimity to the long wait for their paychecks. "God willing, I can see the light at the end of the tunnel," said Mr. Rahim, the accountant.
Shah Jihan stood contentedly with a colleague, putting together his first shopping list in six months. It included flour, cooking oil and tea. Goaded by his friend, he threw in a few discretionary items: mattresses, pillows and perhaps a carpet.
"We should buy what we need before we start thinking about luxuries," Mr. Jihan said with a smile.

GRAPHIC: Photo: In Kabul on Tuesday, the Central Bank began cashing paychecks for civilian employees of the Afghan government. It does not yet have the money for soldiers' pay, or for salaries that are months overdue. (Chang W. Lee/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: City Reviewing Investment Strategy for Its Pensions 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
The pension funds for New York City's firefighters, teachers, police officers and other workers lost $109 million in Enron investments and $25 million in Kmart investments, leading the city comptroller to say yesterday that he was considering a change in how the funds invest.
 In recent years the city's pension funds have invested more money in index funds, which generally track whole segments of the stock market, and the city has relied less on money managers to actively monitor investment funds and consider other factors in buying and selling stock. But the comptroller, William C. Thompson, who took office Jan. 1, said the heavy blow delivered by the collapse of Enron and the plummeting stock price of Kmart, which were both companies included in the index funds' investments, was leading him to review that strategy. 
 Mr. Thompson said that while index funds charge smaller fees than actively managed funds, and many had done well over time, they lacked "aggressive, or active managers, who will say, 'Oops, look at this,' and will bail out of a situation if they start looking at it as it deteriorates." 
New York State's pension fund system also suffered because of its investments in the two companies. But while the state's pension system, at $112 billion, is larger than the city's $77 billion system, the state lost less money: $58 million on investments in Enron and $17 million on investments in Kmart, according to figures provided by State Comptroller H. Carl McCall's office. 
The state sold its remaining Kmart stock on Friday, when shares closed at $1.74 each, said Jeffrey Gordon, a spokesman for Mr. McCall. The city's funds still hold 1,772,895 shares of Kmart common stock. Kmart filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday, and it was priced at 89 cents a share at the end of trading yesterday. Marc Kalech, a spokesman for Mr. Thompson, said the city's pension funds held on to so many Kmart shares because the pension system's index funds held on to the shares. He did not say which funds held the stock.
The S & P 500, one of the most popular indexes, announced last Wednesday that it was dropping Kmart.
On the Enron front, the city is going to court to try to recoup the $109 million its funds lost.
The city joined forces with Florida, whose pension system lost $306 million in Enron investments, and filed papers on Jan. 14 in Federal District Court in Houston seeking to be named the lead plaintiffs in a class action suit against the Enron Corporation and several of its top executives.
Pension funds around the nation lost money in the Enron collapse, and a number of municipalities and investors are seeking to be named lead plaintiff in the suit against Enron. Michael A. Cardozo, the city's corporation counsel, said that in class action securities suits, the investors who could show that they lost the most were usually named the lead plaintiffs. A suit brought jointly by Florida and New York City could claim $415 million in losses. 
"Both Florida and the N.Y.C. funds are prepared to commit all of the personnel and resources necessary to adequately manage this litigation," Leslie A. Conason, an assistant corporation counsel, wrote in an affidavit filed with the court.
Mr. Thompson, the city comptroller, said that his office was working with the corporation counsel to bring the suit. 
"The fact that people were misled and information was denied, that's the reason that you'd wind up suing," he said. "Based on that situation -- that's what made Enron so different from other things, the fact that information wasn't made public, that things were concealed, and that accounting that was done wasn't accurate. That is something that stockholders have a right to."
New York City has five pension funds, for teachers, firefighters, police officers, city employees, and other Board of Education workers. The city comptroller sits on the boards of four of the funds, and serves as investment adviser and custodian to all five. Under the previous comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, the funds increased the use of index funds for buying stock, and during the stock market boom of the late 1990's, the funds prospered, earning more than had been anticipated. But like other investment funds, and many private 401(k) plans, the funds have suffered during the recent recession. 
Mr. Thompson said that it was too soon to tell how much more money the city might have to contribute to the funds to offset losses in the market. But he said that he would speak to the trustees of all five funds about the possibility of relying less on indexes and on looking for long-term investments.
"The one thing is that you look at pension systems over an extended period of time -- you are a long-term investor," he said. "It is not just what happens today, it is what happens next year, 5 years, 10 years down the road that you're most interested in, and providing stable returns for all the members of the pension system."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Comptroller William C. Thompson, who appeared before reporters yesterday with Public Advocate Betsy Gotbaum, said yesterday that he might change the way the city's five pension funds make investments. (Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: New Murder Trial Begins In 1981 Killing of Doctor 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT F. WORTH 

 BODY:
More than 20 years after a Manhattan doctor was fatally shot in Washington Heights, prosecutors began a fresh attempt yesterday to convict one of the two men they say killed him.
 The defendant, Daryl Whitley, is on trial for the second time in the killing of Dr. John Chase Wood Jr., who was shot to death on Nov. 2, 1981, in a botched robbery attempt as he returned to Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after visiting his wife, who was five months pregnant. Mr. Whitley's first trial, in late 1997, ended in a hung jury, and the man charged as his accomplice was later acquitted. 
 In opening statements in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday, an assistant district attorney, Joel J. Seidemann, said the prosecution would be built on testimony from Mr. Whitley's former friends and acquaintances who say he confessed his role in the crime to them. "It was in essence the neighborhood's worst-kept secret," Mr. Seidemann told the jury.
Mr. Whitley's lawyer, Michael Yucevicius, said those witnesses were convicted criminals who stood to gain by implicating Mr. Whitley. After Mr. Whitley's first trial, the jury foreman said concern about the credibility of the witnesses was the main factor in the jury's inability to reach a verdict.
Mr. Whitley, standing near a coffee shop outside the courthouse yesterday during a break in the trial, professed his innocence. "I have nothing to hide," he said, adding that he was speaking against the advice of his lawyer. "Whoever did this crime deserves to pay, but they didn't catch the right people."
Mr. Whitley was arrested in 1995 and detained at Rikers Island until his release in 1998 after the mistrial. "This case just about killed me," he said.
Prosecutors said Dr. Wood was confronted at West 165th Street and Riverside Drive by a man who demanded his money and threatened him. Dr. Wood, who had only $5 and some credit cards in his wallet, tried to escape, but was shot twice, the first shot grazing his collarbone, the second going through his heart. Dr. Wood, who had just turned 31, died shortly afterward at Columbia-Presbyterian, after his colleagues made desperate efforts to save his life. 
In his opening remarks, Mr. Seidemann said that after an accomplice shot Dr. Wood, Mr. Whitley turned to him and said, "Why did you have to do this?" Mr. Seidemann told jurors that the accomplice was Patrick R. McDowell, who was acquitted of murder in 1996 and of a lesser murder charge in 1997.
Prosecutors said yesterday that the only witness to the slaying in 1981 was a woman who was 20 to 30 feet away and walking home from the hospital with her 5-month-old baby in a stroller. But she did not identify Mr. Whitley's picture after he was arrested in 1995. There were no fingerprints or other physical evidence.
For years after the slaying there was little progress in the investigation. But a detective in the 34th Precinct, Jerry Giorgio, persisted, interviewing potential witnesses living near the crime scene. In 1994, his work led to the arrest of Mr. McDowell, an unemployed janitor from Washington Heights who had spent 10 of the previous 13 years in prison for another murder. A year later, the police arrested Mr. Whitley.
Mr. Seidemann said he would introduce a new witness, a man who was close to the crime scene but only briefly glimpsed the assailants. He also said the case would be built primarily on accounts from former friends and acquaintances of Mr. Whitley, who would describe conversations in which he confessed his role in the killing. 
Mr. Yucevicius, echoing the themes of the defense in Mr. Whitley's first trial, said the people who said Mr. Whitley had confessed were convicted felons who had been pressured to implicate him in exchange for help in their own cases. Some of them had lied to judges in previous criminal proceedings, he said. One of them "may be under the belief that he will go to jail unless he implicates Mr. Whitley," he added.
"The prosecution's proof in this case comes from the words of informants who are not worthy of your belief," Mr. Yucevicius told the jury.
Mr. Whitley is charged with second-degree murder, and faces 25 years to life in prison if convicted, a spokeswoman for the Manhattan district attorney's office said.

HEADLINE: Indonesian Troops Kill Leader of a Province's Separatist Group 

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Thursday, Jan. 24 

 BODY:
Indonesian troops shot and killed the commander of the separatist Aceh Liberation Movement in a raid on his jungle headquarters in Aceh, a rebellious province on the northern tip of the island of Sumatra, the military announced today.
 The death of the commander, Tengku Abdullah Syafei, in a firefight with the Indonesian soldiers on Tuesday is expected to be cited by the army as an important victory, coming fast on the order by President Megawati Sukarnoputri to take bolder measures to stamp out Aceh's 25-year-old independence movement. 
 But the increasingly violent fighting in the province, where an estimated 1,500 people were killed last year, has alienated ordinary Acehnese from the Indonesian armed forces. A study last year by the nonpartisan International Crisis Group reported that if the Acehnese were asked to choose between autonomy from the central government and outright independence, they would choose independence. 
According to accounts by the Indonesian military today, Mr. Syafei, 46, was shot in the thigh and chest Tuesday morning during a 30-minute battle with soldiers in Pidie about 80 miles east of the provincial capital, Banda Aceh. His body and that of one of his wives, Aisyah Umar, were identified by relatives at a hospital on Wednesday afternoon, the accounts said.
A spokesman for the liberation movement, commonly known by its Indonesian acronym, GAM, confirmed that Mr. Syafei had been killed. Other members of the movement vowed that his death would inspire Acehnese to join its armed wing, which was run by Mr. Syafei.
The movement is considered to hold sway over large areas of Aceh's territory, which contain much of Indonesia's oil and natural gas exports. ExxonMobil, which runs oil fields in Aceh, had to close operations last year because of the unrest, and only recently resumed.
The Indonesian military has been accused of serious human rights abuses in quashing the rebels. The Bush administration, like its predecessors, has opposed the breakup of Indonesia and has discouraged independence movements in Aceh and in the eastern most area of Irian Jaya. But late last year, the United States Embassy here released a statement urging Mrs. Megawati's government to embrace the people of Aceh by protecting their human rights.
The statement was interpreted as an effort to warn the Indonesian military that it would be difficult for the Bush administration to persuade Congress to provide money for training for the army if human rights abuses continued in Aceh.
The military wing of the liberation movement has been shrouded in mystery. Mr. Syafei was known as a charismatic figure but he rarely granted interviews and was hardly ever seen. His troops are said to number between 15,000 and 27,000, but only a few thousand are said to have modern firearms.
In an effort to quell the violence, the prior Indonesian president, Abdurrahman Wahid, offered broad autonomy to Aceh, saying this would alleviate the political and economic exploitation of the province by the central government. But the gesture was interpreted in Aceh as halfhearted. Peace talks broke down and the fighting increased. 
The issue of Islam versus Christianity, which is at the center of other conflicts in Indonesia, has not played a major role in Aceh. The province embraced Islam in the 16th century and has practiced a conservative brand of the religion ever since.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters; 
Pataki Takes Roosevelts To Heart

BYLINE:  By JOYCE PURNICK 

DATELINE: ALBANY 

 BODY:
DISCUSSING his new budget on Tuesday, Gov. George E. Pataki stood before a portrait of his favorite predecessor, Teddy Roosevelt, inviting inevitable comparisons.
 The governor was being "very Teddy," one Republican said, "so optimistic." 
 No, said another, that makes him more like F.D.R. 
George Pataki as Franklin Delano Roosevelt? Let's not get carried away.
But the governor's new budget proposal does prove, if there was still any doubt, that he is not the same Peekskill Republican who was elected in 1994.
He has moved far enough leftward to make Democrats here squirm. It dawned on them that Mr. Pataki proposed an unexpectedly gentle election-year budget that keeps pain to a minimum, protects labor and relies heavily on budgetary gimmicks straight out of the Democratic playbook. 
Even the leading Democrat here, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, was reduced to stating the obvious, that Mr. Pataki was "kicking off his re-election campaign." Mr. Silver kept saying he wanted to make changes in the governor's proposal, including financing prekindergarten classes and blocking the governor from delaying a student scholarship program. But he couldn't explain where he would find the money.
The two Democrats who want to run against Mr. Pataki -- Comptroller H. Carl McCall and Andrew M. Cuomo -- were left sniping about budget gimmicks. But how can Democrats condemn tactics their party proudly practiced for so long?
Now this governor has proven his own dexterity, political as well as budgetary. He struck a health care deal that pays for medical programs and salary increases for health care workers in the union headed by the influential Dennis Rivera. Given this deal and the governor's trip with him to Puerto Rico last April to protest naval exercises on Vieques, Mr. Rivera, who usually supports Democrats, will not rule out supporting Mr. Pataki in November. (The union leader resigned from the Democratic National Committee yesterday, saying he had a time problem, not a party problem.)
In any case, it cannot hurt the governor's re-election chances that his proposed budget spends generously in a bad economy, sparing Mr. Rivera's membership hardships that seemed inevitable.
If the governor gets his way, bus and subway fares will not increase in the next year, nor will tuition at the city and state universities. No state workers will be laid off. And tax cuts will not be deferred, to the delight of Republican and Democratic lawmakers, who are also up for re-election.
Mr. Pataki's budget provides no increase in school aid, but now that he has taken care of health care workers, he may also be in a position to help public school teachers, using bond sales to make $204 million available to the New York City Board of Education in each of the next two years. The state would pay both the interest and principal.
HOW can the governor do this in a recession? The $88.6 billion budget plan is not profligate in its spending, but neither is it draconian, despite the anticipated gap of $5.1 billion.
Mr. Pataki has simply decided that the terrorism of Sept. 11 created an emergency, and so warranted extraordinary maneuvers and hopes. He proposes spending about 80 percent of the state's reserve fund that he set aside in fatter times, to use one-time income for expenses that will keep recurring, and to hope for federal dollars and an early end to the recession.
Not all of the federal money is certain by any means, and some may be needed for growing welfare rolls.
"It's a budget that calls for extraordinary measures to deal with extraordinary circumstances," the governor said, justifying his reliance on the rainy day fund. Between the recession and Sept. 11, "We didn't get a rainy day, but we got a monsoon."
What will happen next year, when the one-shots and rainy day funds are gone? Or if the number of welfare recipients increases more than expected? The governor is clearly betting that the recession, as some economists predict, will end halfway through the year and that state revenues will grow enough to compensate for the one-shots. "It's a gamble," one budget analyst said. "If he loses, next year's budget will be horrendous. In the meantime, it's good for the city and the state." And for Mr. Pataki's prospects next November.
A bold bet like that is not the fashion in conservative Peekskill, nor will it ever win favor with fiscal monitors. But it has been the style of the most famous governors in Albany, most notably the Republican as well as Democratic Roosevelt.
