HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; 
For Musicals, Big and Brassy Gives Way To Small And Affordable

BYLINE:  By BRUCE WEBER 

 BODY:
IN November an unheralded and underfinanced new musical, "Little Ham," began a showcase production at the Hudson Guild Theater in Chelsea. After four weeks, to attract publicity and potential investors, the show converted to a union contract and had an official Off Broadway opening. Without expectations I went to see it, mainly because the week before Christmas there wasn't much else on my theatergoing schedule.
 Based on a 1936 comedy by Langston Hughes, the show, which has been in glacially paced development since the mid-1980's, turned out to be lively and well performed if old-fashioned. Set in Harlem, with a plot about gamblers, gangsters and a neighborhood caught up in the numbers racket, it had a fine, jazz-based score played by an onstage band, spirited and clever lyrics and an ingratiating cast of 14 actors, unfamiliar to me, working for union scale. It extended for a week and then, even with a string of sold-out performances, closed. 
 The Hudson Guild has only 99 seats, nowhere near enough to support the show financially, despite its shoestring budget. So to have the further life its producer, Eric Krebs, imagines for it, "Little Ham" needs more space. More space demands grander and more complicated choreography, a snazzier set, more ambitious lighting and sound design. And those things cost money. Which leaves Mr. Krebs, who put on the showcase and its extension at an unrecouped cost of some $150,000, with a decision that has become typical for producers of emerging musicals: How big a show should this be?
In some ways this is always the question a producer asks in trying to balance the art and commerce of putting on a show. But over the last few seasons, with more musicals crowding into the pipeline, musical-friendly theaters in short supply and Broadway economics more daunting than ever, the conventional wisdom regarding what size show belongs in what size theater has been challenged as never before. For one thing, smaller shows that can be exploited to fill a Broadway house and command Broadway prices have become the gold standard for producers who aren't corporations or affiliated with Mel Brooks. "Rent," which began life as a modestly conceived piece at the New York Theater Workshop, is one such show. "Chicago," a slightly enhanced concert version of the original Bob Fosse show that was plucked from the "Encores!" series at City Center, is another. And so is "Mamma Mia!," which strikes me as little more than a few recycled sugary pop songs and some excellent amplification equipment.
But obviously, not every attempt succeeds. Last year "A Class Act," a quaintly old-fashioned song and dance and story show with a small cast and a small orchestra, made the leap from the Manhattan Theater Club to the Walter Kerr Theater on Broadway, where it tanked. And this season's example, of course, is "Urinetown," which rode critical raves from the Fringe Festival to Off Broadway to the Henry Miller, where it opened in September. One reason it is a smash is that it costs the producers just over $200,000 a week to run it, less than half, maybe even less than a third of the weekly expenses for extravaganzas like "The Phantom of the Opera" and "The Lion King."
"The main thing I continually discover is, no one really knows anything," said Mr. Krebs, who has experience as a producer both on and off Broadway. "We take a major movie like 'Saturday Night Fever' and put in $10 million, and it fails. And we take a movie like 'The Producers' and put in $10 million, and it succeeds. 'Seussical,' with all those advance expectations, fails, and then 'Urinetown' becomes the darling of the establishment."

Born to Be Small
Still, audiences are now more keen for musicals than for plays, which means producers are eager to find ways to put them on the stage. And with a perpetual shortage of theaters with an orchestra pit, a stage wide and deep enough to accommodate an energetic choreographer and a sizable cast, fly space and wing space to allow scenery to be stored and moved around, and enough seats to pay for it all, they are looking to Off Broadway in ways they never have before. As a result, a flood of commercially produced musicals on a reduced scale have appeared in New York: "Tick, Tick . . . Boom!," "Bat Boy," "Reefer Madness," "Summer of '42," "Love, Janis" and "I Sing," to name a few presented in the last year.
Not that the Off Broadway musical is a new phenomenon. Shows like "The Fantasticks," "Threepenny Opera" and "Little Shop of Horrors" were famously successful in small downtown theaters, and the shoestring revue "I Love You, You're Perfect, Now Change" is in its sixth year at the Westside Theater. But these and other shows like them never created a tradition of their own. And after "A Chorus Line" leaped from the Public Theater to Broadway, many other musicals -- "Falsettos" and "Sunday in the Park With George" come to mind -- were nurtured and developed by nonprofit theaters with the goal of earning a place in the commercial spotlight. But in their Off Broadway incarnations they were like children growing to maturity; all along, everyone knew that when they were ready, they'd leave home to seek their fortunes.
The point is that until now the musical as a genre has generally implied the indulgence of show-biz hoopla, extravagance and spectacle, which was possible only on Broadway. That is no longer so. But what has changed isn't that such grandiosity is now more possible elsewhere; it's that it is less possible anywhere.
Why so many musicals off Broadway? "Two obvious reasons," said Michael David of Dodger Theatricals, the group that developed and produced "Urinetown" off Broadway and on. "One is that people refuse to stop writing them. The other is that Broadway makes it too expensive for them to be done."

Money Isn't There
That brings us back to "Little Ham," which is a case in point. Mr. Krebs would like to produce it on Broadway; he has been in discussions about putting the show in a small theater (the 597-seat Helen Hayes), a midsize theater (the Belasco, 1,018 seats) and a large one (the Richard Rodgers, 1,368 seats). But so far he has been unable to raise the $3.5 million or so required to mount a Broadway production. (At the Hayes the cost would be somewhat less.)
"People all around the country are congratulating me on the show," he said. "However, when it comes to raising $3.5 million, it's a different story. One major investor told me, 'I liked it a lot, but I'm putting money in another show this spring.' Another said, 'My heart isn't in this kind of material.' I'm also hearing that it's too old-fashioned, that there are no stars and that you can't make money with a black musical. So what does this mean?"
One thing it means, Mr. Krebs said, is that the show could end up Off Broadway again in its next incarnation, but as it happens, the most capacious theaters -- the Variety Arts and the Union Square -- are booked. So at the moment, the most likely home for the show is the 287-seat John Houseman Theater, after "Puppetry of the Penis" exhausts the city's supply of adolescent-minded voyeurs. It has a larger stage than most small theaters and, perhaps more crucial, Mr. Krebs has its long-term lease. He said, "believe it or not, I can make the numbers work."
The size of the theater in which the show ends up has implications not only for Mr. Krebs, his investors and the performers (whose unions mandate higher salaries for Broadway shows) but for audiences as well. For example, the set is to be redesigned by Edward T. Gianfresco in any case, but his resources will be determined by the theater. According to Mr. Krebs's figures, the cost of the show's physical production (sets, costumes, lighting, sound, props and installation in the theater), which was about $26,000 for the showcase, would be $90,000 for a new production Off Broadway. For Broadway, the budget jumps to $550,000. That's a lot of added bells and whistles for an audience to take in. On Broadway, it's likely that four ensemble members would be added to the cast to give heft to the choreography and the vocal arrangements, and the band would probably increase to seven members from five.

Reinventing a Form
All of this makes me wonder whether what we are witnessing is the evolution of a whole new theatrical genre, a pocket-size musical born of economic necessity but recognized by both artists and producers as a creative opportunity. A rock-based, small-cast performance piece like John Cameron Mitchell's "Hedwig and the Angry Inch" laid the groundwork for this season's unearthing of Jonathan Larson's compact early work, "Tick, Tick . . . Boom!," not to mention Randal Myler's "Love, Janis." Bruce Buschel and Diane Paulus took the music of Laura Nyro and built a kind of dance narrative around it; the show, "Eli's Comin', " appeared at the Vineyard Theater last year. Next month "The Last Five Years," a two-character musical about the decline and fall of a young marriage by Jason Robert Brown, the composer of "Parade," begins performances at the Minetta Lane Theater. All of these strike me as attempts to reinvent the form in a new order of magnitude.
Many of these newer, smaller shows are written by younger people who are aware of Broadway's forbidding odds and want to get a foot in the door. So they write for chamber groups, work in contemporary musical idioms and bring with them distinctly contemporary attitudes characterized by archness, irony, sarcasm and self-mockery. Shows like "Bat Boy" and "Urinetown" consciously spoof the traditional musical even as they pay homage to it, as if the young composers are aware that their love of musical theater is a guilty pleasure. ("Little Ham" is an obvious exception; the composer, Judd Woldin, who wrote the score for the 1974 Tony-winning musical "Raisin," is 76.)
Thus many of these shows are intended for younger audiences, which is not only a good thing but also a requirement.
"We thought 'Bat Boy' would attract a hip audience as well as a musical theater audience, and we also thought we were setting a tone for a new talent pool," said Robyn Goodman, one of the show's producers. Ms. Goodman, who was also involved in "Tick, Tick . . . Boom!" and "A Class Act," said that in the end the producers of "Bat Boy" may have underestimated its potential as an audience-pleaser. The show suffered, along with the rest of the theater world after Sept. 11, but its future was already in doubt. Even though it found a core downtown audience, it lost its entire capitalization of $1.8 million.
"We definitely thought it should be Off Broadway," Ms. Goodman said. "But then 'Urinetown' comes along, moves to Broadway and not only survives but succeeds. There was talk when 'Bat Boy' was closing that maybe we should just raise more money and move to Broadway ourselves. Maybe we were too timid. It does seem like the rules have changed."

Recouping on Tour
The sentimental "Summer of '42," with its bittersweet movie plot and saccharine score, can't lay similar claim to hipness. But like "Bat Boy," at $1.7 million it is among the larger musicals to try to make a go of it Off Broadway, which is what makes it particularly noteworthy. No thorough statistics are kept for Off Broadway shows, but several producers interviewed for this article noted that they didn't think the number of Off Broadway musicals is increasing noticeably. What has increased, they said, is the number of musicals Off Broadway with high profiles and budgets that will accommodate substantial advertising. 
"We had anticipated taking the show to Broadway," said Donald Frantz, the general manager of "Summer of '42.". "That was the production plan, but when we were reminded of what Broadway had become, a place where the dramatic audience won't go to a musical even if it has considerable dramatic content, and where tourists only want to see the biggest show, we reconsidered." Still, Mr. Frantz said, in a 499-seat theater like the Variety Arts, earning the $85,000 to $90,000 a week it costs to break even is difficult.
"It's particularly tough to make it through the lean months of January and February," he said. "So where does the small musical go if it has a dramatic message and isn't about how many feet are tapping?" When the show closes on Sunday, it will have earned back none of its capitalization.
Still, the producers are not only reasonably sanguine about their experience; they are reasonably pleased. With nine actors and six musicians, the show is an economically sound candidate for touring to regional nonprofit theaters (the Pasadena Playhouse in California has expressed interest) and to cities with modest-size commercial auditoriums -- seating, say, 1,000 to 1,500 people -- where larger shows cannot afford to play and where mainstream rather than envelope-pushing entertainment is relished. As an established entity, it should also generate ancillary revenue in stock and amateur rights.
"What we needed to do was display the piece in New York," Mr. Frantz explained, adding that to do so on Broadway would have cost $3.5 million, more than twice what the show has lost so far. "So you see, it's not a disaster at all."
In the end, whatever the success of the current crop of shows, it is indisputable that the landscape of musical theater is expanding and that artistic developments are being accompanied by emerging business and marketing models. It seems to me that the longer this goes on, the more likely it is that audience expectations will begin to change, that theatergoers will grow accustomed to and hence more accepting of musicals in varying shapes and sizes. Predictions are dangerous, and it has never been fashionable in the theater business to express optimism, but this represents progress.

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW; 
When You're in the Right, Obstinacy Can Be a Virtue

BYLINE:  By A. O. SCOTT 

 BODY:
The hero of "Beijing Bicycle" is Guei (Cui Lin), a young man from the countryside who finds a job in the Chinese capital working as a bike messenger. On one especially stressful day, he arrives at a high-class spa in search of a customer named Mr. Zhang, whom Guei interrupts in the midst of a massage. It turns out that this is the wrong Mr. Zhang, and the mix-up culminates in a comical standoff with the management, the summoning of uniformed security guards and a sarcastic piece of advice from a receptionist: "Try Zhang Yimou."
 That Mr. Zhang is one of the best-known filmmakers of the Fifth Generation, whose movies, mostly set in rural China in the recent and distant past, have been among the country's most prestigious cultural exports since the mid-1980's. Wang Xiaoshuai, the director of "Beijing Bicycle," is younger than Mr. Zhang, part of a generation that has concerned itself with naturalistic, sometimes harsh depictions of Chinese urban life. (Mr. Wang's previous film, an atmospheric Shanghai noir called "So Close to Paradise," was released in the United States last year.) 
 But the invocation of Zhang Yimou's name is more than a throwaway joke. Guei could be the male counterpart to one of Mr. Zhang's peasant heroines, like the young teacher in "Not One Less" or the indomitable women played, in at least a half-dozen movies, by Gong Li. He shares with them the virtue of obstinacy. The other characters -- from his boss and co-workers at the Fei Da Express Delivery Company to the gang of schoolboys who torment him -- pay repeated, grudging tribute to his incorrigible stubbornness. When his bicycle is stolen, he sets off in search of it, an enterprise less like trying to find a needle in a haystack than like looking for a particular bit of hay.
The bicycle, purchased from Fei Da for a portion of his weekly wages, is Guei's livelihood, and its disappearance (just after the incident at the spa) may remind you of Vittorio De Sica's "Bicycle Thief."
Mr. Wang has updated De Sica's lyrical fable of urban poverty to the bustling, grasping streets of contemporary Beijing, a city in perpetual and exhausting motion, where people are simultaneously trying to scratch out a living and participate in the frenetic consumer economy. The bike eventually comes into the possession of a petulant student named Jian (Li Bin), who values it as highly as Guei does, but for different reasons. For Jian it is a way to impress girls and to fit in with his classmates. The money that his father had promised would be spent on a new bike has instead gone to his stepsister's tuition, and the actions Jian takes to get what he wants seem justified to him. Losing the bike, which its owner eventually comes to claim, would mean, for Jian, a kind of social death, and he doesn't care that for Guei it might mean something worse.
The conflict between the two young men, which reaches a climax of surprising brutality, develops slowly. Mr. Wang has a graceful, almost classical sense of perspective. He positions his camera at a distance from the action, using the mazelike alleyways of the city's poor districts to produce precise, painterly configurations of light and shadow. "Beijing Bicycle" is at once somber and mysterious, comical and sad. It shows just how lonely a crowded city can be.
"Beijing Bicycle" is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for a few violent scenes.

BEIJING BICYCLE

Directed by Wang Xiaoshuai; written (in Mandarin, with English subtitles) by Mr. Wang, Tang Danian, Peggy Chiao and Hsu Hsiao-Ming; director of photography, Liu Jie; edited by Liao Ching-Song; music by Wang Feng; art directors, Tsai Chao-Yi and Cao Anjun; produced by Ms. Chiao, Mr. Hsu and Han Sangping; released by Sony Pictures Classics. Running time: 113 minutes. This film is rated PG-13.

WITH: Cui Lin (Guei), Li Bin (Jian), Zhou Xun (Qin), Gao Yuanyuahn (Xiao), Li Shuang (Da Huan), Zhao Yiwel (Father) and Pang Yan (Mother).

HEADLINE: 2 Japanese Insurance Giants Will Merge 

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 24 

 BODY:
Two big Japanese insurers, Meiji Life and Yasuda Mutual Life, said today that they would merge, creating Japan's third-largest life insurer, in a move to cut costs and bolster returns at a time when the Japanese economy is sour and interest rates are near zero.
 The combination, to be completed by April 2004, will yield a company with current combined assets of 27.7 trillion yen ($208 billion) in assets. It is the first between major life insurers in Japan (Meiji now ranks fourth and Yasuda sixth), but analysts said it would not be the last. 
 A change in regulations last year allowed insurance companies, banks and brokerage houses to enter one another's businesses, but before today's announcement the only significant deals in the insurance industry had been alliances between life insurers and property and casualty insurers. 
Japan is the world's largest life insurance market, with nearly $400 billion in annual premiums paid, about 20 percent more than the United States. But the population is aging, leading to rising payouts and falling premium revenue -- because many in-force policies are becoming fully paid up and fewer young people are coming along to buy new policies.
On top of that, the majority of policies guarantee their holders rates of return that are now well above prevailing interest rates, which on short-term debt are almost zero. In these conditions, insurers are hard pressed to make money.
Profits on the core policy business at both Meiji Life and Yasuda Mutual Life fell more than 20 percent in the first half of the current fiscal year, which ends March 31, compared with the prior period. 
To narrow the gap between their obligations to policyholders and their increasingly meager profits from investments, life insurers have cut the guaranteed return on new policies to 1.5 percent, and they may halve that rate again later this year. The lower returns have made the policies less attractive to Japanese consumers.
The insurers are barred from reducing the guaranteed returns on existing policies, however, so they must look elsewhere to cut costs. The two merger partners plan to consolidate computer systems and close about 15 percent of their combined network of 2,000 branches. Between them, they hope to save 41 billion yen ($310 million) in costs.
The two companies, which have not yet chosen a name for the new entity, plan to eliminate about 2,000 of their nearly 50,000 salesmen as they grapple with the core of their distribution network: armies of middle-aged housewives who sell policies door to door.
"With the economy globalizing and new businesses entering the insurance industry, we need higher standards and a healthier financial statement," said Mikihiko Miyamoto, president of Yasuda Mutual.
Though Meiji Life and Yasuda Mutual Life, which are both more than 120 years old, hope to reduce fixed costs through their merger, they are unlikely to bolster their investment returns while Japan's stock market remains in a funk and bond yields are near historic lows. Unrealized gains on stocks held by the country's largest insurers fell by half in the first half of the current fiscal year, as the benchmark Nikkei 225 stock index plunged 25 percent.
"The quality of their assets will remain a problem as long as they are exposed to the equity market and interest rates are so low," said Runa Ichihari, an insurance analyst at Standard & Poor's in Tokyo. "These problems will not be solved by mergers."
Still, Ms. Ichihari said, other insurance companies will probably follow with merger deals. Investor speculation is already swirling around Sumitomo Life Insurance and Mitsui Mutual Life Insurance, whose sister companies in banking and property insurance have already merged, creating Sumitomo Mitsui Bank Mitsui Sumitomo Insurance.
Several medium-size life insurers never got that chance; six have collapsed since 1999.
Japanese life insurance companies also compete for business against the post office, which offers a number of financial services including savings accounts and life insurance; its insurance division has 60 trillion yen ($450 billion) in assets. Unlike private insurers, the Postal Life Insurance program has an implied government guarantee, making its borrowing costs lower and allowing it to offer higher rates of return. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: ON STAGE AND OFF 

BYLINE:  By Jesse McKinley 

 BODY:
Lights Down, But Not Out
 As of today, fewer than half of Broadway's 38 Tony-eligible theaters are lit, a phenomenon that probably owes as much to the calendar as the state of the American theater. 
 January, of course, is always a tough month at the box office. For those shows that remain, however, many seem to be holding up, especially considering the dismal predictions after Sept. 11. Only one show, in fact, played to less than 70 percent capacity last week -- "Les Miserables" -- and its number was just a shade under. (Part of the high attendance, mind you, certainly had to do with Martin Luther King's Birthday and wintertime ticket offers.) Over all, attendance is down about 600,000 from the same period last year, while gross box office sales are off only about 5 percent. 
And more shows are coming; from the beginning of February to the end of April, 19 Broadway openings are planned.
Still, there are a handful of theaters available -- the Belasco, the Cort and the Richard Rodgers, among them -- and several producers are still considering bringing in productions before the deadline, including the current revival of Noel Coward's "Private Lives," a hit in Britain. (The rumored transfer of London's "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof," however, now looks unlikely.)
Of those producers, no one is busier than Elizabeth Ireland McCann. Ms. McCann, who is already producing Edward Albee's "Goat" and another play, "The Smell of the Kill," on Broadway this spring, said this week that she was considering bringing a third production: a revival of Herb Gardner's "I'm Not Rappaport." 
The production in question stars Judd Hirsch -- repeating his 1986 Tony-winning original role -- and Ben Vereen. The show originated at the Coconut Grove Playhouse in Florida, and is currently playing Ford's Theater in Washington, where Ms. McCann is traveling this weekend to check it out. The production is then scheduled to go to the Paper Mill Playhouse in New Jersey, ending there on March 24, which would conceivably allow it to open on Broadway before the Tony deadline.
As for "The Smell of the Kill," Ms. McCann and the director, Christopher Ashley, have found their cast: Claudia Shear ("Dirty Blonde"), Lisa Emery ("Dinner with Friends") and Jessica Stone ("Grease") will play a trio of malicious, delicious wives. The dark comedy, by Michele Lowe, is to open in March at the Helen Hayes. 

Final Curtain at Site
Even while dealing with the impact of the slumping economy and a harsh fund-raising environment, one major Off Broadway theater company is now facing an even more frightening prospect: eviction.
The MCC Theater Company's home on West 28th Street is where the 1999 Pulitzer winner "Wit" played and where the MCC Company has been in residence since 1992. But the company recently learned that its run in the flower district will come to an end this summer. The company, founded by the actor Robert LuPone and Bernard Telsey, the casting director, had recently entered into negotiations to renew its lease and believed a deal was set. 
But just before the company was to sign the new lease, the founders say, the deal was rescinded by the landlord. 
"We survived Sept. 11," Mr. LuPone said, "only to find ourselves out in the street." Calls to the landlord, Oday Realty, were not answered.
The company, which opens a new play, "Runt of the Litter," on Thursday, says it will begin a capital campaign to raise money for a new home.

Contract Talks
Actors Equity, the actors' and stage managers' union, began talks this week with Lincoln Center Theater and the Roundabout Theater Company over the prickly issue of those companies' LORT contracts.
What's a LORT? The acronym stands for League of Resident Theaters, an organization that includes about 80 of the nation's large nonprofit theaters. Broadway productions staged by commercial producers operate under the standard Broadway production contract, which guarantees actors a minimum of $1,252 a week. Nonprofit companies, however, like Lincoln Center Theater and Roundabout, operate under LORT agreements when they produce Broadway shows, which allows them to pay a lower rate; the minimum is $728 a week.
Both Lincoln Center and Roundabout own Broadway houses -- the Vivian Beaumont and the American Airlines, respectively -- that operate under LORT agreements. But both companies also sometimes produce shows in other Broadway theaters and use the same contract. Equity, however, feels they should use the standard production contract when away from home. 
Nonprofits generally argue that the LORT agreement is the only way they can do large productions, like the Roundabout's recent revival of "Follies," without breaking the bank.

And the Beat Went on
Tonight, at a little past 8 at the Imperial, the conductor will raise his baton and a little history will be made, as "Les Miserables," with 6,138 performances, becomes the second-longest-running musical in Broadway history, passing "A Chorus Line," and still chasing "Cats."
For eight musicians in the pit, it will be a very familiar tune because those eight -- David Gale, Pete Hyde, Brian Koonin, Batia Lieberman, Marion Pinheiro, John Rojak, Mitchell Weiss, and Robert Zottola -- have been with the show since it opened on March 12, 1987. 
"I had no idea it would be a life sentence," joked Mr. Zottola, 65, who plays the trumpet. "We expected if we were lucky we'd get a couple of years out of it. And we're still here."

Along the Way
*Billy Connolly, the Scottish comic and actor, will appear for one night only at Town Hall on Feb. 23. 
*Bill Irwin ("Fool Moon") will replace Bill Murray in "The Guys," a play by Anne Nelson about a fire captain who loses men on Sept. 11. The play, which stars Sigourney Weaver, runs from Tuesday through Feb. 9 at the Flea, 41 White Street, TriBeCa.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
EMC's Loss in 4th Quarter Was Not as Deep as Feared

BYLINE:  By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
To the delight of Wall Street, EMC, the data storage company that became a widely held technology bellwether during the 1990's, yesterday reported a narrower loss than expected in the last quarter of 2001 and projected a return to profitability as early as this spring.
 EMC, which is based in Hopkinton, Mass., said that it lost $70.2 million, or 3 cents a diluted share, on revenue of $1.51 billion in the quarter. The consensus expectation of analysts had been that it would lose 7 cents a share on sales of $1.31 billion. While the quarterly results were off sharply from a year ago, when EMC earned $562.9 million, or 25 cents a share, on revenue of $2.62 billion, they provided evidence that EMC was rebounding faster than expected from huge losses in the third quarter of last year. 
 EMC said it benefited from strong growth in business segments like storage gear linked together in networks, software and storage services. The company also had more savings than expected from cost-cutting measures. 
The company said that customers remained cautious about investing in information technology. It endorsed projections that overall spending would be flat or down slightly this year unless there was a strong economic recovery. But it said the parts of the technology business that EMC deals with had already begun to bounce back from levels that were depressed even before the uncertainty created by Sept. 11.
"The environment felt a little more like a normal business environment," said William Teuber, the chief financial officer, in a conference call with analysts before trading began yesterday.
Investors responded quickly, sending EMC's shares as high as $17.21 before they settled back to end at $16.83, up 16 percent from Wednesday's close.
"This is more of a story of EMC executing well than the information technology market really strengthening," said James Berlino, an analyst at Merrill Lynch. "The things that are in their control, they're controlling."
EMC said that it had completed nearly all of the domestic portion of the 4,000 job cuts it had announced in response to plunging sales last year. EMC said the cuts and other cost-saving measures saved it $157 million in the fourth quarter. 
EMC's projections of a 5 percent decline in revenue for the quarter, to $1.44 billion, are rosier than Wall Street's current estimate of $1.26 billion.
The company said that the improving business climate in the last three months was most evident in the growth of storage network equipment sales, up 52 percent from the previous quarter, and software, up 45 percent. 
Some analysts were particularly impressed with the assertion of Joseph Tucci, the company's president and chief executive, that EMC had achieved the results without resorting to discounting at the end of December to close pending sales.

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Are Now Near A 6-Month Low 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 

 BODY:
The number of workers filing new claims for state unemployment benefits fell last week to the lowest level in almost six months, the Labor Department reported today, a sign that companies are slowing the pace of dismissals.
 "We are getting near the end of the recession," said Steve Cochrane, senior economist at Economy.com in West Chester, Pa. 
Companies are "positioning themselves for the recovery." 
 Initial jobless claims fell by 15,000, to 376,000 in the week ended Saturday, from a revised 391,000 the week before, the report said. That is the lowest level since the last week of July, and compares with an average 456,000 weekly claims filed in the final three months of 2001.
Analysts had expected that jobless claims would rise to 395,000 last week.
Reductions in initial claims are one of the first signs that a recession may be drawing to a close.
The four-week moving average of unemployment benefit claims, a less volatile indicator, fell to 404,250 last week, the lowest level since the week ended Sept. 1, from 413,000, the Labor Department said.
The number of people continuing to collect jobless benefits fell in the week ended Jan. 12 to 3.46 million -- the lowest since the week ended Sept. 22 -- from 3.51 million the previous week. That decline suggested that hiring may be starting to pick up in expectation of increased demand.

HEADLINE: Health Improves, but Racial Disparities Remain 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Jan. 24 

 BODY:
Americans made advances against a wide variety of diseases and other health threats in the 1990's, but glaring racial and ethnic disparities remain, the government reported today.
 The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention looked at 17 "health indicators," including infant mortality, suicide and stroke, that were broken down into racial and ethnic groups. 
 For all but one of the indicators -- low birth weight -- the statistics improved for the population as a whole. The death rate dropped 9 percent for stroke, 15 percent for car accidents and more than 28 percent for homicides. Syphilis was down more than 80 percent, to fewer than 3 cases per 100,000 people in 1998. 
The percentage of babies with low birth weight rose to 7.6 percent in 1998, from 7 percent in 1990.
But while the indicators for racial and ethnic minorities also improved in the 1990's, the numbers for whites tended to improve faster.
From 1990 to 1998, for example, the breast cancer death rate fell 4 percent among black women and 13 percent among Hispanic women. For white women, it fell 18 percent.
Among the other gaps were the rate of tuberculosis, 8 times as high for blacks and 6 times as high for Hispanics as for whites; homicide, 10 times as high for blacks and 4 times as high for Hispanics; and syphilis, more than 30 times as high for blacks and 3 times as high for Hispanics.
"In many ways, Americans of all ages and in every racial and ethnic group have better health today," Surgeon General David Satcher said. "But our work isn't done until all infants have the same chance to thrive, all mothers have equal access to prenatal care, and all Americans are equally protected from cancer, heart disease and stroke."
Researchers said the reasons for the gaps were different for each indicator and even for different parts of the country. "Certainly some are due to social and economic factors, and others behavioral factors," said Ken Kettel, a statistician at the centers.
The centers also reported that death rates from lung, breast, colorectal and prostate cancer fell during the 1990's, though not as much for blacks as for whites. Researchers credited less smoking and early detection, though they urged more study to figure out why prostate cancer deaths dropped.

PERSON: Amanda M. Burden 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
Planning Chief Tries to Rub Off the Socialite Tag

BYLINE:  By ROBIN FINN 

 BODY:
AMANDA M. BURDEN, a compulsive civil servant cursed -- at least she thinks so -- by the lissome looks, banner breeding and bank account of a socialite, extends a cool, unadorned hand that, like the rest of her, seems made of filigree, not flesh. 
 She apologizes for the sniffles muddying her Hepburn-esque diction: picture Audrey wearing a honey-blond ponytail and a simple black Calvin Klein pantsuit and, voila, you have Ms. Burden, New York City's earnest and elegant new director of the Department of City Planning and chairwoman of its Planning Commission. She has a cold; she's toughing it out. Not for her to miss work, not now that she has the clout to transform this lackluster commission from "more of a regulatory body" to a proactive dynamo in its chairwoman's image. 
 "I've always had this fanatical need to make a contribution, and I've always had a desire to build something permanent," she says. "This is the opportunity of a lifetime for me. The chairman sets the agenda for what can and should happen in the city, and articulates it, and that's what I know I can do." As director, she runs a department of 230.
Two jobs at one respectable salary: $162,800. Two roles that Ms. Burden, who repeatedly refers to herself as "a child of the 60's" deeply affected by John F. Kennedy's "ask not" speech, expects to be pivotal now that the city has been forced to resurrect itself, architecturally and economically, from the ravages of Sept. 11. First on the docket is the rebuilding of downtown to make it competitive with the rest of the city and make it a multi-use, multifaceted neighborhood. 
Ms. Burden hails from the "make no small plans" school and deviates from standard planner playbooks in that her goal isn't just producing the proper plan, but also seeing it materialize. Like tiny Paley Park, her first project, and one with family ties. And Battery Park City's esplanade. 
Her other qualifications include a master's degree in urban planning from Columbia University, where her thesis on recycling urban garbage won the program's top award; a stint with the Urban Development Corporation; and a mentor in the urbanologist William H. Whyte, who taught her that a city's true lifeblood is in the vitality of its streets and public spaces. 
So why do the media persist in labeling her a socialite as it chronicles her table-hopping on the arm of Charlie Rose, the television personality she's been seeing for a decade (her only other significant other is her pug, Minnie)?
An ominous scowl crosses her face: "It's horrible, really, the socialite thing; it's like some kind of tattoo you can't rub off."
She was not born to shop (waste of time). Or decorate her Upper East Side digs to death (dull), though she does confess an addiction to transplanting shrubs at her weekend spot in the Catskills and at Mr. Rose's place in Bellport, Long Island. She never tried to be a chip off the old block, which in her case would have meant making a career of being unbearably beautiful. "I didn't have the talent for that," she says through clenched teeth. Since talking about her famously fashionable mother, Babe Paley, tends to be a white-knuckle experience for her, better to tackle it later.
SHE pours water into a plastic cup to chase down the grilled cheese sandwich she bolted at her desk between the wall-to-wall meetings she's been attending since her promotion after 12 years as a commission member. Then she shuts the door of her big bland office at 22 Reade Street -- she lost weight worrying whether Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg would make it hers -- and tucks herself into a corner of a worn brown leather sofa. She does not take up much space. 
As for decorating this space, forget about it. She did put up a skyline sketch of Battery Park, homage to her most influential job, before this one, as vice president for planning and design of the Battery Park City Authority. "When we got there in 1983, there was nothing except sand."
On the corner table are a smattering of family photos and a timely birthday present (she turned 58 last week): a silver-framed shot of her with the mayor just after her coronation at City Hall. She says she and he are on the same page on "conveying a sense of the fantastic possibilities for the future of this city" and getting it to a place where "tragedy becomes opportunity."
Ms. Burden was raised by a series of nannies in a silver-spoon setting on Long Island's Gold Coast. William S. Paley, the CBS magnate, became her stepfather when she was 3. (Her father was Stanley Mortimer, the Standard Oil heir.) She and her mother were not close. "She kept her distance," she says. "She was just incredibly beautiful, so always perfect." It was Babe Paley's mission to be the most beautiful woman in every room she entered, but that room rarely contained her children.
Ms. Burden escaped to boarding school at 14 and never went back home. At 18, she became engaged to Carter Burden, owner of The Village Voice and New York magazine, and left Wellesley to marry him, have two children and assist in his successful campaign for City Council. They divorced in 1972 but stayed friendly. 
In 1976, she finished her undergraduate studies at Sarah Lawrence, and in 1980 she married Steve Ross, the Warner Communications czar; their divorce, 16 months later, was the antithesis of friendly. Did it sour her on marriage? "Yep," she says, sounding not a bit like a socialite.

PERSON: Pierre Bourdieu 

HEADLINE: Pierre Bourdieu, 71, French Thinker and Globalization Critic 

BYLINE:  By ALAN RIDING 

DATELINE: PARIS, Jan. 24 

 BODY:
Pierre Bourdieu, a leading French sociologist and maverick intellectual who emerged as a public figure here in the 1990's by championing the antiglobalization movement and other antiestablishment causes, died in a Paris hospital on Wednesday. He was 71.
 The cause was cancer, friends said. 
 The author of 25 books, many translated into English, Mr. Bourdieu was particularly interested in exploring the formative roots of class distinctions and power structures. He applied his theories to a broad range of topics, including education, television, masculinity, intellectuals, the media, language and poverty. 
While his influence has long been felt in academic circles in France and the United States, Mr. Bourdieu assumed a public role in the tradition of Emile Zola and Jean-Paul Sartre only in the last decade, when he became what Le Monde called "the intellectual reference" for movements opposed to free market orthodoxy and globalization.
In the process, he also turned his guns on television talk-show hosts for delivering "cultural fast food" and on many fellow intellectuals whom he accused of abusing their privileged status in France by opining on issues about which they knew little. Counterattacks by intellectuals like Alain Finkelkraut and BernardHenry Levi ensured that he remained in the public eye. Some critics said that he had grown increasingly sectarian in recent years. 
Yet while he described his political position as "to the left of the left," meaning that he considered the Socialist Party to have sold out, he stood at the heart of France's intellectual establishment. He held the chair of sociology at the College de France, an elite government-backed think tank, he taught at the Ecole des Hautes Etudes en Sciences Sociales and he edited a sociology journal.
One measure of his iconoclastic renown in France was that the report of his death was the lead story in Le Monde. Prime Minister Lionel Jospin, himself a Socialist, described Mr. Bourdieu as a master of contemporary sociology and said that "his works made him the leader of a school of thought that applied incisive criticism to the capitalist society."
One of Mr. Bourdieu's central theses was that social and cultural breeding were critical to achieving status and power, but his own life's story suggested that, at least for some, France could work as a meritocracy.
Born on Aug. 1, 1930, in Denguin in the foothills of the Pyrenees, Mr. Bourdieu had a peasant farmer-turned-postman as a father. Gascon, now a moribund regional dialect, was spoken at home. Young Pierre nonetheless proved a bright student, attending the region's best high school before gaining entrance to the Ecole Normale Superieure in Paris, the traditional cradle of French intellectuals, where he studied philosophy before turning to sociology. 
Although he graduated at the top of his class, he felt something of an outsider as a poor man surrounded by children of the French elite, and that feeling continued even as he became part of the French intelligentsia. "A lot of what I've done has been in reaction to the Ecole Normale," he said in an interview with The New York Times a year ago. "I think if I hadn't become a sociologist, I would have become very anti-intellectual. I was horrified by that world."
Beginning in 1958 he taught for two years at the University of Algiers just as the Algerian war for independence from France was gaining momentum. From this experience emerged his first book, "The Sociology of Algeria." After returning to France to teach in Lille and Paris, he married the former Marie-Claire Brisard in 1962. She and their children, Jerome, Emmanuel and Laurent, survive him.
Later, while assuming an ever more prominent role as a sociology teacher, he stepped up the pace of his publications. "Distinction: A Social Critique of the Judgment of Taste," published in France in 1979 and in the United States in 1984, was named one of the 20th century's 10 most important works of sociology by the International Sociological Association. Among his other influential works are "State Nobility: Elite Schools in the Field of Power," "Homo Academicus," "Pascalian Meditations," "On Television" and "The Weight of the World: Social Suffering in Contemporary Societies," which he edited.
A soft-spoken man who seemed to enjoy provoking other intellectuals, Mr. Bourdieu had a fatalistic view of the social and economic possibilities available to most people, believing that they entered adulthood with the experiences that would determine their success or failure. "The point of my work is to show that culture and education aren't simply hobbies or minor influences," he told The Times. "They are hugely important in the affirmation of differences between groups and social classes and in the reproduction of those differences."
Persuaded that most people in France did not have a fair chance to rise in society, he came to favor the underdog, above all those fighting against perceived injustices wrought by unfettered capitalism. 
Among those whom he supported was Jose Bove, who gained fame in 1999 by leading small farmers in France on an attack against McDonald's. Today, Mr. Bove was among those remembering Mr. Bourdieu warmly. "For him," Mr. Bove said, "life itself was a commitment."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Pierre Bourdieu in 1998. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Dust Stirs Worry in Tour of a Shuttered School 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT F. WORTH 

 BODY:
When a group of teachers from the High School of Economics and Finance went back to tour their shuttered school next to the World Trade Center site, city officials assured them that it had been thoroughly cleaned. The building, which is closer than any other school to ground zero, has been closed since the terrorist attacks and is scheduled to reopen Jan. 30.
 But as the teachers began walking the halls on Tuesday, they found a thick layer of dust in the faculty lounge and in one of the elevators. Worried that the dust might be toxic, a union official who accompanied them promptly declared the building unsafe, and now many teachers and parents say they will not return until they are sure that the building has been adequately cleaned. 
 "We listened for two hours while they told us the place was spotless," said Scott Shaffner, one of the teachers who was present on the tour, organized by the United Federation of Teachers. "Then I touched the ceiling duct of one of the elevators, and my hand came out black -- like tar.
"The feeling was, they weren't being up front, and it makes you wonder what else wasn't done," Mr. Shaffner said.
Last night more than 100 students, teachers, parents, and officials from the New York City Board of Education met at the school, at 100 Trinity Place, to discuss safety issues and hear from environmental experts. 
Bernard Orlan, the board's director for health and safety, said the dust remaining in the school is not a safety hazard. The building, which was occupied by the city's Office of Emergency Management in the months after the Sept. 11 attacks, was given a thorough environmental cleaning in December and January, he said. The air was then tested inside and outside the building and found to be safe. The problem, he said, arose when repairs were made to the school's ventilation system and old but harmless dust spread into the air.
"Basically the building is dirty but not environmentally unsafe," said Margie Feinberg, a spokeswoman for the Board of Education. It is being cleaned now to eliminate surface dirt, she added.
Neil Feldscher, a spokesman for Emteque Corp., the environmental firm hired by the school's parent-teacher association, said he conducted tests in the building yesterday but had not collected enough information to make a final judgment.
Students at the school, which was founded in 1993 and specializes in preparing students for careers in finance, have been sharing space at Norman Thomas High School, at 33rd Street and Park Avenue, since Sept. 11. But some parents have moved their children to other schools. The enrollment at Economics and Finance is now 628, about 100 less than it was at the start of the school year, Ms. Feinberg said.
Altogether, five school buildings in the area remain closed, with their students attending classes elsewhere: the High School of Economics and Finance and the High School for Leadership and Public Service at 90 Trinity Place, which are scheduled to reopen Jan. 30, and Public Schools 89, 234 and 150, which are scheduled to reopen Feb. 4, Ms. Feinberg said.

HEADLINE: Paterson's Mayor Indicted On Charges of Trading City Contracts for Gifts 

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Jan. 24 

 BODY:
The mayor of Paterson was indicted today on federal charges of taking cash, gifts, 14 vacation trips, home improvements and payments for "female companionship" from city vendors in return for contracts.
 The 40-count indictment against the mayor, Martin G. Barnes, grew out of a nearly two-year investigation of the activities of United Gunite, a sewer repair and paving contractor operating in Paterson and several other New Jersey cities. Top company officials pleaded guilty last year to bribing unnamed municipal officials in the region and have been cooperating with prosecutors. 
 The indictment comes just 10 days after Mr. Barnes announced that he would seek re-election in May. A popular Republican, Mr. Barnes, 53, has been the mayor of New Jersey's third-largest city since he was appointed to fill a vacancy in 1997. He was elected to an interim term that fall and, without major opposition, to a full term in 1998. 
But at a news conference at his office here, Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney for New Jersey, said the many gifts that Mr. Barnes is accused of accepting from city contractors showed him to be "a mayor more interested in serving himself than serving the people." 
Mr. Christie said that in addition to soliciting thousands of dollars' worth of trips and other gifts for himself and his wife and girlfriends, the mayor siphoned $20,000 from his campaign fund to pay a girlfriend's expenses, filed false tax returns and sought city reimbursement for nonbusiness travel. He is also accused of defrauding the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development of $29,000 in grant money, in a scheme to renovate a building he owned.
Because of the long investigation and the guilty pleas from United Gunite officials, today's indictment came as no surprise to Mr. Barnes, said his lawyer, Jack Arseneault, who has been monitoring the work of the grand jury. Mr. Arseneault said his client denied the charges, which he believed grew out of attempts by a United Gunite official, Gerald David Free, to win leniency at sentencing on other federal bribery charges. He called Mr. Free, a former close friend of Mr. Barnes's, an "admitted con man."
"I am conceding that on some occasions he did accept gifts from Gerry Free," Mr. Arseneault said. "But you will be hard pressed to find anything other than personal connections there, and there is nothing in any of it that is beneficial for the company and detrimental to the city."
If convicted of the most serious charges, Mayor Barnes could face up to 20 years in prison. Under an agreement with the United States attorney's office, Mr. Barnes is scheduled to surrender to Federal Bureau of Investigation agents in the next two days for his first court appearance.
The indictment also came as no surprise to members of the Paterson City Council, who have raised questions publicly about the mayor's frequent travel and the absence of competition for some lucrative city contracts in the last year.
"It all began to shed a bad light on the city," said Councilman William Kline, referring to the claims by United Gunite executives that they had bribed unnamed Paterson officials. "What they were saying contradicted what the mayor was saying to us, and we were asking questions and trying to do whatever we could do to uplift the city."
Aslon Goow, a member of the Council and longtime critic of Mayor Barnes, said that in the last year he and others thought they could not trust the mayor, who had long refused to meet with them to discuss his policies and initiatives. 
"I think this is a sad day for Paterson," Mr. Goow said.
Bob Grant, a spokesman for Mayor Barnes, who is black, said that with the indictment the mayor "joins a lengthening list of African-Americans who have come under scrutiny since being elected to office."
But Mr. Christie, the prosecutor, insisted that race had played no role in this or any other corruption inquiry by his office.
Mr. Christie said, "Millions of dollars in city contracts" were secured for companies who agreed to "join the Barnes Team" -- the words he said the mayor used. "Whatever his whim was, he was going to get them to pay for it." 
The 49-page indictment indeed reads like a primer for conspicuous consumption, alleging that Mr. Barnes pressured various unnamed contractors to finance trips to Washington; Nashville; Louisville, Ky.; Rio de Janeiro; Aruba; and to a castle in Bristol, England. Some of the trips were taken with his wife, according to the indictment, while others were taken with various girlfriends.
The six-day trip to Rio de Janeiro was taken by Mr. Barnes alone, said Mr. Christie, who added that the mayor then importuned the contractor who was paying the bills to arrange for female companionship for him when he arrived. When asked, the prosecutor would not characterize the companion as a prostitute.
On another occasion, according to the indictment, Mr. Barnes had a contractor build a swimming pool with a waterfall in his backyard.

HEADLINE: Layoffs Start In New Jersey As Towns Brace for Cuts 

BYLINE:  By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 24 

 BODY:
Even during his campaign for governor, James E. McGreevey warned New Jerseyans that a yawning budget deficit would cause pain. Now, as governor, he has begun to inflict it.
 So from state government employees to local governments, the question today was where his knife would cut the deepest. 
 About 600 state employees, most of them in technical jobs outside Civil Service protection, ended their day Wednesday with brusque notices saying they were laid off. In the process, Mr. McGreevey eliminated the Office of State Planning, headquarters for the state's nationally recognized efforts to control sprawl. 
And that may be just the start. His staff has also put already nervous Civil Service unions on notice by warning that some layoffs of regular employees, of the kind that roiled the state under Gov. Jim Florio a dozen years ago, may also be coming.
And Mr. McGreevey has told New Jersey's towns and municipalities, where costs have been rising steadily, that their nearly automatic annual increases in state aid are a thing of the past, and that they will get no increase for the new budgets many of them have just begun to draw up.
The new governor, who took office on the 15th, has put some of the blame for the state's budget problems on his Republican predecessor, the former acting governor Donald T. DiFrancesco. Some Democratic officials went out of their way today to pin the impending pain on the Republicans, and Governor McGreevey himself declared that he would stir a political hornet's nest by auditing, and perhaps trying to reopen, the $500 million, seven-year contract the departed Republican administration signed in 1998 with Parsons Infrastructure and Technology Group to operate New Jersey's auto emissions testing program.
At the end of the day today, many of the men and women who had been laid off were cleaning out their desks and hoping that their jobs might yet be saved. After all, they said, the 600 jobs that were cut would save only about $25 million according to the governor's own calculation. Of that, the 27 people in the Office of State Planning accounted for only about $2 million of the $2.8 billion budget shortfall Mr. McGreevey has said he must erase.
"Everybody was shocked," said Kathleen Bird, who had been the spokeswoman for the planning office. Like the others, she received a letter telling her that her "duties and obligation to report to work cease immediately" and that she would get two weeks' severance pay. Some of her colleagues wept, Ms. Bird said, and others were simply numb.
In a note of concern, champions of managing the state's rapid growth added that the cost in sprawl could be much greater if the planning office is left vacant.
"What McGreevey said was that these people are expendable, they're unnecessary or they're political hires," said Barbara Lawrence, executive director of New Jersey Future, a controlled-growth advocacy group. "But in the case of the Office of State Planning we are losing the best professionals you can hire. They are the brains behind the concept of smart growth in New Jersey."
Mayors and managers of New Jersey's more than 500 municipalities have been left scratching their heads over the impact of Governor McGreevey's freeze in municipal aid, which towns and cities apply to abating their high property taxes. Officials in several wealthy towns said today that Mr. McGreevey's ample warning of a budget crisis prepared them to expect no additional help. But for large cities, where state aid accounts for a disproportionate share of municipal revenues, the prospect of a freeze brought a sense of foreboding.
New Brunswick, for example, had been counting on a 3 percent annual increase to keep up with inflation, said Thomas Loughlin, the city administrator. A freeze would amount to $510,000 lost, he said. "We're going to feel the impact here, there's no question of that."
Eric Maurer, business administrator for Morristown, was among the town officials who said they were in the dark about the impact of the governor's freeze in state aid levels. "We're operating in an information vacuum," he said.
Mr. Maurer said officials from the previous administration had promised Morristown a $100,000 increase in state aid, to $3.8 million. The town is already planning to raise the tax rate by an amount equal to $180 for a typical $200,000 home, he said. If state aid is frozen at the current $3.7 million aid level, that tax increase will grow by an additional $16.
In Newark, Mayor Sharpe James said his city received about a quarter of its $432 million budget from Trenton, but he did not know how much it would be hurt. "Recognizing the budget crunch, all of us have to share in that pain," he said.
A spokesman for Parsons Group said that it was ready to work with the new governor in examining the state's auto emissions testing contract, but that the engineering company was not prepared to reopen the contract, as Mr. McGreevey had suggested. Matching the discussion of the state's budget problems, Parsons seemed prepared to do the same as the newly empowered Democrats: blame the departed Republicans.
"We welcome the opportunity to work with the McGreevey administration to show how effective the system has been for New Jersey motorists," said Bob Sommer, the spokesman. "We could not agree with him more that some of the previous administration's contract specifications and a condensed time frame were the cause of many of the start-up problems, and they bear further review."

HEADLINE: Hoping for Calm, Preparing For Strife at Economic Talks 

BYLINE:  By AL BAKER 

 BODY:
Even many of the veterans of wild protest melees at Seattle and Genoa say there would be something unseemly about violent protests in New York, still healing from the wounds of Sept. 11, when the World Economic Forum starts meeting next week.
 Despite efforts to keep demonstrations under control, both the police and demonstrators say there is no way to be certain what will happen if, as expected, thousands of demonstrators arrive in New York to protest the policies of the world's industrial leaders. Although most of the opponents of global capitalism say they are committed to nonviolent protest, others are planning to turn out in helmets and riot gear and some are expecting that some property damage could be a part of the street activities. 
 About 3,000 leaders of corporations and governments as well as academic, religious and cultural figures will be at the meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria in Midtown Manhattan from Thursday to Feb. 4, discussing topics as varied as economic growth, foreign policy, the role of the chief corporate executive and what gastronomy can reveal about foreign cultures. 
The meeting, moved to New York from its longtime home in Davos, Switzerland, after the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, has historically given corporation executives a chance to sit down with government officials behind closed doors -- for the price of a very expensive ticket. 
The protesters, who include mainstream student and union groups and more radical elements, plan street demonstrations focusing on such issues as declaring war on poverty, racism and mass layoffs, workers' rights and ways to reduce world debt.
Students interviewed in New York insisted that they were not planning to confront the police directly or to crash through barricades. Instead, they said, they will use less radical tactics than those used in Genoa, Italy, last summer, when one protester was killed during an economic summit meeting. 
Some also said they thought it was more important to demonstrate opposition to economic globalization than to ensure that public activities are subdued as a sign of respect for the losses of Sept. 11. 
"If the movement can orchestrate a significant show of force in New York City right now," one student said, "we can show the world that we can do it anywhere, anytime."
As Larry Holmes, a spokesman for the International Action Center, one of the groups expected, said yesterday, "We're back after 9/11, more sure of our cause."
Many protest organizers feel that the World Economic Forum, more than the World Trade Organization or the economic meeting of industrialized nations called the Group of Eight, is a more appropriate target for protests against global capitalism because it consists largely of corporate representatives and is not, at its core, a meeting of governments.
The protesters' groups, formed out of the labor, student and environmental movements, have names like the Workers Democracy Network, War Is Not the Answer Coalition and the First Quarter Storm Movement.
Protesters say the nature of the demonstrations will be shaped by the nature of the police response.
"A current concern that we are facing now, as we prepare to voice our concerns in the streets, is that we are not sure what type of police-enforced climate we are walking into," said Yvonne Liu, a Columbia University junior from Bayside, Queens, who is among the organizers of Students for Global Justice, a group formed in mid-December.
The police are also keenly aware of the public relations implications of the event. "Hopefully, we will not have to arrest anybody," said the new police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly. "We recognize everyone's right to demonstrate peacefully, and we are going to do everything we can to see that that happens." 
The World Economic Forum's usual meeting place, in Davos, does not attract the kind of attention that it is expected to draw in New York. This year, said the organization's spokesman, Charles D. McLean, in his headquarters in Geneva, reporters' requests for access to this meeting exceeded all others in the group's 32 years.
"Last year we accredited 500 journalists," Mr. McLean said. "This year we've had thousands of requests, and we can still only accommodate a fraction of those who want to attend. It's going to be shoulder to shoulder."
Because of that, and because of the aftermath of Sept. 11, many protesters said they did not expect unrest other than textbook forms of civil disobedience. 
They added that only a very slim minority of people, perhaps 200 in a group of several thousand, would ever condone property damage. 
"Basically, the general feeling among most people is that this is not the moment for that," said David R. Graeber, an assistant professor of anthropology at Yale University, who is a member of the New York Direct Action Network and Another World Is Possible, an umbrella organization for many groups.
"A lot of people have said they think that would be terribly inappropriate because it would be insensitive and disrespectful to people in the city and to protesters who come from the city," Dr. Graeber said. 
He said past experience showed that any window-breakers in the crowd would not attack independent owner-operators. "Never a cafe of a small businessman," he said, adding that he has never damaged any property. He added that the past also showed that violence was more likely to be directed at large coporations: "Citibank? Sure. Starbucks? Sure. But never anyone who is actually going to be hurt by that."
People in law enforcement who have seen globalization protests said the demonstrators were organized and in some cases used diversions to enable them to cause disruptions or mar property elsewhere. The protesters, though, blame law enforcement for scuffles. 
In New York, some of the demonstrators will use props to create a sort of street theater "for a festive kind of atmosphere that will get across the kind of world we like to see" instead of the world that the economic forum "and the groups that it is influential with are trying to create," said Eric Laursen, a member of Another World Is Possible.
Dr. Graeber said the protesters would use such props as giant cardboard depictions of corn (as a representation of life to many of New York City's Hispanic immigrants) or top hats and champagne glasses (as a representation of affluent excess). 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Police officers practiced crowd control tactics last week at Shea Stadium in Queens, preparing for a meeting in New York next week of the World Economic Forum. (Angel Franco/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
TROUBLES IN ARGENTINA TO REDUCE EARNINGS AT DIAL

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
 The Dial Corporation said yesterday that the devaluation of the peso in Argentina, the company's biggest international market, would reduce earnings this quarter. Dial said it might have to write off the value of at least some of its $44.7 million in good will, the premium paid above assets, for acquisitions made in Argentina. The company plans to cut marketing, manufacturing and administrative expenses sharply in Argentina, where it gets about 7 percent of its sales. Dial, the maker of soap, Armour Star canned meat and Renuzit air fresheners, put itself up for sale in August. Shares of Dial, based in Scottsdale, Ariz., fell 74 cents, or 4 percent, to $15.76.

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Falls 

BYLINE:  By Ken Belson (NYT) 

 BODY:
 Japan's merchandise trade surplus fell to an 18-year low in 2001 as the recession in the United States hurt exports of electronics and other high-technology equipment. 
Japan's surplus stood at 6.6 trillion yen ($50 billion) last year, 38 percent lower than in 2000. The surplus has declined over the last decade as manufacturers have moved some production overseas, where costs are lower. Total export volume, which removes changes in exchange rates, fell 15 percent, the 12th straight decline. Ken Belson (NYT)

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; 
Analyzing the Cultural Collision That Gave Rise to Sept. 11

BYLINE:  By SERGE SCHMEMANN

 BODY:
WHAT WENT WRONG?
Western Impact and Middle Eastern Response
By Bernard Lewis
180 pages. Oxford University Press. $23.
 One of the first and most troubling questions to arise after Sept. 11 was whether Osama bin Laden represented a fanatical aberration of an otherwise humane and tolerant faith or whether he was the cutting edge of a dangerous and swelling sentiment in Islam. The question revealed a considerable ignorance about Islam in America and placed a high premium on those few with genuine expertise in the field. 
 Bernard Lewis, an 85-year-old retired professor of Near Eastern studies at Princeton and a wartime British intelligence officer (he describes it as a period when he was "otherwise engaged"), was among those who came to the fore. His books were sought out; his essays in The New Yorker and The Atlantic Monthly were widely cited; he appeared on "Meet the Press" and "Charlie Rose." So it is not surprising that a new book by Mr. Lewis with the enticing title "What Went Wrong?" would raise high expectations.
The title is certainly provocative, suggesting as a starting point a general agreement that something has gone amiss in the Islamic civilization, at least in its reaction to the impact of the Judeo-Christian West. But this has been Mr. Lewis's basic premise for some time. His fundamental argument is that Muslims became accustomed in the early centuries of their history to perceiving themselves as the bearers of the final and true faith, and so never came to understand or accept the Christian civilization of Western Europe that he maintains has surpassed and humbled them.
The shock of Western ascendancy has led, in our time, to two responses: emulating the West and its secular culture or returning to the fundamentals of the faith -- the path whose most extreme manifestation is Mr. bin Laden. This, Mr. Lewis wrote in 1990 in a celebrated essay in The Atlantic Monthly (which introduced the catch phrase the political scientist Samuel P. Huntington then made famous) "is no less than a clash of civilizations -- the perhaps irrational but surely historic reaction of an ancient rival against our Judeo-Christian heritage, our secular present and the worldwide expansion of both."
"What Went Wrong?" explores the various aspects and consequences of this cultural collision -- military, social, cultural, governmental -- usually with the conclusion that even in those rare instances when Islam overcame its fundamental resistance to learning from the infidel, it was for a specific and limited purpose, generally military.
In other words, Westernization, even when it happened, did not lead to modernization. Simply agreeing to send students to Europe, Mr. Lewis writes, was a radical act: "It is difficult for a Westerner to appreciate the magnitude of this change, in a society accustomed to despise the infidel barbarians beyond the frontiers of civilization. Even traveling abroad was suspect; the idea of studying under infidel teachers was inconceivable." 
Not surprisingly, assertions like that have attracted no little controversy. Mr. Lewis has been accused of too Eurocentric an approach, of creating a justification for European imperialism, of taking too narrow a view of Islam. There is no doubt that he eschews relativism, from the title of his book to affirmations like this: "By all the standards that matter in the modern world -- economic development and job creation, literacy and educational and scientific achievement, political freedom and respect for human rights -- what was once a mighty civilization has indeed fallen low."
But such certainty only raises expectations that "What Went Wrong?" will take the case forward. Unfortunately, the volume is in fact a few steps behind. In the preface, Mr. Lewis acknowledges that the book was already in page proof on Sept. 11, so it does not deal with the terrorist attacks. But the more important disclosure is reserved for the Afterword, where Mr. Lewis confirms what the reader already suspects, that the book is really a compilation of lectures and articles dating from 1980 to 1999.
That does not mean that they are uninformative or uninteresting. There are fascinating riffs on the profound and fateful differences between the cultures of Islam and Christendom, from fundamental differences in the understanding of relations between church and state to more subtle contrasts in perception of time, literature, authority and identity.
"For traditional Muslims," Mr. Lewis writes, "the converse of tyranny was not liberty but justice. Justice in this context meant essentially two things, that the ruler was there by right and not by usurpation, and that he governed according to God's law, or at least according to recognizable moral and legal principles." 
In his chapter "Time, Space and Modernity," Mr. Lewis advances the provocative notion that one of the central elements of Western progress is the prevalence of poly phony -- not only as many voices proceeding harmoniously in music, but also as a capacity for complex interaction in sports, literature, science and ultimately politics. In Islamic civilization, he argues, the long absence of a precise measurement of time has precluded this critical synchronization.
These are certainly intriguing concepts to chew on as we seek to comprehend the world from which the suicide pilots came to do us such extraordinary damage. But they do not quite satisfy expectations. For one thing, this slim, 180-page volume never really overcomes the feel of old lectures. There is a lot of repetition, a lot of reference to old texts and a lot of generalization of the sort that may be acceptable in a lecture but is frustrating in a book whose title promises convincing answers to the riddles of Sept. 11. 
It is especially difficult to accept that so vast and complex a portion of the world could be reduced to a fairly homogeneous historic force. Mr. Lewis often seems to treat the Ottoman Empire as a template for the entire Muslim civilization, drawing broad conclusions about all Muslims from Turkish examples even as he writes elsewhere of the ancient differences and great rivalries among Turks, Persians, Arabs and other Islamic nations.
Similarly, some of Mr. Lewis's conclusions simply long for more evidence, like the civilizing role of polyphony. Is its absence really all that great a handicap? And if it is, why did it not afflict Far Eastern nations with different musical or organizational traditions? It's an enticing notion, but not convincing.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bernard Lewis (Denise Applewhite/Oxford University Press)
