HEADLINE: GROUND ZERO: FEDERAL AID; 
Pataki Asks To Oversee 9/11 Aid

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 25 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki has asked the State Legislature to give him the authority to oversee about $10 billion worth of federal aid that he expects to flow to the state to repair the damage done by terrorists, but legislative leaders are balking at the governor's request.
 The request is part of an $11.2 billion supplementary budget bill intended to fill holes and gaps in the state's spending plan for the fiscal year ending on April 1. The bill also contains $200 million to bolster security, $125 million for environmental programs and $287 million to cover a shortfall in the state's Medicaid program. But a fight is brewing over the governor's proposal that he be given the blanket authority to distribute up to $10 billion in federal aid for Lower Manhattan. 
 Congress has already approved more than $10 billion to help the state recover from Sept. 11, but very little of that money has been delivered to Albany yet. Once it arrives, the governor may not spend it without legislative approval. In essence, he is asking the Legislature for that approval in advance. 
Even though much of the aid expected to flow from Washington has been earmarked for specific purposes, legislative leaders in the State Assembly and Senate are reluctant to give Mr. Pataki complete control over such a large amount of aid, in advance, without seeing the details.
"I want to see, before we sign off on a blank check, what the purposes are for this money, how we are using it," said Sheldon Silver, the Assembly speaker, a Democrat who by coincidence represents the neighborhood hardest hit by the attacks.
A spokesman for Senate Majority Leader Joseph L. Bruno said the Republicans who control the Senate are also unlikely to support giving Mr. Pataki, who is also a Republican, the final word on the use of federal aid. "We would want to have a say in how those funds are directed," said the spokesman, John McArdle. "For any appropriation along these lines, it's appropriate for the Legislature to review and have some input."
Mr. Pataki's budget officers, however, maintain that most of the $10.4 billion in aid for Manhattan that Congress has approved so far is strictly regulated. The governor holds little sway over how the money is spent, they argue.
Legislative leaders, however, say that not all of the money Congress has approved is restricted to paying for the cleanup and rebuilding of the infrastructure around the blocks destroyed when hijacked jets rammed the twin towers, causing their collapse. Some of the money comes in the form of housing block grants, for instance, which the governor and his economic development corporation would control.
The relief package that Congress approved included about $6.4 billion that was provided to the Federal Emergency Management Agency to reimburse the city for debris removal and rebuilding at the disaster site. That money passes through state coffers but Albany lawmakers cannot touch it.
But the federal package also contains about $2.7 billion in block grants to help businesses and residents in the area. Here, the governor has much more influence, legislative aides said. The rescue plan also contains $400 million for transportation projects, $140 million to help New York hospitals, $175 million for workers' compensation, and $120 million in loans from the Small Business Administration.
Kevin Quinn, a spokesman for Mr. Pataki's budget office, said Congress has already put guidelines on the use of most of these funds. 
"The vast majority of these funds are simply passed on to New York City to meet their rebuilding and recovery needs," he said.
But legislative leaders point out that they already gave Mr. Pataki the authority to distribute $5 billion in federal aid back in September, and only about $375 million in disaster aid has passed through the state to the city. Some lawmakers wonder why the governor needs the blanket authority to spend another $10 billion without legislative approval.
But Mr. Pataki's aides said having a lump-sum appropriation means the state can get the federal aid to New York faster. "This will allow us to get those funds to New York City in the most expedited way possible," Mr. Quinn said. "We don't want to do anything that would delay getting the money to New York City."

HEADLINE: New President of Trinity To Keep Hartford Focus 

BYLINE:  By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
Trinity College in Hartford has named Richard H. Hersh, the former president of Hobart and William Smith Colleges in upstate New York and a fervent advocate of liberal arts education, as its next president.
 Dr. Hersh, 59, who will take his new helm in April, succeeds Evan S. Dobelle, who won national attention for using the college's resources to spur urban renewal in the city. Mr. Dobelle left last July to become president of the University of Hawaii, and Ronald R. Thomas has been the acting president since then. 
 With Dr. Hersh's appointment, the trustees are signaling their desire not only to continue Mr. Dobelle's work but also to pay greater attention to the college itself and the education it offers. Under Mr. Dobelle, the goal was to try to improve the college's setting and turn it into a plus.
Trinity put more than $5 million of its own money into an urban renewal project called the Learning Corridor, which resulted in the opening of several new public schools for the city's children. The school also worked with government officials and private industry to make the streets safer, to make mortgages more available and to expand job training.
"We've worked real hard on improving the physical plant at Trinity and on the community surrounding it," said Thomas S. Johnson, chairman of the board at Trinity and the leader of the presidential search committee. "And we have worked real hard on Trinity's finances. It isn't a question of deviating from any of that, but of making sure that the richness of that experience gets built into the curriculum in a more cohesive way."
Dr. Hersh yesterday applauded Mr. Dobelle's leadership and reaffirmed the need for the college to continue its work with the community.
"We'll be involved every bit as much," he said. 
But he added that he would "do it in my own way," and suggested it would center more explicitly on the educational value of such involvement.
Most of Dr. Hersh's career has been spent in education: he earned a doctorate in education at Boston University, and then climbed the administrative ranks at a variety of colleges, including Harvard, Clark, Drake, the University of Toledo, the University of Oregon, and Hobart and William Smith.
But he pointed out that community involvement has been an important part of his life as well. He said he has worked on an urban teacher corps, with community groups fighting for fair housing and civil rights, and as a town selectman.
His primary passion is for liberal arts education, which he called the best and most practical education for the 21st century.
"We know that powerful feedback from caring adults is the most powerful form of teaching there is," he said.
The campus Dr. Hersh is joining is similar in many ways to the one he left. They are both small, co-ed, liberal arts colleges with fewer than 2,000 students, founded in the early 1820's. Trinity, however, sits in a more urban setting and has a more diverse and somewhat academically stronger student body. Its endowment is also bigger -- about $350 million. Under Dr. Hersh, Hobart's endowment grew from $26 million to $105 million and the campus revamped its curriculum, raised its admissions standards and retention rates and began to send more than half of its students overseas.
For Dr. Hersh, the new job is a lucky coincidence. He left Hobart and William Smith in 1999 after eight years as president because his wife, Judith Meyers, took a job in Connecticut and they did not want to have a commuting marriage. Since then he has worked on educational grants with the Christian A. Johnson Endeavor Foundation in New York City, and with the Council for Aid to Education on a project to measure how well students learn.

HEADLINE: He Plays Boswell In Storied Stadium; 
Yankees' Tour Guide Knows All And Worries About New Park

BYLINE:  By ALAN FEUER 

 BODY:
Tony Morante is a middle-aged man of average height and average weight with a graying mustache, wire-rimmed glasses and thinning light-brown hair. He is 59, has lived in the Bronx his entire life and his most extraordinary trait is knowing more about Yankee Stadium than any other person currently alive on Earth does.
 Mr. Morante is the stadium's tour guide -- a position created just for him in 1979. He is the official storyteller for what may be the most storied sports arena in the country. He has led, by his own account, more than 10,000 tours of the famous ballpark and can provide, without the slightest hint of effort, an exhaustive 15-minute lecture on the locker room alone. 
 He is quick to inform tour-takers that the 11.6-acre plot beneath the stadium was bought by the Yankees from the Astor estate in 1921 for $675,000. An hour in his company will send a listener home with the knowledge that no player has ever hit a ball completely out of the park, though two have come fairly close -- Negro Leagues slugger Josh Gibson in 1934 and Mickey Mantle in both 1956 and 1963. 
"It's part of my life, this place, a part of me," he said the other day inside the Babe Ruth Hall of Fame Suite, a luxury loge one level up behind home plate. "I have a lot of feelings here that go way beyond fandom, way beyond making this the place I go to work."
Mr. Morante has worked at the stadium since 1958 -- first as an usher in the upper deck -- but his job as tour guide has become a bit uncertain in recent weeks. Just before leaving office, the departing mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, announced a $1.6 billion plan for new stadiums for the Yankees and their crosstown rivals, the New York Mets.
With the city's finances shaken by recession and terrorist attacks, even the Boston Red Sox may have a World Series ring or two before Yankee Stadium is replaced and demolished, although the talk of tearing it down has Mr. Morante thinking. He has been gathering arcana on the ballpark for more than 40 years, and all that knowledge could, with the stroke of a pen, be rendered obsolete.
"I'd hate to see it go, I really would, but you can't be mired in the past," he said. "Mr. Steinbrenner" -- that is, George Steinbrenner, the Yankee's principal owner -- "is looking toward the future. It's up to the boss, and I'm sure the boss will do whatever is best for the team."
If this sounds like the company line, it is, but the look in Mr. Morante's eye -- like that of a boy who expected a chemistry set for Christmas but got a pair of socks instead -- betrays far more than his words do.
He was 6 when he first set foot in Yankee Stadium. He knows which locker Joe DiMaggio used.
His father was an usher, too, and man and boy worked side-by-side in the now-vanished mezzanine loges that were known as Millionaire's Row. His father would tell him things like, "Yo, let's go! Six hot dogs for the gentlemen from Howard Johnson's!" And Tony Jr. would fetch those hot dogs fast for 10-cent tips.
His father, Tony Sr., ("Use the name Tony in the Bronx," he says, "and you've got it right at least 50 percent of the time") was the first civilian on the field to congratulate Don Larsen on his perfect game in the 1956 World Series. The Yankees have a film clip of the moment, and Mr. Morante employs it as part of his tour. It always chokes him up to see his father storming the mound, arms up in a swarm of players, ecstatic and bouncing in his pageboy cap. 
Mr. Morante gives his tours each day at noon at the price of $12 for adults and $6 for kids, and they are filled with personal memories. His style is that of an old pal leading you through the creaky rooms and hallways of his house. For every scripted line about scalloped facades and triumphant Yankee dynasties, there are off-the-cuff remembrances. He walks backward, facing his group, and recalls working on the three-man suicide squad that protected Mantle from the fans by meeting him at second base at the end of a game and escorting him off the field. 
When he tells people that the center-field fence used to be much farther away from home plate than it is now, it is embedded in a story about his favorite Yankee moment -- Chris Chambliss' pennant-winning homer in 1976. When he reminds his listeners that the New York Giants football team played there for several years, it comes with the tale of watching his father knock out a rowdy fan who tried to pull the goal posts down.
Tony Morante was raised in Bathgate, a neighborhood in the central Bronx, and except for a brief tour in the Navy and a four-year stint on Wall Street has never held a job outside the stadium walls. He wears a 2000 World Series ring on his left middle finger and sometimes greets people with a hearty "Top of the morning!" He is of Bronx-Italian extraction, pronouncing mozzarella cheese the way it should be: "mutz-a-rel."
In January, the right-field line is buried in snow and the infield a mound of fresh-turned dirt. As Mr. Morante begins his tour in the press box, he mentions that a 19th-century reporter by the name of Henry Chadwick created the art of sportswriting. His group, however, seems far more captivated by the wintry diamond below, was reminiscent of a Hollywood starlet caught on the street without her makeup on.
He takes his group down to the clubhouse for a 10-minute lesson on the uniforms the Yankees have worn for nearly 100 years. The interlocking NY, he says, was designed by Louis Comfort Tiffany in 1877 to commemorate the first police officer shot in the line of duty in New York. The design was eventually adopted by the team.
Mr. Morante is just a tour guide, but he has ambitions and is rapidly branching out. He contributes the occasional column to The Bronx Times Reporter, a local newspaper, and is hard at work on a book entitled, "Baseball: The New York Game."
The History Channel has tapped him to do a segment on the famous deal that brought Babe Ruth from the Red Sox to New York, and Fordham University has asked him to submit a proposal for teaching a college course on baseball history. There is even some loose talk floating around his office that he will be named the official curator of the new Yankee Stadium, if one is ever built.
Still, Tony Morante will miss the old place, should it vanish. He will miss telling wide-eyed tourists that Derek Jeter has an extra locker in the clubhouse for his fan mail. He will miss telling them that the Yankees have worn their pinstriped jerseys since April 11, 1912.
He sits in the Babe Ruth Suite when his tour is done and, once more, watches the old clip of his father rushing the pitcher's mound in 1956. The film jumps to last year's World Series, when the Yankees, their backs to the wall, won the next two games at home. The narrator says, "Two nights! Two dreams!" and Tony Morante repeats it under his breath. "I still get goose bumps," he says.
By now, he is staring out the window of the loge, at the mezzanine boxes where Millionaire's Row once stood.
"I used to run up and down those stairs," he says. "I had a chance to meet all those wonderful people. They touch you in so many different ways and give you memories that you're able to take with you.
'It's gonna be tough, it's gonna be tough. You can't be mired in the past, you have to embrace the future. And there's at least another four or five years, right? And I'll be able to say it's been a good run."

HEADLINE: Beliefs; 
A revival of religious traditions sweeps Vietnam. A rejection of modernization? Seemingly not.

BYLINE:  By Peter Steinfels 

 BODY:
Dong Ho is a Vietnamese village near Hanoi where for centuries families have created bold, colorful woodblock prints portraying village scenes, folk tales and national legends. This ancient art form is now supported there by Unesco. 
 But when Mary Cross and Frances FitzGerald visited Dong Ho in the spring of 2000, they found only two families pursuing that endeavor. Most of the villagers devoted themselves to fashioning the paper objects that Vietnamese burn so that their ancestors may enjoy in the afterlife the material things that those objects represent. Alongside paper likenesses of age-old items like shoes, shirts and money were ingeniously constructed paper versions of distinctly modern things like motorbikes and cellphones. 
 That image encapsulates the story that Ms. FitzGerald tells in "Vietnam: Spirits of the Earth" (Bulfinch Press/Little, Brown), a large new volume joining her text with Ms. Cross's striking, often poignant photographs.
Author of "Fire in the Lake: The Vietnamese and the Americans in Vietnam," which won a Pulitzer Prize and a National Book Award in 1973, Ms. FitzGerald reported from Vietnam at various times from 1966 to 1974 and began revisiting in 1993. 
Now, half a century after a nationalist Communist government took power in the north and a quarter-century after it extended its sway to the whole country, what she has found is an astonishing revival of traditional religious rituals and institutions.
It is a revival that, as Ms. FitzGerald sees it, and as those paper motorbikes and cellphones suggest, is far more of a piece with modernization than in conflict with it. 
At the heart of many a Vietnamese village, especially in the north, the dinh -- the communal house that serves not only as a meeting place for the elders but also as a sanctuary for the village's guardian spirit -- has been restored or refurbished. The annual festivals for the guardian spirits have been revived, complete with offerings, banquets and entertainment. (They make one think of Latin Roman Catholicism's feasts and processions for local patron saints.)
The Vietnamese cult of ancestors, Ms. FitzGerald reports, is no less resurgent, reflected in the care for ancestral altars, the resumption of family rituals and the construction or repair of lineage halls, which are shrines that contain ancestral tablets and clan genealogical charts.
Meanwhile, Buddhism, which in Vietnam coexists more or less harmoniously with Confucianism, Taoism and the cults of villages and ancestors, draws increasing numbers of pilgrims and supplicants to restored pagodas in search of divine favors or spiritual enlightenment.
Several weeks in Vietnam, sticking to major cities, well-known cultural sites and the better roads, provided this visitor at least superficial confirmation of Ms. FitzGerald's observations: ubiquitous family altars and renovated village temples and pagodas. (To be sure, some of the fresh paint was preparation for next month's celebration of Tet, the Lunar New Year, Vietnam's biggest holiday.)
Vietnamese who know the countryside also confirmed her thesis of religious revival. There was less agreement, however, on why it was occurring. 
Among the explanations were the idea that a revival of tradition was filling a void created by the collapse of Marxism, and the cynical view that government authorities were encouraging the colorful trappings of religion as bait for tourists.
Unquestionably, the government, after decades of discouraging religious practices as wasteful and superstitious, has reversed course and blessed some of them as culturally significant. In a still-poor nation that has been almost frantically trying to build a market economy for the last decade, officials are discovering, Ms. FitzGerald believes, that religious traditions may help maintain social ties and even spur productivity in a way that collectivization failed abysmally to do.
Not that Vietnam's Communist government has been converted to genuine freedom of religion. Conditions for believers are clearly improving, but the United States State Department and the United States Commission on International Religious Freedom have amply documented the many restrictions that continue to hamper even officially recognized religious institutions, like Roman Catholicism and the Buddhist umbrella group organized by the government itself in 1981.
The government regulates their choice of leaders, limits their recruitment of clergy and keeps a tight rein on their few publications and charitable activities. Groups that are not recognized -- like the Protestant "house churches" of ethnic minorities in the mountain areas or the dissident United Buddhist Church of Vietnam -- face harsher forms of suppression, though often more by arbitrary local officials than by the central government.
What the Vietnamese Communist Party fears is obviously not personal or familial piety but anything that could become a rival political base or a nucleus of ethnic separatism.
Those possibilities seem distant, however, from the hopes that bring women to offer fruit and to light joss sticks at the Quan Su Pagoda in Hanoi or the devotion that packs people into Sunday Mass at nearby St. Joseph's Cathedral. 
Ms. FitzGerald does not rush to judgment about any of this -- how much reflects a popular religious "equivalent of insurance policies" in an unfamiliar, high-risk economy; how much reflects a need for social ballast in a turbulent time; how much reflects a profound search for spiritual meaning and transcendence.
But she does challenge the often-assumed simple opposition between religious revival and modernization.
"In Vietnam," she writes in the January issue of Smithsonian magazine, in a condensation of her text, "the revival of the rites does not mean a return to the past. People reconstruct their lineage halls and their dinh ceremonies, but they do not therefore reject public schools, agricultural machinery or the considerable improvements in the status of women."
"What we are witnessing is the traditional order reasserting itself in order to deal with what Westerners blithely call modernization," she concludes. "The Vietnamese are going back to tradition and forward at the same time. More precisely, they are reclaiming and refashioning their traditions in order to move on." 
Which in fact sums up a great deal of religious history.

HEADLINE: GROUND ZERO: UNEMPLOYMENT; 
Jobless Funds Running Low in New York

BYLINE:  By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
New York State is about to run out of money to pay unemployment insurance benefits, prompting state officials yesterday to ask the federal government for up to $740 million in loans. 
 The state has also asked the federal Department of Labor for a grant of $266 million to cover the unemployment benefits of the 103,641 people that it says have been displaced so far by the World Trade Center disaster. While the loans are automatically authorized, such a grant would require Congressional approval. 
 As of the middle of January, the unemployment insurance fund had about $200 million, down from $1.2 billion a year ago, said Betsy McCormack, director of communications for the State Department of Labor, which administers the insurance fund. The state is asking for $90 million in February, $350 million in March, and $300 million in April.
Statewide, initial claims for unemployment insurance benefits shot up in late September and early October, when more than 30,000 people a week applied for benefits, more than half of them in New York City. While applications for benefits subsequently dropped off, they remain about 30 percent higher than at this point last year (and 40 percent higher in New York City).
Labor advocates have been complaining for months that the fund's reserves have been too low, but Ms. McCormack said that the state has a policy of trying to keep payroll taxes low.
The insurance fund is paid for by taxes on employers. Those taxes will rise this year, by $35 to $42 an employee a year, or by 12 percent to 16 percent, Ms. McCormack said. The amount companies pay per worker varies widely and depends, in part, on how often they lay off employees. 
New York should have been building up reserves in the fund in anticipation of having to cover more laid-off workers during a recession, said Maurice Emsellem, director of public policy for the National Employment Law Project. 
Having to borrow the money "is not good planning and in the end it hurts workers," Mr. Emsellem said. "There will be more pressure to deny benefits because the funds are low, and it will be much more difficult to expand benefits." 
Currently, laid-off workers can receive as much as $405 a week for half a year, though they can be required to take a job after 13 weeks. The state forecasts that workers laid off because of the events of Sept. 11 will get an average of $283 a week.

HEADLINE: Still Shortchanging the City's Schools 

BYLINE:  By Michael A. Rebell; Michael A. Rebell is director of the Campaign for Fiscal Equity.

 BODY:
Governor George Pataki said, in this year's State of the State address, that we need to "throw out the existing school aid formula and to achieve equity." Last year he delivered a similar message, calling the current system for financing our public schools a "dinosaur" that should be "on the ash heap of history." At about the same time, State Supreme Court Justice Leland DeGrasse issued a landmark ruling in Campaign for Fiscal Equity v. State of New York, declaring the state's school funding system inequitable and unconstitutional. 
 The governor's decision in March of last year to appeal the decision has put on hold the reforms ordered by the judge, and in the absence of legal compulsion, the governor and the Legislature have done almost nothing to make education financing serve all of New York's residents. The budget they enacted last year caused widespread cutbacks in education and created even greater inequities. 
 This week, Governor Pataki issued a budget proposal that provided a veneer of reform but essentially maintained the status quo. And by keeping the state's total spending on schools at last year's dollar levels, with no inflation adjustment, the budget will almost certainly cause educational services to be reduced.
New York's political leaders will not, however, be able to ignore the movement for education finance reform for long. The plaintiffs' victory in the lawsuit last year was not an isolated event. It was the latest in a series of legal challenges to inadequate state education spending that have been filed in over 40 states. In the past 12 years, plaintiffs have prevailed in the overwhelming majority of those cases.
The astounding success of these plaintiffs is rooted in an egalitarian imperative that is part of America's political culture. The desire to have public schooling that could equally serve all Americans inspired the 19th century "common school" movement. This movement culminated in the incorporation into many state constitutions of provisions guaranteeing,as New York's constitution puts it, a "a system of free common schools, wherein all the children of this state may be educated."
Justice DeGrasse's decision held that it is the state's constitutional duty to provide students with the skills they need for sustained employment in a competitive market and to be capable voters and jurors. There is no debate that a significant number of public schools in this state are unable to carry out this duty. The lack of adequate resources to meet educational needs, particularly in urban schools, is also indisputable.
Governor Pataki now has an opportunity to redeem his political pledges -- and get beyond legal delay tactics. He should convene an education summit to bring legislative leaders, parents, teachers and community leaders together. They would be charged with developing a fair financing plan that would calculate the amount needed to provide basic services to all students, adjust appropriately for differences in costs of living in various parts of the state and ensure stable funding from year to year. This would provide students with the resources they need to meet the state's challenging new high-school graduation standards. Even if not all needs can be fully financed in this difficult time, agreement on a fair process, an appropriate down payment and a definitive schedule would further New York's constitutional commitment to providing equal educational opportunity.

HEADLINE: A Harvard Star In Black Studies Joins Princeton 

BYLINE:  By JACQUES STEINBERG 

 BODY:
One of the stars of the Afro-American studies department at Harvard University resigned his professorship yesterday and accepted an offer to join the faculty of rival Princeton University, raising questions about whether other professors from the department would follow.
 The professor, K. Anthony Appiah, resigned only weeks after another member of his department, Cornel West, said that he and other professors were considering offers from Princeton because of concerns that Harvard's new president was not fully committed to a strong department and to affirmative action. 
 After Dr. West's complaints became public, the Harvard president, Lawrence H. Summers, appeared to quell the dispute -- and to head off an immediate departure by Dr. West or other members of the department -- by professing support for diversity at Harvard. 
But Professor Appiah's appointment to the Princeton faculty, which is to be formally voted on Saturday by the university's board of trustees, poses a fresh threat to Mr. Summers's efforts to hold Harvard's nationally known department together.
Professor Appiah, an expert on African philosophy, said in an interview yesterday that he was not leaving Harvard because he shared Dr. West's complaints about Mr. Summers. Instead, Professor Appiah said he had grown tired of commuting weekly to Cambridge, Mass., from New York City, where he has lived for seven years.
But Professor Appiah's departure raised immediate questions about whether Harvard could retain the department's chairman, Henry Louis Gates Jr., who has collaborated with Professor Appiah for two decades and who, along with Dr. West, was contacted by Princeton last year. Professors Gates and Appiah were graduate students together at Cambridge, and later worked alongside each other at Yale, Cornell and Duke before joining the Harvard faculty in 1991.
"Obviously, Anthony Appiah and I are very close," Professor Gates said. "His departure would be one of several factors that I would have to consider in arriving at a decision. But for the past decade I have been a devoted citizen of Harvard. My colleagues and I have worked diligently to create a great center of African-American studies, and it would be difficult for me to decide to leave."
Professor Gates was responsible for luring academic all-stars like William Julius Wilson and Lani Guinier to Harvard in recent years.
It was impossible to determine last night whether Professor Gates would seriously consider an offer from Princeton, or was merely seeking to gain additional leverage for his department with Mr. Summers. But by his departure, Professor Appiah has strengthened Professor Gates's hand.
At the same time, the hiring of Professor Appiah, 47, is a major lift to those at Princeton who have been seeking to transform its African-American studies program, which does not award undergraduate degrees, into a full-fledged department on par with Harvard's. In a world in which the comings and goings of top scholars are often tracked as if they were trades between Major League Baseball teams, Professor Appiah's move to Princeton represents a bit of payback for Dr. West's defection to Harvard from Princeton in 1994.
A native of Ghana, Professor Appiah has written several well-received books, including "In My Father's House: Africa in the Philosophy of Culture" (Oxford Press, 1992), which The Independent of London described as "an erudite and demanding work, engaging with debates in moral philosophy, anthropology and the politics of racial and national identity." With Professor Gates, Professor Appiah created a sprawling encyclopedia on CD-ROM that sought to document the breadth of the African experience from its earliest tracings to the present day.
But it was another collaborator, Amy Gutmann, now the provost of Princeton, who ultimately won Professor Appiah over. The two wrote "Color Conscious: The Political Morality of Race" (Princeton University Press, 1998).
"I have no dissatisfaction with Larry Summers or anyone in the department at Harvard," Professor Appiah said yesterday. "I'm leaving because of the personal and intellectual opportunities at Princeton."
A Princeton spokeswoman, Marilyn Marks, said she would have no comment on Professor Appiah before Saturday. "The trustees are meeting tomorrow and faculty appointments are always on the agenda," she said yesterday. "When it happens, if it happens, when any appointment is made, at that point we would announce it. We haven't announced anything yet."
President Summers, who was traveling to Japan, said in a statement released through a Harvard spokesman that Professor Appiah had "made important contributions" at Harvard and "will be missed."
The Boston Globe first reported the rift between Mr. Summers and the Afro-American studies department in late December. The dispute was touched off during a meeting earlier in the year in which Mr. Summers urged Dr. West, among others, to serve as a leader in tamping down grade inflation and encouraged Dr. West to embark on a new work of scholarship befitting his elite designation as University Professor at Harvard. While he has written several books in recent years, Dr. West also served as an adviser on the presidential campaign of Bill Bradley and recorded a rap album.
In early January, Mr. Summers met again with Dr. West, this time to make amends, and said afterward that any perception that he had insulted the professor was a "misunderstanding."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 29, 2002

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on Saturday about a decision by Prof. K. Anthony Appiah to leave Harvard for Princeton misstated his birthplace. It was England; he moved to Ghana at age 1.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Bush Orders Review Of Contracts in Enron Case
The White House ordered federal agencies to consider dropping contracts worth more than $60 million a year with Enron and Arthur Andersen, saying the accusations swirling around the companies raised doubts about whether they should be receiving taxpayer money.
 The order continued a pattern by the Bush administration of trying to distance itself from a corporate meltdown whose aftershocks have been felt in both the political and business worlds. Page A1. 

The body of a former Enron vice chairman was discovered in a Houston suburb after he apparently killed himself. The executive, J. Clifford Baxter, quit last May after voicing concerns about the company's direction. A1.

Questions About Loans at ImClone
ImClone Systems, already facing an inquiry into whether it misled investors about the status of its cancer drug, disclosed that its chief executive, Samuel D. Waksal, has lost 80 percent of his shares because they had been pledged as collateral for loans. The fact that Dr. Waksal had borrowed against his stock could raise questions about whether he had an incentive to keep the stock price high. C3.

At least six drug makers have received approval to market metformin, a generic version of the diabetes drug Glucophage. C3

Sales of Homes Fell in December
Sales of existing homes fell 0.8 percent in December, although total sales in 2001 were a record 5.251 million units, the National Association of Realtors reported. The total for the year eclipsed the previous record of 5.205 million homes in 1999. C3.

Canadian Companies Talk Merger
Two oil and gas producers in Canada, Alberta Energy and PanCanadian Energy, said they were discussing a possible merger. The combined company would have a market value of about $12.5 billion. C2.

Ericsson Posts a Loss for 2001
Ericsson, the maker of telephone equipment, has reported its first unprofitable year in half a century and warned that losses in the first quarter would be greater than expected. Ericsson's sagging fortunes are emblematic of wider problems facing the industry. C2.

Amazon Looks for an Encore
Talk to Jeffrey P. Bezos, the co-founder and chief executive of Amazon, and he will speak of myriad ways that Amazon has refined its strategy and tactics over the last year. But what is most striking is how, unlike nearly every other Internet company, Amazon is not pulling back from the audacious combination of ambition and idealism that drove his initial vision. News Analysis. C2.

Conflicting Signals for the Market
Investors gave blue chip shares a lift but pushed technology shares slightly lower as they tried to deal with conflicting economic signals. The Dow Jones industrial average finished up 44.01, closing the week with three sessions on the upside. C7.

Alaska Air Reports a Loss
The Alaska Air Group, the parent for Alaska Airlines and Horizon Air, said that it had a net loss of $36.4 million, despite receiving more than $50 million from the government. C7

The AMR Corporation has rejected a proposal from its American Airlines pilots to shift the flying of regional jets to American Airlines from its commuter unit, American Eagle. C7

A Move to Join Asbestos Claims
The Big Three automakers have asked a federal judge to consolidate most asbestos claims pending against them in an effort to thwart the kind of crippling liabilities the lawsuits have spawned in other industries. C7.

HEADLINE: GOLF; 
Waldorf Moves Up; Tryon Set to Move On

BYLINE:  By CLIFTON BROWN 

DATELINE: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Jan. 25 

 BODY:
Duffy Waldorf did enough to take the lead. Ty Tryon did enough to make himself proud.
 When today's second-round play was suspended because of darkness, Waldorf was the clubhouse leader at 12 under par. His second straight 65 gave him a 130 total, one stroke better than Vijay Singh and Rory Sabbatini. Tryon was six over par through 15 holes, with virtually no chance to make the projected even-par cut when second-round play resumes Saturday morning. 
 Tryon, however, insisted he would remember this week fondly. After his awful opening-round 77, which included five bogeys over his first seven holes, Tryon, 17, showed his resiliency, playing his last six holes today at two under par, including consecutive birdies at No. 13 and No. 14. Tryon also soaked up the atmosphere, inspired by the fans who cheered him late this afternoon, while looking forward to his next event, the Genuity Classic, in Miami (Feb. 28 to March 3).
Tryon, the youngest player to earn his PGA Tour card, also showed his sense of humor when reminded that he was one of 25 players who would complete their second rounds Saturday morning.
"I made it to the weekend," Tryon said, smiling. "I knew I'd make it to the weekend somehow.
"I learned a lot this week. There was so much buildup coming into this tournament. I had a great time. I learned how to deal with all the pressure, and what happens when you don't deal with it the right way. I could've given up. I was seven over through my first nine holes, which isn't very good in professional golf. But nine holes isn't going to ruin my whole year. I just have to keep my head up and keep going."
Waldorf, meanwhile, will try to keep it going this weekend. A four-time winner on the Tour, Waldorf is coming off a subpar 2001, when he finished 120th on the money list and managed just one top-10 finish. Knowing that his chipping and putting slipped last year, Waldorf spent the off-season working on his short game, and it paid off quickly.
"I've been trying to be a little more aggressive around the greens," said Waldorf, who made a 25-foot chip-in for birdie during a round that included seven birdies, an eagle and three bogeys. "My short game has been better this year. That has really been the difference."
After missing the cut at the Sony Open in Hawaii, Waldorf bounced back with a tie for 31st last week at the Bob Hope Chrysler Classic. Building on that momentum, Waldorf has been solid off the tee this week, enabling him to capitalize on the three par-5's at the T.P.C. of Scottsdale. Through two rounds, Waldorf had made five birdies in the six par-5's. The only exception was No. 15 today, where he made eagle.
"That's a good exception," Waldorf said.
Known for his colorful shirts and the unorthodox markings he puts on his golf balls, Waldorf wore a relatively subdued outfit today, including a light-blue hat that read "The Duffy." In a sign of the economic times, Waldorf does not yet have an endorsement contract for the front of his hat. Waldorf has gotten some offers but none that he has found acceptable.
"I'm not going to give it away, it's business," Waldorf said. "Instead of taking a low offer, you'd rather just wait for a better deal to come along. Either a better deal will come, or times will change and there will be more deals available."
If Waldorf wins this weekend, it will only help his business leverage. And if he continues to putt as well as he did today, he will not fall out of contention. Waldorf made three putts from 25 feet or more for birdie, keeping the momentum in his round headed in a positive direction.
"I haven't putted that well for quite some time," Waldorf said. "I feel good on the greens. It's interesting. I was almost better off putting long ones for birdie than short ones for par."
So, while the tournament was far from decided, Waldorf liked his position heading into the weekend, after missing the cut at Phoenix last year.
"I kind of found my game early last week and it carried through for a good tournament," Waldorf said. "I'm playing well."

HEADLINE: Letter to Kmart Starts an Accounting Inquiry 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE KAUFMAN with GREG WINTER

 BODY:
The Kmart Corporation said yesterday that it had hired outside accountants to investigate charges made in an anonymous letter "expressing concern regarding unspecified accounting matters."
 Kmart, the third-largest retail chain, which filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday, said that it had informed the Securities and Exchange Commission about the letter and that the commission had "subsequently authorized a private investigation." The commission declined to comment. 
 A Kmart spokesman, Jack Ferry, said the discount retailer received the letter "about a week ago."
"It was unsigned and very vague," Mr. Ferry said, "but it did raise questions about accounting, and we take that very seriously."
Despite the vagueness of the charges, Kmart has little choice but to take them seriously, financial analysts say, in the context of heightened sensitivity to corporate wrongdoing as a result of the collapse of the Enron Corporation and questions surrounding the work of Enron's auditors at Arthur Andersen.
The letter was addressed to the S.E.C.; Kmart's auditor, PricewaterhouseCoopers; and the Kmart directors. "The letter has been referred to the audit committee of the board of directors," Kmart said in a release, "which promptly engaged outside counsel and accounting consultants to conduct an independent investigation."
The contents of the letter were also disclosed to the bankers who were discussing debtor-in-possession financing for the company last week, a person close to the negotiations said. The bankers are not concerned that accounting irregularities played a part in Kmart's bankruptcy filing, that person said.
Although the banks that lent money to Kmart may say they are contented with its financial practices, many of the company's suppliers, which together face losses of hundreds of millions of dollars, are angry and asking questions. 
In particular, some suppliers have questioned the timing of Kmart's decision to file for bankruptcy protection, as the company still had $300 million on its bank loan and ample inventory.
"They could have gotten the money from the banks," said an executive with a factoring company that had significant exposure to Kmart. 
At a hearing on Tuesday before Chief Judge Susan Pierson Sonderby at United States Bankruptcy Court in Chicago, Kmart's lawyer, John W. Butler Jr. of the firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, said the events that led to the bankruptcy filing could be described as a perfect storm.
He cited several factors including a rapid decline in liquidity, losses in the surety bond market, erosion of supplier confidence, the recession and "unprecedented difficulty in the holiday season."
This will not be the first time that Charles C. Conaway, who is Kmart's chief executive, is at the helm of a company facing an investigation into its accounting. 
In 1999, while Mr. Conaway was the chief financial officer of the drugstore chain CVS, the S.E.C. conducted a review of that retailer's accounting practices. In the end, the commission simply required CVS to shift $11.9 million in merger costs to 1997 from 1998, a resolution that many people on Wall Street took as a clean bill of health.
Kmart has also been through three chief financial officers in less than two years.

HEADLINE: ENRON'S MANY STRANDS: CLOSE TIES IN TEXAS; 
Questions Arise on Law School Dean's Enron Duties

BYLINE:  By JOHN SCHWARTZ 

 BODY:
When the Enron Corporation made the last payment on a $250,000 pledge to the University of Texas Law School last February, the school's dean, William C. Powers Jr., added a handwritten note to his official response: "Thank you for all you do for us!"
 Nearly a year later, Mr. Powers sits on Enron's board and heads an internal investigation of the partnerships that hid the company's losses. Mr. Powers was made a director in late October and was asked to lead the internal investigation. His committee is cooperating with the Securities and Exchange Commission on its investigation. 
 Critics, who have long complained that Enron's money has brought it influence and a cozy relationship with government officials in Texas, Washington and beyond, are complaining that the appointment of Mr. Powers is more of the same. The Enron executive Mr. Powers wrote to, James V. Derrick Jr., was the company's general counsel, a major fund-raiser for the law school, and until recently, a trustee of the Law School Foundation, which supplements Mr. Powers's salary.
Mr. Powers argues that none of the relationships have affected his impartiality. Others say the relationships raise inevitable conflicts of interest that make it impossible for him to do the job properly.
"The exchange between Dean Powers and Derrick exemplifies the close relationship between Enron and U.T. law school," said Cristen D. Feldman, a lawyer with Texans for Public Justice, a group that monitors the ties between money and power in the state. "He's being paid by the very interests he's investigating."
"Despite various justifications and purported safeguards," Mr. Feldman said, "a reasonable analysis suggests Powers should consider resigning from one position or the other."
Mr. Powers noted that his appointment occurred at the end of October, after disclosures about questionable partnerships had forced Enron to write off about $1.2 billion in stockholder equity but before the company's collapse. Enron's board, he said, "wanted to get to the bottom of it, and they wanted to bring in somebody from the outside."
Mr. Powers said he was "happy and willing" to take on the board position and committee work because of the importance of Enron to the Texas economy and to Texans.
"It was, I think, a service to the company at the time, and a service, ultimately, to the public to find out what happened with these transactions," he said. "I do think that we are fulfilling that goal." 
The company, he said, has "cooperated fully" with the S.E.C. inquiry and has given his committee "full access to what we've needed."
Mr. Powers declined to comment on the accusations of illegal shredding by employees of Enron and of the company's auditors at Arthur Andersen. But he said, "We have reviewed many, many documents and feel we will be able to give a report on the nature of the transactions."
As to whether people would trust a report that was produced under these circumstances, Mr. Powers said, "Of course, the report will speak for itself, and people will have to evaluate it." He declined to say when the report would be released.
"We're working as fast as we can," he said. "We can't put a date on it."
A graduate of the University of California at Berkeley and Harvard Law School, Mr. Powers, 55, first came to the University of Texas in 1977. His students recall him as an uncommonly gifted teacher who breathes life into the arcane. He is a nationally recognized expert in the law of torts and product liability, and in the pitched conflict between trial lawyers and defense lawyers, is often identified with the defenders.
Mr. Powers said the contention that he was trapped in a web of conflicts was overblown. Mr. Derrick, he said, left the Law School Foundation board when Mr. Powers joined the Enron board specifically to avoid any conflict. He added that his salary supplement does not present a conflict because the amount that he receives is not controlled by the Law School Foundation. "It's a salary structure locked in place," he said. "The changes are raises that the university gives me."
Those who know Mr. Powers say that, whatever the appearances raised by the Enron appointment, he is a man with an unswerving moral compass. "He is one of the most honest people -- personally, morally and in public life -- of anyone I've met," said Mark G. Yudof, the president of the University of Minnesota and a former dean of the University of Texas Law School. "I just don't worry that he would be influenced by matters or interests external to doing the job that he's taken on. He won't be. I know that to a dead certainty."
But an expert in corporate governance suggested that even the most honest person should avoid the appearance of a conflict of interest when dealing with such an explosive issue. 
"The optics are not good," said Charles Elson, director of the Center for Corporate Governance at the University of Delaware. "The better part of wisdom would have been to say, 'No thanks.' " 
Had the Enron board needed an impartial outsider, Mr. Elson said, it should have approached someone from another state. "There are a lot of good law school deans out there," he said. 
As for Mr. Powers, Mr. Elson said: "He's got a great rep. Why open himself up to this?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: William C. Powers Jr., the dean of the University of Texas Law School, working at his desk in Austin. He denies that his relationships with Enron have affected his impartiality in leading an internal investigation. (Frank Curry for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Enron for Dummies 

BYLINE:  By Bill Keller; E-mail: billkeller@nytimes.com

 BODY:
"I saw this week that President Bush is 'outraged' by the Enron scandal, and I know I should be too, but there's a lot I still don't get. For starters, what kind of company is Enron, exactly?
 Enron is a new-economy company, a thinking-outside-the-box, paradigm-shifting, market-making company. In fact, it ranked as the most innovative company in America four years in a row, as judged by envious corporate peers in the annual Fortune magazine poll. It is also, at this point in time, a bankrupt company. 
 I meant, what does Enron do? 
"Do?" Ah, a quaint old-economy question. You're probably one of those people who like the new no-cell-phone cars on Amtrak. Enron does a lot of things, but mainly it buys and sells energy.
What's so innovative about that?
When Enron got started, natural gas and electricity were produced, transmitted and sold by state-regulated monopolies. They were often plodding and inefficient. Enron used Wall Street magic to transform energy supplies into financial instruments that could be traded online like stocks and bonds. These contracts guaranteed customers a steady supply at a predictable price. This may be a good place to pause for an Enron Lesson. The company did stupid and venal things, but introducing the laws of supply and demand into the energy system was smart business and is, by and large, good for customers. One sad side effect of this scandal is that some good ideas may be discredited by association with Enron. 
So where did Enron go wrong?
As often happens with buccaneering entrepreneurs, it got a case of hubris. It figured if it could trade energy, it could trade anything, anywhere, in the new virtual marketplace. Newsprint. Television advertising time. Insurance risk. High-speed data transmission. All of these were converted into contracts -- called derivatives -- that were sold to investors. Enron poured billions into these trading ventures, and some failed. It turned out Enron was good at inventing businesses, but terrible at the tedious work of running them, judging by some appalling internal management audits discovered by The Times's Kurt Eichenwald. For a time, Enron swept its failures into creative hiding places, but ultimately the truth came out, confidence in the company collapsed and you now have a feeding frenzy.
How did it hide its mistakes?
To keep its mystique alive and its stock price growing, it set up partnerships where it could bury its losses, or generate imaginary revenues. Here's one of the more audacious examples, pieced together by The Wall Street Journal: Enron invested a bunch of money in a joint venture with Blockbuster to rent out movies online. The deal flopped eight months later. But in the meantime Enron had secretly set up a partnership with a Canadian bank. The bank essentially lent Enron $115 million in exchange for Enron's profits from the movie venture over its first 10 years. The Blockbuster deal never made a penny, but Enron counted the Canadian loan as a nice, fat profit.
Um, I'm not sure I follow that . . .
Neither did the Canadian bank, which now holds a lot of worthless Enron i.o.u.'s. Enron also seems to have baffled the accountants at Arthur Andersen, the bankers at J. P. Morgan, the Wall Street geniuses who touted Enron stock, and those C.E.O.'s who kept voting Kenneth Lay, now abruptly retired, the mastermind of the year. Also (with some exceptions) the business press. 
Did Enron break the rules?
Whether it broke the law is yet to be determined. Various prosecutors are undoubtedly reviewing the statutes on accounting fraud, insider trading and illegal destruction of documents, among other crimes. But rules were for sissies. These were invincible innovators, who sneered at rules. In that respect, they were the quintessential 90's company.
What's that supposed to mean?
The company embodied the get-obscenely-rich-quick cult that grew up around the intersection of digital technology, deregulation and globalization. It rode the zeitgeist of speed, hype, novelty and swagger. Petroleum was hopelessly uncool; derivatives were hot. Companies were advised to unload the baggage of hard assets, like factories or oilfields, which hold you back in the digital long jump, and concentrate on buzz and brand. Accountants who tried to impose the traditional discipline of the balance sheet were dismissed as "bean-counters," stuck in the old metrics. Wall Street looked to new metrics, new ways of measuring the intangible genius of innovation, and the most important metrics were the daily flickers of your stock price. Above all, everyone was looking for the killer app.
"Killer app?"
You are clueless. The killer application was the world-beating opportunity. (Mr. Lay called that Blockbuster deal "the killer app for the entertainment industry.") As often as not, the killer app was not a new product or service, but a beautiful loophole. In the new-economy best seller "Unleashing the Killer App," the first example is a guy who realizes that gas stations in Germany are exempt from the country's rigid early-closing laws for most stores. Voila! German gas stations become virtual shopping malls. By the way, in the 90's, expressions like "killer app" were widely believed to have an aphrodisiac effect. 
So it was about sex, after all?
Oh, absolutely. Wall Street was the new Hollywood, risk was the new testosterone, Lou Dobbs was Leonardo DiCaprio. Accountants called themselves consultants and bought Miata convertibles. And how cool was Enron? About two years ago a Fortune magazine writer likened utilities and energy companies to "a bunch of old fogies and their wives shuffling around halfheartedly to the not-so-stirring sounds of Guy Lombardo. . . . Suddenly young Elvis comes crashing through the skylight." In this metaphor, the guy in the skin-tight gold-lame suit was Enron. The writer left out the part where Elvis eats himself to death.
That reminds me, is it true what they say about the name "Enron"?
Mr. Lay wanted to call it Enteron, until they realized that was a biology term for the digestive tract. In hindsight, Enteron seems right for a company of such ungoverned appetites. Though I prefer my wife's name for the company: End Run.
Did Enron buy political influence?
Please. That's not the way things work in Washington. Enron bought access. Money just got it in the door to make its case. (The case it made probably went something like this: If the government does things Enron's way a lot of people will get very rich and they will be very, very grateful to the wise leaders who made it all possible.) If you're asking whether the Bush administration did favors for Enron, sure it did -- and so, by the way, did the Clinton administration, and both parties in Congress. Attention has focused on a number of fascinating loopholes lawmakers and regulators secretly customized for Enron. But -- and here's another Enron Lesson -- most of what Washington contributed to the glory of Enron it did in plain sight. Politicians demonized government regulation, and methodically dismantled the safeguards set up in previous downturns to protect little investors. They promoted the cult of stock-market speculation, even calling for Social Security funds to be fed to Wall Street. They cut taxes and all but stopped auditing tax returns. I'd say Enron's campaign donations, about $6 million over the past dozen years, paid off better than most of its other investments. 
Isn't that what free markets are all about -- getting government out of the way?
Yes and no. Free-marketers believe in reducing regulation. Enron believed in reducing regulation of Enron. Enron was perfectly capable of lobbying for the federal government to take over the electric power grid from the states -- hardly a free-market position, but one that would have made life easier for Enron. It lobbied for tighter regulation of air pollution, because it had figured a way to make money trading emission credits. And at the end Enron sure seemed to be fishing for a bailout. More important, a central tenet of capitalism is that people who run companies are subject to the discipline of the marketplace, as meted out by the shareholders. That can't work if the shareholders are lied to about the condition of the company. Another Enron Lesson: The louder someone yells "free markets!" the closer you want to look at his files (assuming they have not been shredded). 
But the administration didn't bail out Enron at the end, right?
No, the administration declined to climb aboard that sinking ship. A final Enron Lesson: When business and politics meet, Kenny Boy, it's not a relationship, it's a transaction.
What happens now?
A witch hunt, of course. In the end, with any luck, Congress will stop some of the money sloshing around the political system, and restore a bit of law and order to the wild frontier. But first, a few burnings at the stake. My wise friend Floyd Norris says there's a basic law of the market: When you get rich, it's because you're smart. When you get poor, it's because somebody cheated you. Just as Enron embodied the stock-market delirium on the way up, it will, now that the euphoria is over, be the scapegoat for all those smooth talkers who convinced us dummies that we could be rich.

HEADLINE: ENRON'S MANY STRANDS: COLLEGE REACTIONS; 
Business Students Fret Over Their Job Prospects

BYLINE:  By JOBERT ABUEVA 

 BODY:
If a visit to Columbia University is any gauge, business school students are less concerned about the damage the unfolding Enron scandal has inflicted on the accounting profession's reputation than the threat it poses to their job prospects.
 Not that those who specialize in accounting aren't a bit defensive these days. Jeannie Craig, a certified public accountant who began her first year in Columbia's M.B.A. program this week, painted the collapse of Enron and the destruction of documents relating to the energy trading company by Arthur Andersen as an aberration. 
 "Accounting is a noble profession," said Ms. Craig, who spent eight years in auditing, finance, and mergers and acquisitions at Ernst & Young in Baltimore. "I know several accountants who are very committed and take pride in the work. I'm glad I am an accountant. You know how a business is run." As for the Enron implosion, she said: "There is no perfect system. Flaws exist in every type of profession." 
The main reaction by students to the financial lapses at Enron and Arthur Andersen, though, was fretfulness at how the disclosures might affect their professional futures.
"It's another jab or punch, a source of frustration," said David Magstadt, a first-year student from Oklahoma who arrived early Tuesday morning to plug in his laptop at the school's Career Resource Center and is hoping to get a summer internship at a bank. Mr. Magstadt, who before enrolling in Columbia had been an information-technology consultant for Accenture, formerly Andersen Consulting, said he and many of his peers were primarily concerned about landing a job, summer or permanent.
At least the scandal has injected a little excitement into the academic routine. Manipulation of earnings was a theme emphasized in his last accounting class, he said, and "I can see how lively all classes are going to be here on out as everyone will have something so real and dynamic to draw from."
Even people with connections to Enron seemed more distressed about the scandal's impact on their job outlook than dismayed about any taint to the accounting profession's image. "My interviews have now deteriorated to, 'So, what happened?' " said Cristobal Perdomo, a second-year entrepreneurship and finance student who worked as Enron's legal counsel in Mexico City last summer. "It's very distracting."
Amanda Magliano, a second-year finance student who just returned to Columbia from a ski trip to Colorado with 150 classmates, said the debate over who was to blame for the Enron debacle was the hottest topic on the slopes.
"The arguments were intense, as we had an ex-Enron employee with us who had lost his entire 401(k)," Ms. Magliano said. Like most other students, though, the aspect of the Enron affair that most gripped her attention was how it might affect her employment future. "Because so much of what was happening was secretive, it doesn't give one any more insight on how to choose which company to work for," she said.
Barak Tulin, who was in the school cafeteria eating soup and thumbing through a recent issue of The Economist with a cover featuring the Enron logo in a bed of black, said he had nothing to worry about personally. He has already landed a job as associate finance manager with the Best Foods unit of the Dutch food and soap conglomerate Unilever, he said, adding, "It's good to be insulated."
Even so, he said, with fewer corporations recruiting on campus these days, the last thing his classmates need is another cloud on their career horizons. "Many fear they'll be out of a job within a year," he said. "A recession, the Sept. 11 disaster and now this. That's a lot of blows."
Mr. Tulin said Enron had interviewed students at Columbia for financial analyst positions as late as November, a visit that some students now joke about. Recently, he said, a friend alerted him to the chance to buy an "Enron/Columbia Business School Recruiting Team" T-shirt on eBay.
At other business schools, too, students are following the Enron-Andersen fiasco closely -- but showing greater worry about the fallout on their futures than about the broader repercussions.
"It certainly casts a dark shadow on the profession," said Ana Gabriela Souza, a junior at San Francisco State University and president of its Accounting Student Association. "Everyone knows a few people within a single company are responsible, but you can't help but think it affects our prospects as well."
Ms. Souza knew she wanted to be an accountant when she first arrived on campus from Rio de Janeiro and for now remains committed to her major. But she says she cannot help but feel uneasy with the barrage of news about Enron and its ripple effects on accountants' careers. Her boyfriend, though, made light of the brouhaha.
"We try to joke about it, even ribbing classmates who just joined Andersen," said the boyfriend, Dominic LaForgia, a recent San Francisco State graduate who began working as an auditor for Grant Thornton this month. "It certainly makes my orientation training lively. Ana and I have lots to talk about, and everyone now knows what I do for a living."
For all Mr. LaForgia's levity, Paul R. Brown, chairman of the accounting department at the Stern Graduate School of Business at New York University, says the Enron scandal has a lot of students there worried.
"I've received several e-mails from students in the throes of recruiting," he said. "Everyone wants to know how endemic the problem is and how they should deal with the issue in their interviews."
For other students, the Enron story is business as usual. Dan Lichtenberger, a senior at the University of Buffalo and president of his school's chapter of Beta Alpha Psi, the accounting honor society, for example, shrugs it off as old news. "It's become more common to have major corporations and their accounting firms under scrutiny by the S.E.C.," he said.
Accountants themselves were a little more worried about their image, Dr. Brown said. Many of the full-time professionals who take part in Stern's executive M.B.A. program, he said, "are incredulous of how basic principles have been violated and at the same time questioning whether what they do for a livelihood is indeed tainted."
Industry analysts say the Enron affair is a blow to the profession because it is likely to discourage young people from entering a career with an age-old reputation for dullness. "It's been historically perceived as a boring job, with traditional firms working new hires as much as 100-plus hours a week and turnover as high as 25 percent," said Arthur W. Bowman, editor of Bowman's Accounting Report in Atlanta. Only in the last three years, he said, have firms begun paying accountants above the rate of inflation.
"Young professionals are feverishly comparing notes and the Enron-Andersen debacle is one more reason why the decline could continue," he said. "It's doubtful you'll hear anyone saying they'd like to start their career with Andersen."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Jeannie Craig, in Columbia's M.B.A. program, says the Enron-Andersen case is an aberration. (Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times); Barak Tulin has already landed a job as associate finance manager with a unit of Unilever. (Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Enron Inquiry: Lessons From a Collapse 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Enron Hearings Open, Focusing on Destroyed Papers" (front page, Jan. 25):
 Why, in the midst of war and recession, does Enron so dominate the attention of Capitol Hill and the media? In part, it's old-fashioned politics and scandal. 
 But more than that, the magnitude of the Enron story reflects a realization, by official Washington, that we've become a nation of investors. More than half of all households have money in the stock market. 
Enron's collapse and the issues it raises -- disclosure, reliability of audited financial records, behavior of executives, analysts' independence, pension plan regulations -- are no longer the stuff of Wall Street, the rich or the financial press. They are Main Street concerns.

JOE BORG
President, North American
Securities Administrators Assn.
Washington, Jan. 25, 2002

HEADLINE: The Enron Inquiry: Lessons From a Collapse 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Enron Hearings Open, Focusing on Destroyed Papers" (front page, Jan. 25):
 The causes and consequences of Enron's decline are many, and they are complex. 
Some sort of regulatory response seems called for. However, whatever the benefits of more regulation of our capital markets, there is a cost to increased regulation, and that cost should be kept in mind. 
 We certainly should try to avoid more Enrons, but we must avoid burdening securities markets and capital formation too much in the process. Our economy depends on our robust capital markets.
Enron's fall may have rocked investor confidence and sadly wiped out the life savings of thousands of people, but excessive regulation of our securities markets has its own costs. Overreaction to Enron's collapse may do more harm in the long run than good.

TROY PAREDES
St. Louis, Jan. 25, 2002

The writer is associate professor of law in corporations and securities regulation, Washington University.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW; 
Castro's Road, a Historical Pageant

BYLINE:  By RON WERTHEIMER 

 BODY:
Cuba is back in the news with the arrival of prisoners from Afghanistan at the Guantanamo Bay naval base. But that hasn't aroused in the American public any renewed interest in Cuba's maximum leader, Fidel Castro. This apathy isn't likely to be disturbed by "Fidel," the lumbering two-part biography on Showtime tomorrow and Monday nights.
 The history lesson is confusing and the drama minimal in this film, which follows Mr. Castro's progress from youthful rabble-rouser in 1949 to successful revolutionary in the 1950's to tired old dictator today. The filmmakers have squandered an opportunity to explain -- or at least speculate about -- a fascinating player on the world stage. Instead they provide a shallow historical pageant in which nothing is more colorful than the protagonist's olive-drab wardrobe. 
 The production rests uneasily on the broad shoulders of Victor Huggo Martin, who has the title role and is on screen nearly every minute. Mr. Martin is a Mexican actor making his English-language debut. He sounds as if he had learned his lines phonetically. He delivers every speech, no matter how intimate, at full oratorical tilt. Of course that could have been a matter of artistic choice by Mr. Martin or the director, David Attwood.
Mr. Martin does resemble Mr. Castro, and great care is expended to give just the right wispy quality to that trademark beard once he grows it, in the second installment. Still, you never feel the magnetism that made men follow him into battle, women follow him into bed and a nation follow him into privation. This Fidel comes across as nothing but a stubborn jerk.
The film, written by Stephen Tolkin with a nod to two Castro biographies, is most interesting in its opening passage, about the young Fidel. He's an idealistic lawyer who's outraged by the disrespectful behavior of United States sailors in Havana.
Fidel stirs up the crowd that marches on the United States embassy. Rocks fly. Cuban police officers use clubs and water hoses on the demonstrators, who include an intriguing young woman named Mirta (Patricia Velasquez). Soon Fidel is grinning at her at a party, where she asks, "Are you a communist?" He replies, "Is that because I don't dance?"
Two years later they're married and have a son. Fidel is active in efforts to supplant Cuba's American-supported government. His party is closing in on an election victory when Fulgencio Batista (Tony Plana) declares military rule. Fidel is soon on the run, dreaming of a revolution. "How else do we change things?" he asks.
Meeting with a handful of other rebels, Fidel declares, "Everyone has to give up his own private dreams and desires." Easier said then done. He's soon making love to a fellow revolutionary, a rich doctor's wife, Naty Revuelta, played by Margarita d'Francisco with the only suggestion of real emotion in this film.
Fidel leads a small band, including his brother, Raul (Maurice Compte), against an army garrison. The raid fails. Many of Fidel's men are killed. He and Raul are jailed. Naty has Fidel's daughter. Mirta divorces him and moves to the United States. Fidel is released and goes to Mexico, where he enlists Che Guevara (Gael Garcia Bernal) to the cause.
Back in Cuba with a ragtag band, Fidel begins to attract more supporters while his new right-hand woman, Celia Sanchez (Cecilia Suarez), tends his image with the press and public. Fidel and Celia are rarely apart, although the film only hints at the depth of their relationship. In fact, the film only hints at any human dimension. 
The rest of the story flies by in a blur: victory for the rebels, the Bay of Pigs, the missile crisis, the stagnation of the Cuban economy. Guevara's death makes Fidel register a little sadness. By the time Celia dies, he's too insulated even for that.
In the end Fidel is left alone. He has lost the attention of the world, the devotion of his people and no doubt his television audience, too.

FIDEL

Showtime, Sunday night at 8

Written by Stephen Tolkin; based on the books "Guerrilla Prince" by Georgie Anne Geyer and "Fidel Castro" by Robert E. HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Blue-Chip Shares Increase, but Technology Issues Fall

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Investors gave blue-chip stocks another comfortable lift yesterday but pushed technology shares slightly lower as they tried to deal with conflicting signals.
 Working in Wall Street's favor were comments Thursday by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, who said the recession could soon be over. But with many companies still unable to confirm a pickup in business, the market's gains were limited and, in many cases, were more attributable to bargain-hunting than a shift in investor sentiment. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 44.01 points, or 0.5 percent, at 9,840.08. The Dow pulled out a three-session winning streak, advancing 65.11 points Thursday and gaining 17.16 points Wednesday. 
The broader market was narrowly divided. The Nasdaq composite index slipped 4.88 points, or 0.3 percent, to 1,937.70, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index inched up 1.13 points, or 0.1 percent, to 1,133.28.
"The only way the market can get going is if earnings accelerate, and don't just sit around at the bottom," said Gary Kaltbaum, market technician for Investors' Edge Partners in Orlando, Fla. "If companies say, 'things aren't getting any worse,' all that does is bump up stocks a bit. In order to get things going, you have to have growth again, and we just don't have that yet."
Blue-chip shares enjoyed widespread gains yesterday, which analysts attributed largely to cheaper prices and somewhat to comments from Mr. Greenspan. Procter & Gamble rose $1.36, to $79.14; Honeywell climbed $1.10, to $32.70; and Caterpillar gained $1, to $50.10.
In technology trading, PMC-Sierra rose $2.29, to $24.15, after reporting a fourth-quarter loss of 15 cents a share, beating estimates by a penny.
But disappointing reports and outlooks held back the technology sector. The fiber optic maker JDS Uniphase fell 73 cents, to $7.16, on a wider-than-expected loss.
The computer maker Gateway slid nearly 18 percent, down $1.14 at $5.22, after announcing on Thursday that it would cut 2,250 jobs and close 19 stores and several offices as it deals with sluggish sales and declining market share.
Stocks have largely fallen this month amid a lack of positive news from companies. Analysts said the sell-off was not surprising given how strongly investors snapped up shares late last year based on hopes of a rebound in profits rather than evidence of growth. 
"The fourth-quarter rally was an anticipatory rally that comes as you believe the worst is over; some pullback from that was expected," said Ronald J. Hill, investment strategist at Brown Brothers Harriman & Company. "When earnings start to come through in earnest, there will be a second, more fundamental leg up. We're kind of in a hiatus right now." --------------------

Treasury Prices Fall
 By Bloomberg News
Treasury bond prices fell yesterday, completing their biggest weekly loss since early December, as investors anticipated that the Federal Reserve might start raising interest rates as soon as the second quarter. 
Two economists at firms that trade with the Fed, known as primary dealers, said the central bank would start increasing rates as soon as April after the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, said the economy's recovery might quicken. Twenty-two of the 24 primary dealers said the Fed would leave rates unchanged next week, a shift from last week when three forecast no change. 
"We're seeing a natural bottoming of the interest rate cycle," said Vic Thompson, who oversees $260 billion at State Street Global Advisors in Boston and expects that the Fed may raise rates in the second half of the year. "The Treasury market is going to anticipate rate increases by the Fed." 
The benchmark 10-year note fell 14/32 , to a price of 99 15/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, rose to 5.07 percent from 5.01 percent on Thursday. The 30-year bond declined 10/32 , to a price of 98 23/32 . Its yield rose to 5.46 percent from 5.44 percent on Thursday.
